\begin_body

\begin_layout Chapter
LBM and CAA
\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
Acoustic Pulse Propagation
\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Wave Propagation according to Linearized Navier-Stokes
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
A reduced form of linearized Navier-Stokes equation that captures the adiabatic
 sound propagation in an isothermal fluid can be written of the form
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{equation}
\left(c_{0}^{2}+\left[\frac{4}{3}\nu+\nu_{B}\right]\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\right)\nabla^{2}P^{\prime}=\frac{\partial^{2}P^{\prime}}{\partial t^{2}}
\end{equation}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
which represent a lossy wave equation.
 Here 
\begin_inset Formula $c_{0}$
\end_inset

 is the thermodynamic speed of sound, 
\begin_inset Formula $\nu=\mu/\rho_{0}$
\end_inset

 is the kinematic shear viscosity and 
\begin_inset Formula $\nu_{B}=\mu_{B}/\rho_{0}$
\end_inset

 is the kinematic bulk viscosity of the fluid.
 It has been shown by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Dellar2001"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 that the kinematic bulk viscosity in LBM-BGK isothermal model is 
\begin_inset Formula $\nu_{B}=2\nu/3$
\end_inset

 and hence the effective viscosity is 
\begin_inset Formula $\left[\frac{4}{3}\nu+\nu_{B}\right]=2\nu$
\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The equation is thus 
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{equation}
\left(c_{0}^{2}+2\nu\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\right)\nabla^{2}P^{\prime}=\frac{\partial^{2}P^{\prime}}{\partial t^{2}}\label{eq:effectiveNSac}
\end{equation}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Here a definition of the viscous relaxation time, 
\begin_inset Formula $\tau_{s}$
\end_inset

 can be useful and is defined as
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{equation}
\tau_{s}=\left(\frac{4}{3}\eta+\eta_{B}\right)/\rho_{0}c^{2}
\end{equation}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
and typical values of this quantity are approximately 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{-10}s$
\end_inset

 for gases and 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{-12}s$
\end_inset

 in liquids.
 Now, a plane wave solution can be assumed of the form 
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{equation}
P'=\hat{A}\exp\left[i\left(\hat{k}x-\hat{\omega}t\right)\right]
\end{equation}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
On substituting this equation to Eq.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand formatted
reference "eq:effectiveNSac"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 one obtains the dispersion relation
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{equation}
\left(c_{0}^{2}-i\hat{\omega}2\nu\right)\hat{k}^{2}=\hat{\omega}^{2}\label{eq:dispersion_relation}
\end{equation}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Temporal Analysis
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Here if 
\begin_inset Formula $\hat{k}$
\end_inset

 is prescribed as an arbitrary real wave number vector 
\begin_inset Formula $k$
\end_inset

, a discretised version of Eq.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand formatted
reference "eq:effectiveNSac"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 reduces to a generalized eigen value problem.
 The analytical solution for this problem was described by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Marie2009"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 and is of the form
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{equation}
\hat{\omega}=-ik^{2}\nu\pm kc_{o}\sqrt{1-\left(k\nu/c_{0}\right)^{2}}
\end{equation}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The solutions thus represent the acoustic modes propogating with phase speeds
 
\begin_inset Formula $c_{T}=Re(\hat{\omega})/k$
\end_inset

 and temporal dissipation 
\begin_inset Formula $\alpha_{T}=-Im(\hat{\omega})$
\end_inset

, hence of the form
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{equation}
P^{\prime}=\hat{A}\exp\left(-\alpha_{T}t\right)\exp\left[ik\left(x-c_{T}t\right)\right]
\end{equation}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{equation}
\begin{array}{cccc}
c_{T}=c_{o}\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{k\nu}{c_{0}}\right)^{2}} & and & \alpha_{T}=k^{2}\nu\end{array}
\end{equation}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Spatial Analysis
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "sec:Spatial-Analysis"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
If instead of prescribing a real spatial wave number, we can specify a real
 frequency 
\begin_inset Formula $\hat{\omega}$
\end_inset

, and Eq.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand formatted
reference "eq:dispersion_relation"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 can be solved for the complex wave number 
\begin_inset Formula $\hat{k}$
\end_inset

 to get 
\begin_inset Formula $\hat{k}=\pm\frac{\omega}{\sqrt{c_{0}^{2}-i\omega2\nu}}$
\end_inset

.
 In practice, this captures the distortion in the wavelength and decay of
 amplitude as the plane wave of fixed frequency propagates in space.
 Now, the phase speed is given by 
\begin_inset Formula $c_{S}=\omega/Re(\hat{k})$
\end_inset

 and spatial dissipation rate as 
\begin_inset Formula $\alpha_{S}=Im(\hat{k})$
\end_inset

, thereby giving the form of propagating wave solution as
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{equation}
P^{\prime}=\hat{A}\exp\left(-\alpha_{S}x\right)\exp\left[i\omega\left(x/c_{S}-t\right)\right]\label{eq:plane_wave_soln}
\end{equation}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where,
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{equation}
c_{S}=\sqrt{2}c_{0}\sqrt{\frac{1+\left(\omega\tau_{S}\right)^{2}}{\sqrt{1+\left(\omega\tau_{S}\right)^{2}}+1}}\text{ and }\alpha_{S}=\frac{\omega}{\sqrt{2}c_{0}}\sqrt{\frac{\sqrt{1+\left(\omega\tau_{S}\right)^{2}}-1}{1+\left(\omega\tau_{S}\right)^{2}}}
\end{equation}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Gaster Transformation
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Gaster transformation deals with relating the spatial and temporal formulations.
 If we assume that the spatial wavenumber 
\begin_inset Formula $\hat{k}$
\end_inset

 and temporal frequency 
\begin_inset Formula $\hat{\omega}$
\end_inset

 are both analytic functions of each other in the complex domain, then Cauchy-Ri
emann equations can be used used to show that 
\begin_inset Formula $Re(\hat{k}_{spatial})\approx Re(\hat{k}_{temporal})$
\end_inset

 if we assume that 
\begin_inset Formula $Re(\hat{\omega}_{spatial})\approx Re(\hat{\omega}_{temporal})$
\end_inset

 and neglect higher order terms.
 Then the temporal and spatial dissipation rates satisfy
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{equation}
\frac{\alpha_{T}}{\alpha_{S}}=C_{g}
\end{equation}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{g}$
\end_inset

 is the group velocity defined as 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{g}=\frac{\partial Re(\hat{\omega})}{\partial Re(\hat{k})}$
\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Useful approximation for Isothermal Adiabatic Pulse Propagation
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
With the above three piece wise analyses, we can make approximations for
 the case of a typical fluid whose kinematic viscosity 
\begin_inset Formula $\nu=1.5\times10^{-5}m^{2}/s$
\end_inset

 and thermodynamic sound speed is 
\begin_inset Formula $c_{0}=343 m/sm/s$
\end_inset

.
 Here the terms 
\begin_inset Formula $\omega\tau$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $k\nu/c_{0}$
\end_inset

 are of the order of 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{-5}$
\end_inset

.
 Hence the phase velocities and dissipation rates from temporal analysis
 reduces to 
\begin_inset Formula $c_{T}\approx c_{0}$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $\alpha_{T}\approx k^{2}\nu$
\end_inset

 whereas the spatial sound speed and dissipation rates from spatial analysis
 reduces to 
\begin_inset Formula $c_{S}\approx c_{0}$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $\alpha_{S}\approx\frac{\omega^{2}}{2c_{0}}\tau_{s}=\frac{\omega^{2}}{c_{0}}\frac{\nu}{c_{0}^{2}}$
\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
FWH Surface Tests
\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsubsection
Oval Surfaces
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
An oval shaped surface is first tested which is placed close to the airfoil
 to obtain a close fit to the surface, but large enough to contain the ejected
 vortices from the slat cove.
 The surface mesh used for recording the data are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Visualization-of-FWH"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The surface together with the airfoil and a slice of the dilatation field
 are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Visualization-of-FWH-2"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The upper and lower surface data are visualized in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:FWHSurface"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Schematic of the surface placement along with airfoil and the dilatation
 field 
\begin_inset CommandInset label

\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Oval FWH surface geometry and placement
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
As can be noted, while using the oval surface, the farfield prediction at
 the suction side tends to generate spurious noise in frequencies greater
 than 
\begin_inset Formula $5 kHzkHz$
\end_inset

.
 This is attributed to the effect of vorticity structures crossing the FWH
 surface which makes the quadrupole source terms significant
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Mendez2013"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 and needs to be included in the calculation.
 However, the volume integrals are computationally inefficient and instead
 surface truncation or data averaging is done such that neglecting them
 generates non-significant errors.
 As can be noted in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:truncatedfwhspectra"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, the spurious hump disappears in the calculated spectra if the surface
 is truncated at the downstream edge region.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
This truncation, however, also cause a drop in the levels for broadband
 range.
 On comparing the sound levels in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:OvalFWHSurface"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:truncatedfwhspectra"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, the drop in levels are approximately 
\begin_inset Formula $4.5 dBdB$
\end_inset

, on average, suggesting that the contribution for farfield sound from the
 truncated region is significant across the range.
 A further truncation of the surface to use only the bottom surface shows
 that a further filtering of the high frequency range is obtained but with
 little to no further loss in the broadband levels.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard

\color blue
For very low frequency, the levels drop with surface truncation and is attribute
d to the fact that in the FWH routine, the fluctuating pressure is obtained
 by subtracting a uniform mean pressure from the FWH surface recording.
 This mean pressure is not the locally averaged pressure for each node and
 hence leads to an erroneous DC component in the predicted PSD.
 
\color black
Nevertheless,
\color inherit
 very low frequencies typically 
\begin_inset Formula $<600Hz$
\end_inset

 are not considered amenable to interpretation in the experimental data
 as well due to the presence of jet shear layer noise and other background
 noises in the experimental setup.
 Also since these additional sources are absent in the simplified simulation,
 levels at low frequencies are expected to be lower than the experiment.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
On further visualization of the vorticity in the suction side using the
 Q-criterion, it can be seen that the upper side of the surface inevitably
 cross the path of large scale vortex structures with small magnitude of
 vorticity.
 This is visualized in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:qcrit_fwh_oval_large_vorticity"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 using isocontours of a low value of 
\begin_inset Formula $Q_{c}$
\end_inset

 with 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{Q_{c}}{M^{2}}=200$
\end_inset

.
 To avoid this problem we update the FWH surface using a larger C shaped
 surface that will allow for the upper surface to be placed farther from
 the HLD.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The upper and lower surface regions contribute differently to the observer
 on the suction and pressure side of the main element.
 This can be seen in the prediction made for an observer at the suction
 side by using only the bottom side of the surface.
 The bottom surface recovers the same levels as of the experiment giving
 excellent agreement for the higher frequencies.
 The tone levels are identical with the surface truncated downstream only,
 whereas the lower frequencies below 
\begin_inset Formula $800Hz$
\end_inset

 drops further.
 The contribution to the suction side observers from the top surface is
 found to be of lower amplitude than the lower surface and hence the negligible
 contribution to the spectra.
 The FWH calculation is implemented such that there involves
\end_layout

\begin_inset Float figure
placement H
wide false
sideways false

\begin_layout Section
Details of simulation that includes the Wind Tunnel Geometry:
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "sec:Details-of-WTunnelsimulation"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Wind Tunnel Simulation:
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The complete configuration of the wind tunnel setup of the original VALIANT
 experiment, which includes the converging duct and the lateral support
 plates, were simulated using the same simulation parameters of the free
 stream simulation.
 This simulation was setup by Airbus engineers (Dr.
 Maxime Itasse and Dr.
 Florian Guiho) and was reproduced at the ECL facility for the purpose of
 testing the version of the code for producing reference data.
 The full simulation requires significantly larger compute resources than
 free stream simulation since the three dimensional shear layers from the
 wind tunnel need to be resolved adequately to avoid spurious effects.
 Hence its needs a few adaptations which make the free stream simulation
 computationally cheaper while maintaining the same fidelity as when including
 the wind tunnel.
 As such, the wind tunnel simulation has the following differences from
 the free stream case:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter06_figs/WindTunnel.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 9cm
	height 9cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:simdomain"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter06_figs/WindTunnelImageWithFWH.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 9cm
	height 9cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:wtsim_fwh_placement"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Wind tunnel simulation setup in ProLB.
 A) The simulation domain of the wind tunnel geometry with the tunnel and
 HLD installed.
 b) Wind tunnel geometry with the FWH surface placed inside the flow
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Wind tunnel simulation setup in ProLB
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter06_figs/WindTunnelDrawing.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 7cm
	height 7cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Dimensions of the wind tunnel nozzle exit
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
The total physical time of wind tunnel simulation is 
\begin_inset Formula $0.078s$
\end_inset

, in comparison to 
\begin_inset Formula $0.2s$
\end_inset

 in the standard free stream case.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
The spanwise length of the domain is 1 chord length, i.e.
 
\begin_inset Formula $0.3m$
\end_inset

 for wind tunnel simulation whereas it is 
\begin_inset Formula $0.2m$
\end_inset

 for free flow simulations.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
Spanwise boundary conditions are set to wall boundaries with no slip at
 the supporting wall surface and uses a wall model.
 In free flow simulation, periodic conditions are applied on spanwise boundaries
 to mimic an infinite spanwise domain.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
The experimental setup has a nozzle geometry which creates an unsteady shear
 layer around the airfoil whereas the free flow simulations have only the
 airfoil surface as a solid generating turbulence and vorticity.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
For the case of simulation with the inclusion of tunnel geometry, the coordinate
 axis are chosen differently.
 The flow is now aligned such that the downstream axis is along the X-coordinate
 axis and the spanwise direction is along the Y-coordinate axis.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Consequently, for spanwise periodic condition in the free stream case, the
 acoustic domain is theoretically infinite allowing the waves to propagate
 without being reflected by solid spanwise boundaries.
 However, the periodic condition numerically copies the data between the
 spanwise boundaries thereby enforcing congruence of the flow variables
 at both boundaries.
 Hence, although the domain is infinite for acoustic propagation, it may
 trigger spurious periodic behaviors in the flow with wavelengths that confer
 to the domain length.
 Another effect of the spanwise periodic condition is that it tends to exert
 spanwise homogeneity in the flow if the spanwise domain length is smaller
 than that which would allow three dimensionality to develop.
 This has been investigated in previous works for the same geometry as that
 used in the present simulations
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 and also for other HLD configurations
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Choudhari2007,Choudhari2011,Choudhari2017,Lockard2022,Zhang2024"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Lockard2009"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 showed that for the development of three-dimensionality of the coherent
 structures in the cove region, a spanwise extend of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.8c_{s}$
\end_inset

 is necessary.
 For the current case simulated, this corresponds to a length of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.0312m$
\end_inset

 while the actual simulated span length is 
\begin_inset Formula $0.2m$
\end_inset

 corresponding to more than 6 times the suggested value.
 Hence this factor is not expected to affect the features of the flow simulated
 in our case and the three dimensionality is expected to develop unhindered.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
A schematic of the simulation setup using ProLB for the full simulation
 is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:simdomain"

\end_inset

 and the placement of FWH surface within the tunnel region is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:wtsim_fwh_placement"

\end_inset

.
 The FWH surface shape remains the same as the chosen C-shape surface from
 Chapter 04, but is now placed inside the tunnel such that the shear layer
 from the nozzle edges develops outside the FWH surface completely.
 Additionally, with a reduced signal length, the computation leads to spectra
 with a lower resolution.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The comparison of the wall pressure spectra obtained from wind tunnel simulation
 against that from experiment are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:FWH_ECLLBM-1"

\end_inset

.
 A juxtaposition is provided for the farfield results from the original
 full length Airbus simulation in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:FWH_AirbusLBM"

\end_inset

.
 It can be noted that a good agreement is obtained regarding the tonal frequenci
es in both cases.
 For the SPL, the first tone at 
\begin_inset Formula $1771Hz$
\end_inset

 tends to be captured adequately by the wind tunnel simulation whereas it
 was almost vanishing in the free stream simulation.
 A good agreement can be seen in general for all higher frequency tones
 (not all harmonics) along with consistently higher broadband SPL simulations.
 The higher SPL suggests that the pressure fluctuations in the cove are
 more energetic in the simulations than the experiment.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement H
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/Shared_Newton/AOA18 Compare CP/Cp_comparison_OnlyAoA18_WithWT.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 12cm
	height 12cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Coefficient of pressure 
\begin_inset Formula $-C_{p}$
\end_inset

 over the surface of HLD obtained using the LBM simulations with and without
 wind-tunnel setup included are compared against the experimental data 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Coefficient-of-pressure"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The mean wall pressure distribution obtained for the wind tunnel simulation
 and the free stream simulation are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Coefficient-of-pressure"

\end_inset

 in comparison with the same from experiment.
 The wall pressure distribution on the slat and the pressure side of the
 airfoils shows a good agreement with the experimental values for both cases.
 However, there is a strong deviation of the suction peak at the leading
 edge of airfoil for both airfoil and the slat, and delivers a value lower
 than the experimental case.
 The free flow simulation also shows an overall shift in the data due to
 uncertainity arising from the mean pressure value 
\begin_inset Formula $P_{0}$
\end_inset

 used in the experiment which is however not available (we therefore use
 the standard pressure of 
\begin_inset Formula $101325\,Pa$
\end_inset

).
 
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The discrepancies in the suction peak is hence suspected to be the effect
 of irregularity in the measurement of inlet velocity, which in our investigatio
ns was not uniform at the nozzle exit of the wind tunnel simulation, suggesting
 that the potential effect of the airfoil distorts the inlet velocity profile.
 The 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{\infty}$
\end_inset

 value used can hence lead to an erroneous 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{p}$
\end_inset

 value calculation.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tb
wide false
sideways false

\begin_inset Argument 1

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\begin_layout Standard
For comparison of the spectra obtained using the simulation that includes
 the wind-tunnel geometry against the experiment, the results are shown
 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:FWH_AirbusLBM"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 A good agreement of the farfield noise with experiment can be noted particularl
y for the broadband noise levels in the range 
\begin_inset Formula $1-10\,kHz$
\end_inset

.
 The agreement is improved at the pressure side observers Probe 2 and 4,
 which are below and upstream of the HLD (See Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:fwhobservers-1-1"

\end_inset

 in Chapter 04 for the probe locations).
 This can be attributed to the effect of the plates affecting the directivity.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Finally, there is good agreement between the hi-fidelity simulation from
 Airbus and the ECL simulation reproducing the same level of accuracy against
 experimental data for capturing the noise source mechanisms thereby validating
 the ECL framework to be deployed to study slat noise.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
Auxiliary data from free flow simulation 
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Auxiliary data
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The free flow simulation of standard case discussed in Chapter 04 has few
 auxiliary data which are relevant for the cove dynamics.
 A more exhaustive set of wall pressure plots are given in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:wp_spectras_slat-1-1"

\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:wp_spectras-mainelement-1-1"

\end_inset

 to show the variation of the spectra along the wall geometry.
 As can be noted the wall pressure spectra along the wall shows a progressive
 variation of the tonal peaks corresponding to the same in far-field spectra.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
For slat geometry, in region near the cusp the turbulent fluctuations are
 weaker compared to the trailing edge and hence captures the tonal frequencies
 with a higher level than the turbulent fluctuations.
 Near the trailing edge, these tonal features are submerged by the stronger
 levels of turbulence.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
For the main element, the strongest peak is seen for Probe 21 for 1771Hz,
 corresponding to the first main tone.
 This location is also close to the cusp.
 For other probes which are farther from the cove but on the pressure side,
 the tones are visible with progressively weakened levels towards the trailing
 edge.
 On the suction side, much like the slat trailing edge, the turbulent flow
 submerges the tonal perturbations to render a largely broadband spectra.
 Towards the main element trailing edge on the suction side, the periodic
 perturbations from the cove are weak and represent the hydrodynamic perturbatio
ns due to the reattached turbulence.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement ph
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center

	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter10/SGP079/Wall_Pressure_prob locations_PADDED.png

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\begin_body

\begin_layout Chapter
Dataset from Bayesian Active Learning
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Dataset
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
Data Description
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Description
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
To enable reuse and further extension, the dataset we obtained from the
 current thesis work is documented here.
 It is first organized into cases representing different slat positions.
 For each case, the data used to generate the LBM simulation case files
 are available in the pre-processing folder 
\begin_inset Quotes eld
\end_inset

preproc
\begin_inset Quotes erd
\end_inset

 with the connected scripts in the 
\begin_inset Quotes eld
\end_inset

templates
\begin_inset Quotes erd
\end_inset

 folder for editing the files according to case specific needs.
 For the template based setup that we used, the configuration files are
 largely the same for different cases except for the slat geometry file
 which is updated with the coordinate translation necessary according to
 the slat coordinates.
 For each case we then use the following conventions.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection*
Case names and regular expression:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Each test case for slat position coordinate is represented by a regular
 expression (regex).
 The four slat coordinates, namely Angle of Attack (AOA), Slat Deflection
 Angle (SDA), Slat Gap (SGP), and Slat Overlap (SOL), together with the
 coordinate values are used to form the case specific regex.
 Characters `p' and `n' are prepended to the value to denote positive and
 negative signs respectively.
 The python3 snippet used to generate the regex, given the four coordinate
 values are given below.
\end_layout

\begin_layout CodeBox
regex = f'AOA{AOA:+05.1f}'
\end_layout

\begin_layout CodeBox
\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset

+ f'SDA{SDA:+05.1f}'
\end_layout

\begin_layout CodeBox
\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset

+ f'SGP{SGP:+05.1f}'
\end_layout

\begin_layout CodeBox
\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset


\begin_inset space ~
\end_inset

+ f'SOL{SOL:+05.1f}'
\end_layout

\begin_layout CodeBox
regex = regex.replace('.', '')
\end_layout

\begin_layout CodeBox
regex = regex.replace('+', 'p')
\end_layout

\begin_layout CodeBox
regex = regex.replace('-', 'n')
\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection*
Folder structure
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Each of the simulation case data is stored in a folder named using the above-men
tioned regex.
 Within each case folder, the data is archived as follows
\end_layout

\begin_layout Itemize
Pre-processing - The `preproc' folder contains files that are inputs to
 the LBPre module.
 It includes case geometries in which the slat.stl file from master folder
 is transformed to obtain the file with case specific positioning, the probe
 coordinates transformed according to case requirement, and the FWH surface
 files.
 The data in this folder is then inputted to LBPre case file using its scripting
 features.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Itemize
Results - The folder `results' contains, for each of the simulated case,
 the data files generated by ProLB solver.
 The result files are formatted consistently across cases and contains the
 following:
\end_layout

\begin_deeper
\begin_layout Enumerate
Mean flow recording - MeanQuantities.xmf and corresponding .h5 data file:
 
\begin_inset Newline newline
\end_inset

The flow recordings are generated for the full domain of simulation and
 are recorded at full resolution of the mesh.
 Temporal averaging corresponds to 5 chord pass times and recording starts
 from the latest possible time step in the simulation.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
FWH surface recordings - FWH_PermeableSurface_Recording_outsurf.xmf and correspon
ding .h5 data file:
\begin_inset Newline newline
\end_inset

The FWH surface recordings are for velocity, pressure, and density data.
 Sampling rate is chosen according to requirements discussed in the main
 text.
 The recording frequency is 
\begin_inset Formula $180405\,Hz$
\end_inset

, and has a total of 49200 timesteps enabling 6 averaging bins, with 8200
 steps per bin for the Welch method for PSD calculation.
 The resulting spectra can be obtained at a resolution of 
\begin_inset Formula $44Hz$
\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
Q-criterion and Vorticity - UnsteadyCoveRecordingRes1Set#_grad.xmf and correspond
ing .h5 data file:
\begin_inset Newline newline
\end_inset

Unsteady data for Q-Criterion and Vorticity vectors in the slat cove region
 are recorded for visualizing the cove vortex behavior.
 The sampling rate is kept lower than FWH surface recording to save storage
 space and its sampling at 
\begin_inset Formula $22550\,Hz$
\end_inset

 is found sufficient for unsteady visualizations of the cove vortex evolution.
 A total spanwise length of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.016\,m$
\end_inset

 are recorded around the span-center plane from a total of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.2\,m$
\end_inset

 of spanwise length of the simulation.
 The recordings are saved in 
\begin_inset Formula $3$
\end_inset

 sets along with the spanwise length to enable faster post-processing also.
\end_layout

\end_deeper
\begin_layout Itemize
Post-processing - The folder `postproc' contains, for each of the simulated
 case, data files related to post-processing of the data.
 The post-processed data primarily has visualizations for the mean flow
 recordings, vorticity, and wall pressure coefficients.
 A slice of the mean recording in the cove region at center-span plane is
 also available as MeanData.csv.
 This recording is used for obtaining streamlines and the shear layer shape.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
All simulations and results
\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection*
All Flow Cases
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
All simulations that is a part of results in thesis are given in the Table.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "tab:allcases"

\end_inset

.
 The variables are Angle of Attack (AOA), Slat Deflection Angle (SDA), Slat
 Gap (SGP) and Slat Overlap (SOL).
 All angles are in degrees and lengths in mm.
 A total of 33 cases are documented of which the first case is the reference
 case studied in Chapter 04.
 This corresponds to the default slat positioning with respect to the airfoil
 and the coordinates are obtained from geometry available from the original
 VALIANT project
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Manoha2012"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The first three cases are the result of simulations that varied only the
 slat gap progressively.
 Among simulation 4 to 32, 10 are selected using the Latin Hypercube with
 Multi-dimensional uniformity to enable initial exploration of parameter
 space and 18 are run using the Bayesian Active Learning sampling technique.
\begin_inset Float table
placement H
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Tabular

<column alignment="center" valignment="top" width="1cm">
<column alignment="center" valignment="top" width="1cm">
<column alignment="center" valignment="top" width="1cm">

\end_layout

\end_inset
</cell>

\end_layout

\end_layout

\end_inset
</cell>

\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\end_layout

\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
List of parametric cases simulated and data archived.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "tab:allcases"

\end_inset

 
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
List of parametric cases simulated and archived
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Auxiliary results
\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsubsection
Shear layer and recirculation bubble shapes
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The results for shear layer shape extraction for cases from Bayesian Active
 Learning simulations are given in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:meanshearlayershapes-2"

\end_inset

.
 The shear layer shape varies with respect to the position of the slat.
 The most sensitive variable to the shape is the Slat Overlap.
 As the slat overlap is negative by definition if the slat trailing edge
 is upstream of the leading edge of the main element, the value needs to
 decrease to increase slats proximity to the main element.
 As it is increased, the shear layer readjusts such that the flow has to
 reverse its direction progressively in order to circumvent the main element's
 leading edge.
 This introduces a strong reversal of curvature to the shear layer.
 The initial curvature is also affected such that when slat overlap is decreased
, i.e.
 slat move closed to the main element, the initial shear layer from the
 slat cusp takes a more tangential path to the free stream flow, only to
 reverse its direction strongly.
 As the flow is more tangential to the incoming flow below the slat cusp,
 the initial curvature of the shear layer decreases leading to less instability
 effects due to curvature.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Conversely, when the slat overlap is decreased, i.e.
 the slat move further away from the main element, the cove recirculation
 shape converges such that the shear layer has a regularized curvature distribut
ion.
 This can be noticed for Case 22, which is the most noisy case among the
 dataset and the coordinates are close to the standard configuration.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
It is also possible to have configurations whose initial curvatures are
 excessively high by maintaining a high slat gap and a positive slat overlap.
 In such cases like Case 5, for example, the flow is strongly deviated towards
 the trailing edge from the initial shear layer instead of having a tangential
 flow.
 Such cases however also tend to have an early impingement with a significantly
 small recirculation region if the slat overlap is too high.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement ph
wide false
sideways false
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The shear layer trajectory at mid-span plane obtained using time integration
 of the mean velocity field for parametric cases in the dataset.
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:meanshearlayershapes-2"

\begin_layout Subsection
Far-field Noise spectra
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The farfield noise spectra for all cases simulated are given in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spectra_parametric-1"

\end_inset

.
 All computations follow the same parameters as explained in Chapter 03
 and 04.
 Case 22 has the strongest broadband and tonal components and since it is
 closest to the experimental case, this case is chosen as the basis of compariso
n.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
For cases which are close to Case 22, the broadband and tonal noise are
 largely significant.
 Cases where the slat gap and overlap are suited, the tonal frequency also
 shows changes in the selection of frequency selection.
 The first four tones are shown to have a high degree of correlation in
 their variation with respect to the slat position.
 The fifth tone however maintain a stable frequency and can be present even
 in the absence of other tones.
\end_layout

\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Farfield noise spectra for parametric cases obtained using the LBM-FWH computati
on.
 Observer location is at 
\begin_inset Formula $90^{o}$
\end_inset

to the airfoil at the pressure side.
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:spectra_parametric-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Shear Layer Curvature Profiles
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The shear layer curvature profiles are given in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:streamlinecurvature-1"

\end_inset

.
 The curvatures are computed along the mean shear layer and for a streamline
 whose origin near the cusp is chosen as detailed in Chapter 04.
 The curvature is calculated as the geometric curvature of the streamline
 and for the mid-span plane.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The curvature inflection point can be noted as the location of local drop
 in the curvature magnitude for each case.
 The location of impingement is marked by the second sharp peak after this
 inflection.
 For most cases, the curvature calculation after impingement location accrues
 a strong numerical noise.
 This is due to the low convergence of the flow features due to low frequency
 oscillating components in the flow leading to non-smoothness of the streamline
 calculation from the averaged velocity field.
 Case 22 which serves as the most noisy case is included for all plots to
 enable comparison.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\align block
\begin_inset Float figure
placement ph
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Curvature profiles along the mean shear layer for parametric cases in the
 dataset 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:streamlinecurvature-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Curvature Richardson Numbers
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The Curvature Richardson numbers for all cases in the dataset are given
 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:curvature_richardson-2"

\end_inset

.
 The calculation is detailed in Chapter 04.
 The Curvature Richardson numbers are shown to have consistent distribution
 across cases where the mean value is maintained above 0.1 and with one inflectio
n point along the shear layer where the curvature reverses sign.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The cases which shows a strong broadband and tonal noise given a red highlight
 whereas for cases whose characteristic noise is attenuated due to excessive
 overlap is given a green highlight.
 The Richardson number profile for the most noisy Case 22 is also included
 to enable comparison.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement ph
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

	filename parametric_case_images/parametric_cases/sl_path/AOAp130SDAp360SGPp040SOLn018_richardson.png
	lyxscale 10
	width 3.75cm
	height 3.75cm
	keepAspectRatio
	BoundingBox 30mm 0bp 1440bp 867bp
	groupId richardson_numbers

\end_inset

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Curvature Richardson Number profiles along the mean shear layer for all
 cases in the dataset 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:curvature_richardson-2"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Spanwise Cells
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The spanwise modulation of spanwise velocity is visualized using 3D isocontours
 for spanwise velocity.
 These cells vary according to the shear layer shape and recirculation cavity
 shape.
 The same for all cases int he dataset are shown in in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_cookies-1"

\end_inset

.
 As can be noted, the formation of cells and their cell size is dependent
 on the cove recirculation shape driven by the slat positioning.
 The presence of the shapes is also seen to be dependent on the cases where
 there exists cases with no spanwise cell formation, cases with 3, 4, and
 5 cells in total across the span.
 This also serves to bolster the notion that formation of the spanwise cells
 is not an artifact of the spanwise periodic condition but a physical manifestat
ion of the centrifugal instability of the flow inside the cove recirculation.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement ph
wide false
sideways false
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Spanwise cells of spanwise velocity demonstrated using 3D isocontours of
 the same for all cases in the dataset.
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:spanwise_cookies-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Spanwise Variation of Spanwise-Velocity Spectra
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The spanwise spectra of spanwise component of velocity near the slat cusp
 revealed a low frequency localized oscillation at the diverging planes.
 These oscillations were shown to be restricted to the vicinity of diverging
 planes in Chapter 04.
 The same was also shown to correspond to the recirculation frequency based
 on the low speed recirculation velocity inside the cove in Chapter 06.
 To demonstrate that this oscillation is a consistent feature across cases
 with consistency of the low frequency at around 200Hz, the spanwise variation
 of the spectra with appropriate color scale is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_psd_probe17_1-1"

\end_inset

, 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_psd_probe17_2-1"

\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_psd_probe17_3-1"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement ph
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename parametric_case_images/parametric_cases/PSD_hot_wire_SL/AOAp130SDAp360SGPp040SOLn018_probe_17.png
	lyxscale 10
	width 7.5cm
	height 7.5cm
	keepAspectRatio
	BoundingBox 0bp 0bp 1250bp 520bp
	clip
	groupId psd_spanwise

\end_inset

\begin_body

\begin_layout Chapter
Introduction
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Introduction to Slat Noise
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{This thesis was conducted within the VALIANT project at IMSIA
 (ENSTA Paris), focusing on aeroacoustic mechanisms of high-lift devices.
 The laboratory has a long tradition in computational and experimental aeroacous
tics, with prior studies on slat noise that motivated and framed the present
 work.}
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
High-Lift Devices (HLDs) were conceived and tested as an apparatus to improve
 airplane lift performance as early as the 1940s
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Weyl1945"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 They primarily enabled aircrafts to take off from shorter runways as in
 the case of military requirements and as the jet engine designs were adapted
 for high-speed cruise, the high-lift wings became necessary to enable take
 offs and landings with heavy payloads.
 HLDs also delayed the stall of the airfoil as well as reduced the required
 angle of attack during take-off allowing better flight controls and enhanced
 visibility over the main-body leading edge.
 The aeroacoustics of HLDs became an active area of research slightly later
 when the airframe noise was identified as a major contributor to aircraft
 noise
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citeyearpar
key "Fink1979"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 This was an effect of the rising popularity of high-bypass turbofan engine
 designs in the 1970s implicitly leading to a sharp reduction in engine
 noise, making them comparable to noise from landing-gears and HLDs.
 The latter two, conveniently called the airframe noise, is to date the
 next engineering bottleneck towards quieter aircraft designs fit for modern
 aviation
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Morgan1975"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 In light of these developments, renewed efforts in airframe noise research
 were promoted by major economies and set the target for noise reduction
 efforts by atleast -10 
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{dB}
\end_layout

\end_inset

 on average per aircraft operation (operations near airport) for the year
 2020
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Collin2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 In the European vision for aviation towards 2050, 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "EuropeanCommission.DirectorateGeneralforMobilityandTransport.2011"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 published in 2011, the long-term target was officially declared as to reduce
 the noise by 
\begin_inset Quotes eld
\end_inset

atleast 65%
\begin_inset Quotes erd
\end_inset

 from that of aircraft technologies in the 2000s – which in quantitative
 terms is by -15 
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{dB}
\end_layout

\end_inset

, a representation of the urgency for quieter civil aviation in view of
 a more sustainable aviation 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Collin2016,Leylekian2022,Dobrzynski2010"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 This also is the fuel behind our current activity and our primary focus
 is on further detailed characterization of HLD noise sources using advanced
 computational methods.
 In this process we also develop tools which enable rapid and data-driven
 aeroacoustic characterization of such complex engineering flows attempting
 to bypass the complexity of its numerical modelling.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tbh
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter01_figs/leading edge slat.png
	lyxscale 14
	width 13cm
	height 13cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
An Airbus A310-300 wing with slat and flaps deployed
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:An-Airbus-A310-300"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
HLDs typically includes two additional components on a standard wing aerofoil,
 namely the leading edge slat and the trailing edge flap as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:An-Airbus-A310-300"

\end_inset

.
 Both slats and flaps are commonly deployed in tandem during take-off and
 landing and are thus active noise sources for operation near airports.
 Among them the leading edge slat cavity has been identified as the dominant
 noise source for low and mid-frequency characteristics and the trailing
 edge flap for high frequency noise respectively
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Dobrzynski1998"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 In general, a wing with HLD generate 10 
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{dB}
\end_layout

\end_inset

 of additional noise than a normal wing 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Dobrzynski2010"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 However a complete analysis of its noise mechanisms are hindered when it
 is part of a larger set of noise sources including the airframe cavity
 noise, landing gear noise, and installation effects.
 Hence as part of efforts to isolate behavior of HLD noise sources, standardized
 sub-scale geometries were created as part of BANC workshops
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Choudhari2012"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The popular configuration is the 30P30N where the slat and flap are deflected
 at 
\begin_inset Formula $30$
\end_inset

 degrees from the main element.
 A schematic of the same is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:geometries_30p30n-1"

\end_inset

.
 Now, although both the slats and flaps contribute significantly to the
 total noise, the mechanisms behind the mid-frequency noise generation in
 the leading edge slat cavity are particularly elusive to engineers due
 to the complex cove flow dynamics.
 Hence on further sophistication of the investigations, the slat only configurat
ion had to be isolated and studied in detail.
 For the same, 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, as part of the recent VALIANT initiative
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Manoha2012"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, generated an optimized 
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{3 element}
\end_layout

\end_inset

 configuration with only the slat and main element.
 Here the flap was replaced with a sharp trailing edge for which the exact
 shape was determined via numerical optimization – the objective being minimizin
g numerical difference between the CFD solutions of cove flow between an
 optimized 
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{3 element}
\end_layout

\end_inset

 geometry and the original 3-element one
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Manoha2012"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 A drawing of the resulting 
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{3 element}
\end_layout

\end_inset

 airfoil is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:geometries_valiant-1"

\end_inset

.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Our study is primarily intended to investigate the slat-only noise phenomena.
 It includes the cove flow dynamics and the noise generation mechanisms
 arising from such dynamics.
 Hence we use the 
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{3 element}
\end_layout

\end_inset

 geometry provided by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 and refer to the same as the VALIANT HLD.
 The positioning of the slat with respect to the main element in this configurat
ion, as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:geometries_valiant-1"

\end_inset

, will be referred to as the standard geometry as well in contrast to the
 cases where we change this positioning.
 It must be emphasized that given the trailing edge of this geometry is
 not of practical relevance, and the noise associated with the same are
 also not of interest, given that there are no suspected interactions between
 this trailing edge and the cove flow dynamics via their acoustics.
 This is so far the case.
 Additionally, the removal of the trailing edge flap has an important advantage
 in enabling experimental studies.
 The 
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{3 element}
\end_layout

\end_inset

 HLD by design generates a strong lift resulting in a significant deflection
 of the incoming jet while mounted in the wind tunnel.
 The deflection necessitates that the wind tunnel installations must be
 adapted to allow this deflection.
 In the 
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{3 element}
\end_layout

\end_inset

 case, the deflection is now reduced due to removal of the deflection by
 the flap and therefore generates less lift and less deflection.
 The wind tunnel setup is thus simplified.
 Given these features VALIANT HLD is adopted for both numerical and computationa
l campaigns at carried out at Ecole Centrale de Lyon.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter01_figs/P30N-airfoil-geometry.png
	lyxscale 40
	width 11cm
	height 11cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The 30P30N high-lift airfoil is the three-element standard geometry for
 experimental and numerical campaigns 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:geometries_30p30n-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter01_figs/VALIANT Profile.png
	lyxscale 15
	width 11cm
	height 11cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The VALIANT two-element geometry numerically optimized to reduce the effect
 of flap removal upon cove flow dynamics.
 The chord size 
\begin_inset Formula $C$
\end_inset

 used for the current activity is 0.3m 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:geometries_valiant-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Comparison of standardized HLD geometries
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
That being the context of our research, to re-investigate slat noise phenomena,
 it is important to understand the current state of knowledge.
 We will summarize the current known features here with an extended account
 of the same and some closely related phenomena in the upcoming chapter.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The slat-only noise phenomena has been extensively documented, although
 with incomplete explanation, through both experimental campaigns and computatio
nal efforts since 1990s
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Dobrzynski1998,Molin2003,Lockard2009,Choudhari2011,Manoha2012,Terracol2016,Pascioni2016,Pagani2017,Bolivar2018"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Dobrzynski1998"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 were among the early researchers to initiate large scale experiments to
 investigate this phenomena and showed that the leading edge slat has a
 tonal noise signature.
 These tones reaching upto 80 
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{dB}
\end_layout

\end_inset

 were first explained to vanish in case of tripped turbulence at the slat's
 pressure side cusp but additional studies showed that they are persistent
 irrespective of turbulence conditions
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "kolb2007,Pott-pollenske2003"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 They are typically below 
\begin_inset Formula $10\,kHz$
\end_inset

 in frequency range and are identified as mid-frequency tones
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Botero-bolivar2020"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 A set of five or more of these tones are supported by a broadband noise
 component which scales with approximately fifth power of the free stream
 Mach number
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Guo2012"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 As the wind tunnel facilities improved, in the recent years, an additional
 tone which appears to be the fundamental of the main evident ones were
 also identified.
 It is referred to as the low frequency hump since this component has a
 broadband and stochastic nature compared to the other tones
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Souza2019,KamliyaJawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 An additional broadband peak at very high frequency of 
\begin_inset Formula $20\,kHz$
\end_inset

 
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{is also reported and is}
\end_layout

\end_inset

 attributed to the vortex shedding from the thick trailing edge of the slat
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Yamamoto2023"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 A typical slat-only noise spectra showing these major components are shown
 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:schematic"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tbh
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter01_figs/slatsources.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 12cm
	height 12cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Schematic showing the potential noise sources in turbulent flow of a leading
 edge slat cove, reproduced from the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Choudhari2007"
literal "false"

\end_inset


\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:schematic_a"

\end_inset


\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:schematic"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Schematic showing the potential noise sources in turbulent flow of a leading
 edge slat cove
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The study, or in particular the reasoning on mechanisms underlying slat
 tones, is but incomplete in the literature.
 The tonal noise is largely explained based on the feedback mechanism typical
 in a cavity flow and is called the Rossiter modes
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Casalino2022"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The flow develops strong turbulence as it encounters the pressure side
 cusp of the slat since there occurs strong shearing of flow between the
 two sides of the cusp.
 The phenomena can be explained based on Kelvin-Helmholtz (K-H) instability
 and leads to periodic shedding of vortices
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Terracol2016,Manoha2012"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Since the mean flow after the cusp deviates from free stream to pass through
 the slat cove, the vortices are also convected through the slat gap.
 See Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:schematic_a"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 for a schematic.
 The nozzle effect due to constriction between the slat and main element
 accelerates the flow and hence the vortices are also accelerated as distorted
 before ejection.
 At low angle of attacks, these accelerated vortices impinges on inner wall
 of the slat trailing edge leading to strong momentum fluctuations near
 the trailing edge.
 The flow then splits where one part enters the recirculation in the cove
 while the other part is ejected out of the slat gap.
 The impinged vortices generate acoustic waves due to momentum fluctuations
 and these waves, both the original ones and those amplified by the trailing
 edge scattering, travel back to the pressure side cusp, influencing the
 periodicity of vortex shedding at the cusp.
 Thus the periodic vortex shedding and resulting influence from acoustic
 waves due to its impingement leads to a resonant cycle in the cove region
 leading to selection of discrete frequencies and the resulting pressure
 fluctuations emanate as acoustic waves towards farfield
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Rossiter1964,Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 These tonal waves manifest as narrow band peaks in the noise spectra.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter05/PSD composition with Gauss peaks.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 11cm
	height 11cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Schematic of a typical slat noise spectrum showing the broadband component,
 tones, and high frequency hump
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:schematic_b"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The broadband components in the spectra has an alternative explanation although
 incomplete.
 It is suggested that the mid-frequency hump (See Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:schematic_b"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

) is generated due to the high speed turbulence ejection from the slat gap
 with a particular influence from the high-amplitude low-frequency fluctuations
 due to vortex impingement in the upstream.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Imamura2007"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 showed that PSD of turbulence fluctuations downstream of the trailing edge
 have strong correlation with frequencies of the mid-frequency hump in far-field
 spectra.
 Regarding the high frequency hump, 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Botero-bolivar2020"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 showed that frequency of this hump increases with decreasing trailing edge
 thickness.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Imamura2007"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 also showed that the frequency of this hump have a high energy content
 in the PSD of ejected turbulence.
 Hence, it can be assumed that both mid-frequency and high frequency broadband
 humps are directly related to the turbulence ejection at trailing edge.
 It is worthy to note that there may exist additional high frequency tones
 in experimental data due to periodic vortex shedding at the trailing edge
 but this is not observed in flight conditions
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Hayes1997,Pott-pollenske2003"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Additionally, more recent advances based on advanced signal processing
 methods like that of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Jawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 has shed light on the intermittent characteristic of the tones and the
 low frequency broadband hump thus shedding more light into their possible
 mechanisms.
 A detailed picture of these dynamics as known in the existing literature
 are presented in Chapter 2 and further insights from our investigations
 are presented in Chapter 4.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
At the current juncture of this research, it must be acknowledged that the
 technical tool set available for scientific computing and computational
 aeroacoustics are also undergoing a rapid expansion.
 In a recent review on computational aeroacoustics, 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Moreau2022"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 has promptly underlined the importance of advanced CFD methods including
 the Lattice Boltzmann Method (LBM) simulations.
 On par with expensive high-order schemes for Navier-Stokes equations designed
 to obtain high fidelity data of the flow dynamics, LBMs enable fast turnaround
 simulations and bring in additional features such as adaptability to complicate
d geometries using Cartesian meshes by deploying Immersed Boundary Methods
 together with a high level of parallelism
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Feng2010a,Marie2009,Satti2012,Soni2022"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Such advancements have lead to considerable reduction in the engineering
 effort required to unravel complex flow scenarios such as for those in
 real world aeroacoustic applications including slat noise
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Souza2019,Souza2022"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Popular LBM solvers like PowerFLOW have also already been demonstrated
 to have the capability to accurately capture both noise generation mechanisms
 and propagation in slat noise simulations enabling direct computation of
 their noise signatures
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Bolivar2018,Bres2007,Astoul2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Well in line with these developments, we also deploy the LBM simulations,
 to investigate the HLD noise using a newly released LBM solver 
\shape italic
ProLB
\shape default
.
 This solver is under active development during the work on this thesis,
 and although our work is not directly involved in the source code development,
 Ecole Centrale de Lyon's partnership in the solver development as been
 leveraged to obtain the necessary technical capabilities and expertise.
 Consequently, we also take maximal effort to test and validate the solver
 for our applications.
 As for contributions from this thesis towards this development, we put
 forward a cost effective simulation framework using 
\shape italic
ProLB
\shape default
 coupling it with an independent in-house acoustic analogy module based
 on the method of Ffowcs Williams-Hawkings
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Williams1969,Casalino2003"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Details and technical aspects of these implementations are presented in
 Chapter 3 of this thesis.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
A second advancement pertinent to modern aeroacoustics also comes from the
 data-driven paradigm
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Mendez_Ianiro_Noack_Brunton_2023"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 In this perspective, reduced order models for flow and acoustics computations
 are possible by leveraging on the high-quality datasets available from
 both simulations and laboratory experiments.
 Their applications in aeroacoustics are still in its infancy and hence
 a few curious experimentation are also undertaken as part of this work.
 In particular we deploy a statistical inference method based on Bayesian
 Active Learning to enable an automated inference procedure regarding the
 nature of the far-field sound spectra with respect to the 
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{position}
\end_layout

\end_inset

 of the slat.
 Using this framework and by committing the required high-performance compute
 resources, we enabled an extensive data generation campaign collecting
 more than 30 high-fidelity slat noise simulations.
 The details of 
\begin_inset ERT
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout


\backslash
textcolor{red}{its development and associated theoretical specifications}
\end_layout

\end_inset

 are presented in Chapter 5.
 Finally in Chapter 6, we utilize the data generated from these simulations
 to obtain new insights into the cove dynamics thereby facilitating advancement
 in the fundamental understanding of its phenomenology.
 All further details on the technical specifications and intermediate results
 that facilitated our progress are also included in the Appendices for completen
ess and to enable future investigators.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset bibtex

btprint "btPrintCited"

options "unsrtnat"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_body
