\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Probe 12
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Wallpressure PSD inside the slat cove compared between the simulation in
 free stream, simulation with wind tunnel, and the experimental data
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:wallpressure_psd_cove-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The discrepancies related to difference of configurations are alleviated
 to a good extend if the simulation setup includes the full wind tunnel
 installation geometries.
 Such a simulation, together with a few additional cases varying the angle
 of attacks for free stream simulation, are detailed in the Appendix A Section
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "sec:Details-of-WTunnelsimulation"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The pressure on the main-element also shows a spatially local sharp peak
 which owes to the acceleration of the flow in the nozzle like shape of
 the slat gap.
 This feature is more prominent in the simulation since continuous data
 over the airfoil wall is available.
 This acceleration is responsible for the high velocity ejection of the
 slat turbulence from the slat trailing edge and hence is likely to drive
 both the characteristic low frequency broadband noise and the high frequency
 noise.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Note
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The case with the inclusion of the wind-tunnel shows a better agreement
 with the experiment for the attacking surface of the slat.
 This is due to the better capturing of the potential effect due to the
 airfoil near the nozzle exit where the exit flow is not uniform across
 the cross flow direction.
 In the full configuration simulation, the static pressure was not measured
 and the velocity was also not uniform, but with minor fluctuations (
\begin_inset Formula $\pm1 m/sm/s$
\end_inset

 which has no measurable effect on the static pressure).
 This might be due to the fact that the static pressure is globally underestimat
ed in the free-field simulation.
 Hence the 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{p}$
\end_inset

 value at the leading edge of the main element can be seen to be weaker
 in the same case.
\end_layout

\end_inset

 
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
However, the suction pressure on both the slat and the main element is higher
 in the experiment suggesting that the total lift is higher in the experimental
 setup.
 This discrepancy is due to the uniform inflow conditions in the free stream
 simulation.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Although not conclusively, the acceleration is also responsible for the
 local disintegration of spanwise coherent vorticity which upon impingement
 drives the Rossiter oscillations.
 The differences of the 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{p}$
\end_inset

 hence can explain the difference of the generated noise in case of free
 flow from the experiment such that in the experiment, the suction peak
 is observed to be stronger and hence leading to stronger broadband noise
 levels.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\color black
The experiment tend to have the highest lift load owing to the fact that
 the HLD generates a strong deflection of the narrow width jet, thereby
 generating a strong lift.
 In the simulations, both ones with and without the wind tunnel, the lift
 performance is observed to be reduced.

\color red
 
\color inherit
Moreover,
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection

\color black
Unsteady Wall pressure data
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard

\color black
The wall pressure data inside the cove represents the dynamics of pressure
 field inside the cove.
 This includes both the hydrodynamic and the acoustic perturbations, where
 the hydrodynamic fluctuations usually dominate.
 Hence it captures both large scale fluctuations due to the vortex behaviors
 and the acoustics including resonances.
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\color black
The shapes of the spectra present some features similar to those of the
 farfield in particular concerning the tonal peaks.
 The convergence of the signals also serves as a monitor for the convergence
 of the acoustic mechanisms.
 
\end_layout

\end_inset

The PSD is calculated over a total time of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.23\,s$
\end_inset

 with a sampling frequency of 
\begin_inset Formula $180405\,Hz$
\end_inset

.
 The total number of time steps allow a Welsh averaging window of 
\begin_inset Formula $8200$
\end_inset

 time steps and 
\begin_inset Formula $5$
\end_inset

 averaging windows with 
\begin_inset Formula $50\%$
\end_inset

 overlap resulting in a spectral resolution of 
\begin_inset Formula $22\,Hz$
\end_inset

.
 The PSD is calculated using the routines provided by Python package 
\begin_inset Quotes eld
\end_inset

matplotlib.mlab
\begin_inset Quotes erd
\end_inset

 and a detrending using a linear fit for the mean value is also used for
 each window together with smoothing of the window edges using Hann window.
 For the free-stream simulation, the data is collected over the full length
 of the simulation to monitor the convergence and is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:rawdatawpsensor-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The comparison of the wall pressure spectra obtained in the free-stream
 and wind tunnel simulation are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:wallpressure_psd_cove-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 (Details of the latter are provided in Appendix A).
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard

\color black
It can be noted that both cases show a reasonable agreement with the experiment
 regarding the tonal frequencies.
 For the SPL, the first tone at 
\begin_inset Formula $1771\,Hz$
\end_inset

 tends to be better captured by the wind tunnel simulation whereas it is
 almost vanishing in most free stream curves.
 A good agreement can be seen in general for all higher frequency tones
 (not all harmonics) along with consistently higher broadband SPL in simulations.
 A higher SPL suggests that the pressure fluctuations in the cove are more
 energetic in the simulations than the experiment.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Hot-wire probes
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The hot-wire probe provides velocity data in flow-critical locations allowing
 comparison of the fidelity of the simulation.
 A plot comparing the velocity magnitude across the nascent shear layer
 is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:hotwire_mean_mag_SL-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The experiment and simulation which includes the wind tunnel installation
 geometries tend to have a better agreement of the average velocity data.
 In both cases, the velocity recovers the free stream velocity of 
\begin_inset Formula $50\,m/s$
\end_inset

 and shows a mean recirculation velocity of 
\begin_inset Formula $8\,m/s$
\end_inset

 on the cove side.
 In comparison, the flow in free stream simulation tends to develop a slightly
 weaker shear layer, with the free stream velocity recovering to 
\begin_inset Formula $43\,m/s$
\end_inset

 and the inner cove recirculation to 
\begin_inset Formula $12\,m/s$
\end_inset

.
 The velocity ratio between the inner and outer flows, 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{U_{i}}{U_{o}}$
\end_inset

, is thus 
\begin_inset Formula $0.16$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $0.27$
\end_inset

 for wind-tunnel and free stream simulation respectively.
 This suggest that a perfect capturing of the shear layer thickness and
 strength requires the presence of the full installation.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tb
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter03/Compare_howire_SL/average_signal_comparison_annotated.png
	lyxscale 15
	width 7.5cm
	height 7.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter03/Compare_howire_SL/RMS_signal_comparison.png
	lyxscale 15
	width 7.5cm
	height 7.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Velocity magnitude data compared between the simulation with and without
 the wind tunnel geometry included in the LBM setup, against the VALIANT
 experimental data for probe file SL placed across the initial shear layer
 near the slat cusp
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:hotwire_mean_mag_SL-1"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Velocity magnitude data compared between the simulation with and without
 the wind tunnel geometry included in the LBM setup, against the VALIANT
 experimental data
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
A few factors can explain this disparity.
 In the free stream simulation, the incoming flow is homogeneous and laminar.
 Hence the boundary layer and the turbulence therein are developed locally
 and spontaneous.
 On the contrary, the incoming flow in the experimental setup and its simulation
 has multiple sources of turbulence upstream of the HLD, i.e.
 the shear layer of the nozzle generates a shedding of vorticity and spanwise
 plates that support the HLD develops a fully turbulent boundary layer upstream
 of the HLD.
 
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The corner flow then allows this vorticity to be convected into the spanwise
 extend.
 From studying the mean flow field, only 
\begin_inset Formula $20\%$
\end_inset

 of the spanwise extend can be seen to the fairly unaffected by the corner
 flow and the rest of the spanwise extend is strongly turbulent.
 These differences between the free stream simulation and the experiment
 hence affect the vorticity thickness of the shear layer and hence the strength
 of shear layer.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The velocity ratio across the shear layer has an important role in determining
 the dynamics of the flow especially the acoustics.
 Among many, the primary effect is that it determines the strength of the
 Rossiter mechanism.
 The shed vorticity from the cusp leads to the generation of the spanwise
 coherent eddies which excite the resonance and hence a reduction of the
 shear strength will weaken the generated vorticity, eventually weakening
 the resonance.
 As will be shown next, this can be one influential factor leading to the
 diminished strength of the first tone in the free stream simulation as
 compared to the experiment.
 
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Another important aspect is that the velocity ratio may affect the strength
 of the centrifugal effect arising from the shear layer curvature and the
 recirculation.
 A detailed study of this aspect is presented in the chapter following this
 one and hence we restrict to a short mention.
 The centrifugal effect which is reasoned to the be driver of the spanwise
 mode formations inside the cove and its associated secondary low frequency
 fluctuations are linked to the difference between the inner cove flow and
 the outer high speed flow.
 The Strouhal number of these fluctuations leads the periodic disruption
 of coherence of the shed vorticity and hence modulates the first Rossiter
 modes via amplitude modulation.
 Hence, to maintain fidelity regarding the secondary flow and the acoustic
 features inside the cove, capturing the velocity ratio is important.
 Nevertheless, this secondary flow features and a possible amplitude modulation
 is a novel finding during this work and hence the numerical framework was
 not initially designed particularly to maintain fidelity regarding centrifugal
 effects and it must be so for future investigations.
 For the current study, the free stream flow is noted to have a difference
 of strength of the shear layer and recirculation, and is related to the
 differences obtained in the predicted acoustic spectra.
 Consequently, we proceed this thesis with this understanding of these possible
 disparities and utilize the compute optimizations obtained from a free
 stream configuration in comparison compared to a full scale simulation,
 for a more extensive parametric investigation of the cove flow phenomena.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
Mean flow fields 
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Mean flow 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Given that the unsteady dynamics has many features worthy of further exploration
, it is important to understand the time-averaged fields in tandem.
 The mean flow field convects the fluid and its vortices to establish the
 macro-flow features like the accelerated flow through the slat gap and
 the recirculation region.
 Within this configuration, the unsteadiness can be thought to be introduced
 by the generation of vorticity due to the presence of slat cusp or the
 shear layer.
 These vortices then develop unsteady dynamics which leads to the aeroacoustics.
 Hence the vortex dynamics itself is intrinsically first determined by the
 established mean flow.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tb
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tb
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/Thesis_Cp_distribution.png
	lyxscale 40

	height 7.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
a) Coefficient of pressure, 
\begin_inset Formula $\ensuremath{C_{p}=\frac{P-P_{0}}{\frac{1}{2}\rho_{\infty}U_{\infty}^{2}}}$
\end_inset

, where, 
\begin_inset Formula $P_{0}=101325\,Pa$
\end_inset

, is the ambient pressure, 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{\infty}=50\,ms^{-1}$
\end_inset

, and 
\begin_inset Formula $\rho_{\infty}=1.225\,kg.m^{-3}$
\end_inset

, are the free stream density and velocity respectively.
 White line indicates the contour 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{p}=0$
\end_inset

.
 b) Time-averaged pressure field in the slat cove.
 Both averaging is done for 5 chord pass times (
\begin_inset Formula $C=0.3m$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{\infty}=50ms^{-1}$
\end_inset

) corresponding to a physical time of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.03s$
\end_inset

.
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

Coefficient of pressure contours in and around the slat cove
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The mean pressure field around the HLD is shown in the Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:meanCp-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 in terms of the Coefficient of Pressure, 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{p}$
\end_inset

.
 The mean pressure, as can be noted, drops significantly near and downstream
 of the slat gap leading to a negative spike.
 This suction peak enhances the lift performance of the wing.
 Looking more closely on to the slat cove, the visualization is made in
 terms of the primitive variables with a tailored color map in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:meanCpCove-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The region of impingement is distinctly identifiable as a region of high
 pressure due to the partial stagnation of the flow and hence the reduction
 in the flow area through the slat gap.
 It is also evident that the low pressure core of the cove due to recirculation
 is not exactly at the center of recirculation itself but shifted nearer
 to the shear layer.
 See Fig.
 4.6.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The mean velocity fields also largely agree with the understanding of the
 cove flow as inspected in the mid-span plane, as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Mean_Cove-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The mean center of the recirculation can be identified in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Magnitude-Mean-Cove-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and the fact that the peak mean velocity magnitude occurs on the suction
 side of the main element which is also the region of reattachment of the
 flow from the slat TE with the main element.
 The peak locations of 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{X}$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{Y}$
\end_inset

 also agree with the geometrical redirection of the flow towards the slat
 gap.
 However, the spanwise mean velocity in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Z-Mean-Cove-2"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 using the same colormap leads to the erroneous inference of its insignificance
 due to the comparatively lower magnitudes.
 An alternative colormap restricted to 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{Z}\in[-5,5]ms^{-1}$
\end_inset

 as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Z-Mean-Cove-1-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 reveals the formation of cells of spanwise velocity inside the cove region.
 The recirculation tend to have alternating signs for the spanwise velocity
 component in the upper and lower regions of the cove.
 The contour of velocity ratio 
\begin_inset Formula $R_{U_{Z}}=\frac{U_{Z}}{\sqrt{U_{X}^{2}+U_{Y}^{2}}}$
\end_inset

 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:CoveMeanVelocityRatio-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, as well as the raw 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{z}$
\end_inset

 for the mean field, shows lower magnitudes than themselves obtained while
 using the unsteady fields as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:VelocityRatio"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Z_1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 This suggest that the cell formation or the spanwise dynamics may possibly
 be a periodic phenomena which are being numerically averaged out in time
 but with a lower frequency than one which cannot be sufficiently averaged
 out within 5 chord pass times.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout

	filename chapter04_figs/ThesisSpanwisePlaneSchematic.png
	lyxscale 30

	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\begin_inset Formula $U_{Z}$
\end_inset

, visualized on a cutplane parallel to the spanwise Z axis inside the cove
 region.

 path in the mid-plane

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Contours of spanwise velocity, 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{Z}$
\end_inset

, showing the cell formation inside the cove region.
 The cut line denoted the approximate position of the shear layer passing
 through the visualization plane 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:ZPlaneCells-1"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Contours of spanwise velocity showing the cell formation inside the cove
 region
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
To generate the spanwise planes, a slice is made parallel to the spanwise
 axis as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:ZPlaneSchematic-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The spanwise velocity is then visualized on this plane with suitable color
 map to identify the local sign of spanwise velocity.
 As can be observed, the `spanwise cells', as we like to refer to the region
 of same velocity direction, appear to be stacked periodically with alternating
 signs.
 The magnitude of mean spanwise velocity is close to 
\begin_inset Formula $5\,ms^{-1}$
\end_inset

, which is upto 
\begin_inset Formula $10%\%
$
\end_inset

 times smaller than of the free stream velocity, 
\begin_inset Formula $U=50\,ms^{-1}$
\end_inset

.
 These cells are also of length scales of the same order of the spanwise
 domain length, which for the current case of standard slat positioning
 generate a total of 
\begin_inset Formula $6$
\end_inset

 cells, or 
\begin_inset Formula $3$
\end_inset

 pairs of alternating signs.
 Their average spanwise wavelength is hence 
\begin_inset Formula $\lambda_{z}=L_{span}/3=0.2/3=0.066\,m$
\end_inset

.
 An exact measurement of the length of center cells are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:ZPlaneCells-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and is approximately 
\begin_inset Formula $0.0696\thinspace m$
\end_inset

 thereby giving a slat chord based non-dimensional wavelength as 
\begin_inset Formula $\Lambda_{z}=\lambda_{z}/C_{s}=1.785$
\end_inset

, where 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{s}=0.039m$
\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The cell formations tend to maintain approximately the same cells size along
 the spanwise direction.
 However, the cells are not only modulated in the spanwise direction but
 are arranged into two layers along the length of the shear layer path.
 The spanwise plane visualization on multiple spanwise planes marked PL1,
 PL2, and PL3, at varying Y coordinates as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Visualisation_planes-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 suggest that the stacking of cells again also form an alternating arrangement
 for the sign of the spanwise velocity, i.e.
 along the shear layer length, the arrangement of the cells are such that
 they oppose in signs between the cells attached to early shear layer and
 later shear layer.
 Visualizing on a fourth plane which lies between PL1 and PL2 as shown in
 Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Visualisation_planes-4-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 also show this arrangement as they transition from the early shear layer
 to the later stage.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The spanwise modulations and their obscurity in slat noise literature lead
 us to many interesting thoughts of which the following three are worthy
 of mention:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
First is that the alternating time-averaged spanwise velocity cells means
 that there exist static nodal planes towards which the flow can converge
 and diverge from.
 Those planes whose both sides have spanwise velocity such that it decreases
 from positive to negative along the spanwise direction and hence have the
 flow directed towards the plane will be referred to as the `converging
 plane'.
 The other type of planes where the spanwise velocity increases from negative
 to positive necessitating the flow to diverge from the plane are the `diverging
 planes'.
 Since these planes act as sources and sinks for the spanwise dynamics,
 they must facilitate the interaction of the spanwise dynamics with the
 2-dimensional dynamics in the streamwise direction.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
Second is that if such nodal planes exist, it is necessary that there must
 exist a mechanism to redistribute the fluid from the converging planes
 and to replenish the diverging planes continuously to establish a steady
 dynamics.
 Here, we have already seen that the recirculating small scale streamwise
 vortices are absorbed into the shear layer in regions near the mid trajectory.
 This suggest that for a converging plane, the mechanism to redistribute
 the fluid is by entrainment of the flow along with the streamwise structures
 into the shear layer, which must also lead to higher concentration (spanwise)
 of streamwise structures at the locations of the converging planes.
 There must also be a lower concentration of the streamwise structures in
 the diverging planes.
 Nevertheless, this may not be a phenomena easily observed in a largely
 turbulent state at 
\begin_inset Formula $Re=10^{6}$
\end_inset

 with constant generation, distortion, and redistribution of vorticity,
 as in the slat cove.
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/VisualisationPlanes3.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 5.5cm
	height 5.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/Spanwise_modulations_velocity.png
	lyxscale 50
	width 9cm
	height 9cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Visualization planes used to show the spanwise modulation at different locations
 of the shear layer 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Visualisation_planes-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/ThesisSpanCellsBetweenPL1andPL2.png
	lyxscale 50
	width 15cm
	height 15cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Spanwise modulation on a visualization plane in between PL1 and PL2 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Visualisation_planes-4-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
The driving factor for the spanwise modulations should be the result of
 a dynamic instability either due to the shear layer geometry or due to
 the recirculating flow.
 Similar spanwise modulations are documented for flow over a backward facing
 step by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Their work demonstrated the existence of large scale spanwise modulations
 in the shear layer due to the presence of a backward facing step, and argues
 that the spanwise modulations are the result of an absolute convective
 instability owing to the closed loop streamline in the recirculation bubble
 leading to generation of steady spanwise modes.
 The eigen functions identified in their work using the linear stability
 analysis of a simplified flow configuration predicts the spanwise wavelength
 with same order as that of the cavity depth.
 This is consistent with the observation that the spanwise cells in the
 slat cove have a wavelength with same order as the slat chord.
 On comparing the rectangular flow cavity with the slat cove, the cavity
 depth is analogous to the diameter of the recirculating cove flow, and
 this diameter is approximately the slat chord.
 Their study also suggest a critical Reynolds number, although at a low
 range of 
\begin_inset Formula $Re_{c}=748$
\end_inset

, from which the spanwise modulations are dominant and this critical Reynolds
 number is also argued to be decreased when a lateral side wall is present.
 In the case of simulations with spanwise periodic conditions mimicking
 an infinite spanwise domain, the critical Reynolds number is also increased.
 The case of slat cove dynamics is at a Reynolds number of 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{6}$
\end_inset

 based on the mean flow and if considering the flow inside the cove region,
 taking the mean velocity to be 
\begin_inset Formula $20\,m/s$
\end_inset

, and the characteristic length scale to be the slat chord, 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{s}=0.039\,m$
\end_inset

, corresponding Reynolds number is at 
\begin_inset Formula $54000$
\end_inset

.
 This regime is still two orders of magnitude higher than that required
 to trigger the convective instability
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The presence of spanwise walls are also of much importance for the slat
 cove flow as well, since, in our simulations we employ periodic conditions,
 and in experimental studies the lateral side walls are necessary to support
 the HLD mockup in the wind tunnel.
 Hence, drawing parallels between the fact that the flow over a backward
 facing step is much similar to the cove flow, particularly due to the fact
 that both cases have one side bounded by a shear layer and both have a
 recirculation bubble in which the spanwise modes tend to dominate, we suspect
 the same mechanism is also in action in the slat cove dynamics.
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter06_figs/Barkley_Eigen.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 12cm
	height 12cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Image of the eigen mode demonstrating the spanwise instability mode for
 flow over a backward facing step from the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The original caption read: 
\begin_inset Quotes eld
\end_inset

Three-dimensional flow structure of the critical eigenmode at 
\begin_inset Formula $Re=750$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $\beta=0.9$
\end_inset

.
 Contours indicate the strength of the streamwise velocity component and
 vectors show the 
\begin_inset Formula $(v,w)$
\end_inset

 flow pattern in each cross-sectional plane: 
\begin_inset Formula $x=1.2,6.2\text{ and }12.2$
\end_inset

.
\begin_inset Quotes erd
\end_inset


\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:barkleyspanmodes-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
Similarly, 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Neary1987"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 studied open rectangular cavity flows and the same was studied more analyticall
y using Linear Stability arguments by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 For the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Neary1987"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, three regimes of flow for an open rectangular cavity based on the Reynold's
 number was identified.
 In the first, there is a strong interaction of the shear layer with the
 recirculating vortex inside the cavity.
 In a second regime of higher Reynolds number, the interaction leads to
 intermittent behavior leading to a bursting phenomena where the recirculating
 vortex tends to oscillate in size leading to it bursting through the shear
 layer to release vorticity.
 While doing so, the flow is said to be strongly turbulent.
 In the third regime typically at 
\begin_inset Formula $Re=33500$
\end_inset

, (for our low speed cove recirculation, 
\begin_inset Formula $Re=54000$
\end_inset

), the bursting oscillations and associated pressure oscillations become
 more frequent but irregular.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
In the later work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, the rectangular cavities were further analyzed using three-dimensional
 global instability analysis to show that the spanwise instability wavelength
 scales are proportional to the cavity depth.
 The resulting spanwise modulated flow also develop oscillations that can
 induce a low frequency pulsation of the recirculating vortex.
 This frequency was deduced to have one order of magnitude lower than the
 Rossiter oscillations.
 The dependence of the growth rate of the spanwise modes with Reynolds number
 was also identified along with a critical value that would trigger the
 formation of the spanwise modes.
 However, the most interesting argument made by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 was that the spanwise instability was a result of the curvature of the
 flow, i.e.
 the curved streamline of the recirculating vortices in the cavity would
 lead to a centrifugal instability that is different from the Rossiter oscillati
ons and the Görtler type instability that occurs on curved boundary walls.
 This argument finds its strength from the fact that the location of the
 strongest spanwise modulation is in the region of strong curvature of the
 recirculation bubble on the downstream corner of the cavity.
 The spanwise modulated recirculation vortex would develop also a low frequency
 oscillation, and this additional oscillations can interfere with the Rossiter
 modes to modulate both its frequency and peak amplitudes.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
That being noted on the spanwise mode formations, the same argument, along
 with the fact that for both the shear layer on a backward facing step and
 the recirculation streamline in open cavity flows have, in common, a curved
 streamline with one side bounded by a shear layer, we choose to investigate
 the case of slat cove dynamics in terms of its peculiarities arising from
 curved streamline path of its shear layer.
 In line with this hypothesis, the behavior of a curved shear layer was
 also studied by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 His work studied the linear inviscid hydrodynamic stability of a slightly
 curved free shear layer.
 The study compared the cases of a stably curved and unstably curved shear
 layer identifying sensitivity of the flow to the addition of curvature
 to an already present shear layer.
 The formation of Görtler vortices was identified as a possible reason for
 the generation of streamwise oriented counter rotating vortex pairs while
 the unstably curved regime is present.
 The work also provides a non-dimensional parameter, the curvature Richardson
 number, to quantify the effect of an accelerated generation of streamwise
 vortices and will be used for comparison in our study as well.
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/Spanwisemodes_Bres.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 14cm
	height 14cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The spanwise modes in a rectangular cavity with periodic spanwise conditions
 from the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The original caption read: 
\begin_inset Quotes eld
\end_inset

Visualization of the three-dimensional flow for run 2M0325-3D at six different
 times (a–f ) corresponding to approximately one-sixth phase intervals of
 a half-period of the three-dimensional instability.
 The iso-surfaces represent the spanwise velocity levels 
\begin_inset Formula $w/U=−0.01$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $w/U=0.01$
\end_inset

.
 The whole spanwise extent of the cavity is shown and the wavelength 
\begin_inset Formula $λ/D=1$
\end_inset

 of the instability can clearly be observed.
 The velocity vectors in the streamwise cross-section at 
\begin_inset Formula $z=0$
\end_inset

 are shown inside the cavity and once in the free-stream for comparison.
\begin_inset Quotes erd
\end_inset

 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:spanwisemodesbres-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
From the above-mentioned array of ideas, we tend to theorize that the slat
 cove dynamics at the current Reynolds number has the following features
 and explanations:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The slat shear layer formed due to the difference of velocity between the
 free-stream and the recirculation vortex leads to the canonical Kelvin-Helmholt
z (K-H) instability as well identified in the literature
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Terracol2016,Souza2019"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The saturation of K-H instability leads to the generation of 2-dimensional
 spanwise coherent structures being shed periodically from the cusp.
 If these vortices were to be convected in a straight line path, their behavior
 would only have the peculiarities of a vortex convected through an accelerated
 flow.
 However, since the established mean flow is such that the streamlines are
 curved along with the shear layer to facilitate flow through the slat gap,
 the vortices also follow a curved trajectory.
 This curvature of the streamline necessarily have a mean diameter of curvature
 similar in magnitude to the slat chord length.
 The spanwise coherent vortices which undergo such strong curvature experience
 an additional centrifugal force.
 Here, the pressure distribution inside the slat cove is lower than the
 pressure outside the cove region due to the fact that the region outside
 the slat cove is at the pressure side of the main element and is affected
 by presence of stagnation point on the main-element.
 Hence, the normal pressure gradient along the shear layer is positive along
 a radius of curvature of the shear layer with center of rotation inside
 the cove.
 This radial pressure gradient opposes the centrifugal force thereby requiring
 a balancing of these forces to enable a stable flow.
 This is the classical requirement for a dynamic instability to occur where
 two opposing forces which are supposed to be balanced are, in reality,
 not exactly and dynamically balanced, thereby leading to large growth rate
 for certain class of perturbations.
 The curved shear layer is hence susceptible to the curvature instability
 leading to the typical steady spanwise modes primarily attached to the
 shear layer as described by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Considering the mean velocity distribution as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Magnitude-Mean-Cove-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, it can be noticed that for the early part of the shear layer, the lower
 velocity flow is on the concave side of the shear layer curvature.
 This is a stable curvature since according to Rayleigh criteria the equilibrium
 is stable against curvature instability if the angular momentum decreases
 radially outward
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Rayleigh1917"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 In early shear layer, the streamline velocity is increasing radially outward
 from the cove center and hence the curvature instability is stabilized.
 Furthermore, as inferred by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, the initial K-H instability may also be stabilized partially leading to
 a reduced growth rate of the streamwise perturbations suggesting a delayed
 spanwise vortex generation due to the effect of curvature.
 Hence, in this regime, the major noticeable dynamics are a delayed generation
 of K-H vortices as suggested by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 together with the large spanwise modulations arising from the convective
 instability of the recirculation from the suggestion of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
As the flow progresses downstream, the shear layer weakens due to its spreading
 and growth of spanwise vortices.
 Simultaneously, the radius of curvature also decreases to eventually reverse
 its sign.
 Once the sign of curvature reverses and re-strengthen near the vicinity
 of the slat trailing edge region, i.e., the streamlines curve such that the
 low pressure area of the suction peak on the main element is again on the
 concave side of the streamlines near the slat gap, and the high pressure
 region generated due to the impingement of the shear layer on the slat
 trailing edge is on its convex side.
 This reversed configuration of pressure gradient is again opposing the
 centrifugal acceleration facilitating curvature instability again.
 However, unlike the early shear layer, the velocity field can be noticed
 to have the high velocity stream on the concave side of the curvature.
 This according to 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 is the unstably curved configuration and satisfy the Rayleigh criterion
 to have a radially decreasing angular momentum.
 Hence the shear layer now develops a strong centrifugal instability leading
 to the generation of streamwise oriented counter rotating vortex pairs.
 This generation of small scale structures are strongly accelerated by the
 presence of the ingested vortices from the recirculation region.
 It must be clearly noted that the regime of flow near the slat trailing
 edge is the asymptotic case for the linear stability analyzed by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 whose conclusions are only directly valid for a curved free shear layer
 with small curvatures.
 The effective range of curvature Richardson numbers for their analysis
 is of the order of 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{-3}$
\end_inset

 where for the slat shear layer, these are on average two orders of magnitude
 higher as we will show in the upcoming session.
 Hence, for the later part of the shear layer near the impingement location
 and flow through the slat gap, the major phenomena is the curvature instability
 driven by a considerably lower radius of curvature with a mean velocity
 distribution enabling a fully unstable configuration.
 The only noticeable effect is hence the generation of streamwise oriented
 counter rotating vortex pairs which assimilate into larger streamwise vortices
 on the slat trailing edge and are elongated and ejected through the slat
 gap.
 The terminology used in the recent literature
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Wang2019,Wang2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 that these are `Görtler like' transition is hence logically valid, although
 there is no curved boundary layer as in the case of the canonical Görtler
 transition that leads to small scale streamwise oriented structures.
 Note that since this is a purely centrifugal instability, meaning that
 this generation of streamwise structures would happen even if there was
 no supply of spanwise coherent vortices in the impinging shear layer, as
 reported by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Wang2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Their work demonstrates that at low enough Reynolds numbers, the periodic
 vortex shedding from the slat cusp is suppressed, possibly due to the combined
 effect of the stabilization of K-H instability due to curvature and the
 low Reynolds number, and the only noticeable turbulence generation is that
 of the streamwise vortices near the trailing edge.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Finally, inside the recirculation, the flow developing spanwise modulation
 was previously unidentified in the literature although it was noticed early
 that the vorticity ejected from the slat gap had spanwise modulations.
 The flow in the cove region was largely analyzed under the assumption that
 it is spanwise homogeneous, and at this point of understanding the cove
 dynamics, it is striking why the prediction of cove flow and related acoustics
 remained elusive from a perfectly predictive modelling 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Souza2022"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 This we suggest is due to the fact that the three dimensionality of the
 flow due to the spanwise modulation would induce additional oscillations,
 suggestively with frequency one order of magnitude lower than the first
 Rossiter tone, which can modulate the tonal frequencies and the amplitude
 of the peaks as suggested by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 This tone, or more precisely a broadband hump in the low frequency was
 clearly identified in the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Jawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, who characterized the same as having a different source mechanism compared
 to other tones.
 The broadening of a purely tonal wave while propagating though a strongly
 turbulent region like that of the slat cove and flow around the airfoil
 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Clair2018"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, together with the fact that the intermittent bursting phenomena associated
 with oscillation of the recirculation vortex can both significantly broaden
 the frequency bandwidth of fluctuations effected by this mechanism on a
 far-field microphone.
 This broadband hump is also in the low frequency range which is dominated
 by the measurement noise from the experimental setup and noise from the
 shear layer of the open jet wind tunnel adding to their elusiveness.
 Thus when tonal character of slat noise was rightly identified as those
 related to the Rossiter mechanism by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, their modulation mechanism was overlooked due to the assumption of the
 spanwise homogeneity and thereby wrongly advising the choice of methodology
 for both experimentation and numerical studies so far.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Before a further analysis, of this newly observed spanwise feature, let
 us complete the validation of the simulations using the predicted and experimen
tal noise signatures.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Now, before moving on to further discussion of the unsteady data related
 to the acoustics, we take a light detour to showcase a few additional simulatio
ns to establish that the formation of spanwise modes are not purely an artifact
 of the numerical simulation.
 This is evident from the fact that the same phenomena is observed in both
 flow over a backward facing step
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 and open cavity flows
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 and also the experimental studies of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Wang2019,Wang2021,Wang2023"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Nevertheless, our simulations serve to shed more light on the same in the
 particular context of slat cove dynamics.
 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Ffowcs Williams-Hawkings Computation
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "subsec:fwh_computation-1"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
FWH Computation
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The placement of FWH surfaces requires careful consideration for reasons
 detailed in the previous chapter.
 The primary challenge is the positioning the surface to allow vortical
 structures to exit the computational region without crossing it.
 However, utilizing an open surface inherently reduces predicted pressure
 levels, as acoustic wave fronts from internal sources interact with the
 entire surface area, albeit with varying timing and amplitudes.
 This challenge is mitigated by spherical spreading, where wave amplitudes
 decay with increasing distance from the source.
 Consequently, surface regions far from the source contribute less significantly
 to the far-field observer measurements.
 This physical behavior allows positioning of the open part of the surface
 sufficiently downstream from the main element while maintaining acceptable
 accuracy 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Giret2012,jacob2005,Casalino2003a"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tbh
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/Shared_Newton/Pics for Marc/FWH_FullSurface_NoTruncation/FWH_truncsurf_B258U258.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 5cm
	height 5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Full Surface.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/Shared_Newton/Pics for Marc/FWH_FullSurface_Truncated_Near_TE/FWH_truncsurf_B246U246.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 5cm
	height 5cm
	keepAspectRatio
	BoundingBox 0bp 0bp 611bp 372bp

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure

sideways false

\begin_layout Plain Layout

	lyxscale 20

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Bottom only surface.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Oval FWH surfaces tested.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
To optimize surface placement and evaluate far-field sound contributions,
 we conducted multiple test cases.
 Our investigation began with an oval surface positioned close to the airfoil,
 which was progressively modified into a C-shape and enlarged to contain
 the ejected cove vorticity within the airfoil's suction side, thereby preventin
g spurious effects.
 While results from the oval surface testing are presented in Appendix A,
 we focus here on the optimal C-shaped surface configuration here.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
C-shaped surfaces, characterized by one rounded side and one open side,
 are widely adopted in airfoil FWH computations 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Giret2012,Wu2017"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Their primary utility is in the open ended shape which allows the convected
 vortices to exit through the open side and since the open side can be kept
 sufficiently far, the radiation of the downstream eddies is expected to
 have a negligible effect onto the sound field regions that are upstream
 of the surface open end.
 In our case they also allow to avoid large size low vorticity structures
 on the suction side by careful placement.
 They also provide sufficient space to be confidently deployed to parametric
 case simulations such that when the slat positioning is varied, the increase
 or decrease of ejected flow will not necessarily cross the upper part of
 the surface, thereby enabling easier parameterisation.
 The C-surface placement plotted against the dilatation field around the
 airfoil is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:cshapedfwhsurface-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and the numerical microphones are placed at coordinates as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:fwhobservers-1-1"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter03_figs/FWHSurface_CShape_Dilatation.png
	lyxscale 25
	width 15cm
	height 15cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout

s.

\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout

 for the free stream configuration 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard

\color red
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The downstream part is kept open for the sound calculation although the
 data is recorded during the simulation on a vertical surface connecting
 the edge points.
 This is to make the data available in the dataset in the event of a further
 development of a correction for the FWH formulation.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\color red
The usage of this surface was first tested in the simulation akin to the
 Oval surface.
 Nevertheless, the data from the same simulations for the C-surfaces were
 lost due to operational faults.
 
\color inherit
Hence we present here the data from a continuous simulation of the second
 kind, which uses all the same simulation parameters with only addition
 that the simulations are carried out in a single stretch instead of simulations
 which were according to sequential time partitioning scheme discussed in
 Section 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "subsec:Sequential-Time-Partitioning"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\color inherit
The sound signals obtained for selected probes are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Sound-pressure-data_FWH_Cshape-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 All microphones show a steady mean-pressure that corresponds to the local
 flow pressure as the microphones places in the non-turbulent region.
 The mean pressure is however not same across the probes and a constant
 pressure at the ambient is subtracted from the total pressure for the FWH
 calculation.
 The residual value of pressure reflects as the non-zero mean value of the
 microphone recording, but does not affect the calculations of farfield
 sound since only the time derivative of pressure is used in the FWH formulation
 and not the absolute values.Accordingly, to avoid the DC component in the
 spectra computed using Welsh's method, a constant local mean subtraction
 is also enabled for each of the averaging windows.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The resulting spectra for corresponding probes are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Sound-pressure-spectra_FWH_Cshape-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 where they are compared with the spectra from the VALIANT experiment and
 another simulation of same kind but addition that it includes the wind
 tunnel installation.
 The latter as mentioned additionally includes lateral side plates and the
 converging duct which issues a jet, increasing the fidelity of the simulation
 towards the experiment.
 The comparison of results show a good performance of the numerical framework
 in capturing the far-field tones and the broadband characteristic slat
 noise.
 For an observer at 
\begin_inset Formula $-90^{o}$
\end_inset

 at the suction side of the airfoil, the prediction obtains the peak at
 
\begin_inset Formula $1771\,Hz$
\end_inset

, and the higher harmonics of the fundamental which is at 
\begin_inset Formula $885\,Hz$
\end_inset

 corresponding to the first Rossiter tone for this case according to 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 For the fundamental tone at 
\begin_inset Formula $885\,Hz$
\end_inset

, the experimental spectrum also misses the first tone primarily due to
 the fact that at frequencies of 
\begin_inset Formula $800\,Hz$
\end_inset

 and below, the installation noise dominates the acoustic field in the experimen
tal setup.
 In addition, the fundamental tone has a lower SPL component that hardly
 peaks out of the main spectrum as a small hump.
 This suggests that the source radiation might be strongly distorted by
 the local large eddies resulting in a flattening and broadening of the
 associated peak
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Clair2018"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Nevertheless, the hump is visible at the upstream microphone on the pressure
 side, corresponding to Probe 
\begin_inset Formula $9$
\end_inset

 at observer angle 
\begin_inset Formula $135^{o}$
\end_inset

 as seen in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Probe-9-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 Furthermore, we demonstrate in a subsequent chapter using a slightly adjusted
 position of the slat that this first peak can in fact be captured with
 stronger power levels in the same simulation setup and installation effects.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
For the first main tone at 
\begin_inset Formula $1771\,Hz$
\end_inset

, which is the second Rossiter tone, the simulation faithfully reproduces
 the experimental frequency.
 However, the measured sound level is considerably higher at this frequency,
 which is not captured by the free stream simulation.
 In comparison, for the simulation that includes the installation geometries,
 especially the lateral side plates, the prediction leads to a better matching
 of the sound level.
 This suggests that the amplification of this tone can be due to the effect
 of the lateral side plates.
 Indeed, a spanwise resonance can be reasonably suspected to be present
 in the experiment.
 The experiment was designed with a span-to-chord ratio of 1, leading to
 separation between the plates to be 
\begin_inset Formula $0.3\,m$
\end_inset

.
 The fundamental tone for resonance between the plates is thus 
\begin_inset Formula $f_{S0}=572\,Hz$
\end_inset

 whose second harmonic is at 
\begin_inset Formula $1716\,Hz$
\end_inset

.
 This is close to the 
\begin_inset Formula $1771\,Hz$
\end_inset

, i.e.
 the first harmonic of the cavity resonance.
 Furthermore, while comparing with the simulation that includes the spanwise
 lateral plates, both wall pressure recording and the farfield spectra show
 that the first tone obtained in the installed case is amplified with respect
 to the free stream configuration and hence reaches better agreement with
 the experiment.
 This supports the assumption that the disparity of the first tone is not
 an inaccuracy due to the simulation methodology but has a physical background.
 
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Interestingly, in the further chapters of this thesis, this disparity is
 also explained further as due to the stronger development of the centrifugal
 effect of the cove recirculation in the case of a cleaner spanwise flow
 in the free-stream simulation.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
For higher frequencies, the spectra downstream of the airfoil on pressure
 side, i.e.
 Probe 
\begin_inset Formula $0$
\end_inset

, shows a better agreement.
 Microphones facing the suction side register higher levels for the frequencies
 above 
\begin_inset Formula $10\,kHz$
\end_inset

 which are possibly due to sources on the suction side of the HLD.
 Both turbulence ejection from the slat and its impingement on to the suction
 side of the airfoil leads to generation of high frequency noise.
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
However, in the experiment, it is possible that the high frequency noise
 is attenuated by the presence of the jet shear layer and hence lower sound
 levels for the higher frequencies at farfield observer.
\end_layout

\end_inset

 The obtained agreement between the simulation in free flow condition and
 wind tunnel experiment is hence reasonable.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Additionally, as mentioned, the spanwise extent of airfoil is not the same
 in both experiment and simulation.
 For the experiment, the distance between lateral side plates is kept as
 1 chord length, i.e.
 
\begin_inset Formula $C=0.3\,m$
\end_inset

.
 On the other hand the simulation uses a chord length of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.66C=0.2\,m$
\end_inset

.
 Theoretically, the experiment is designed to isolate a region between the
 plates which is unaffected by the boundary layer and the corner flow formed
 at the junction of side plates and the airfoil.
 But an exact estimation of what length along the span is effectively free
 from this disturbance and hence acoustically effective is not possible
 from the available data.
 Hence a correction of the sound level corresponding to the spanwise length
 difference can not be considered.
 
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Nevertheless, since the exact spanwise length that is acoustically active
 in the experiment is ambiguous, such a calculation is not trivial.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
Unsteady Data and Cove Dynamics 
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Cove Dynamics 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
To study unsteady dynamics of the cove for the noise-validated standard
 geometry case, we used the Q-criterion visualization 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Hunt1988"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 to first isolate the vortices.
 The Q-criterion is defined as 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{align*}
Q & =\frac{1}{2}\left((\nabla\cdot\mathbf{u})^{2}+|\mathbf{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}|_{2}^{2}-|\mathbf{S}|_{2}^{2}\right)
\end{align*}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where, 
\begin_inset Formula $\mathbf{u}$
\end_inset

 is the instantaneous velocity vector, 
\begin_inset Formula $\mathbf{S}$
\end_inset

 is the strain rate tensor or symmetric part of the velocity gradient 
\begin_inset Formula $\nabla\mathbf{u}$
\end_inset

, 
\begin_inset Formula $\boldsymbol{\Omega}$
\end_inset

 is the vorticity tensor or the anti-symmetric part of 
\begin_inset Formula $\nabla\mathbf{u}$
\end_inset

, and 
\begin_inset Formula $|.|_{2}$
\end_inset

 is the Frobenius norm.
 The Q-criterion serves as a scalar which represents relative magnitude
 of the vorticity component as opposed to the strain rate.
 In the volume occupied by a vortex, the vortex core has a strong vorticity
 component with minimal strain (hence a larger Q-value) and vice-versa on
 the exterior.
 Hence, by choosing a suitable Q-criteria and obtaining the isocontours
 of the same, vortex structures can be identified given the 3D unsteady
 velocity field.
 To use the same, we use the internal calculator of the ProLB solver to
 record the Q-values along with the unsteady velocity field and extract
 the isocontours using the visualization software ParaView.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/Qcriterion_NotColored1.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 14cm
	height 14cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Iso-surfaces of Q-Criterion, 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{Q}{M}=10^{9}$
\end_inset

 where, 
\begin_inset Formula $M=0.14$
\end_inset

, is the flow Mach number.
 The region of sparsity for the small scale recirculating structure is demarcate
d with the yellow line 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:IsoQcrit"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tb
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter10/SGP079/ThesisVorticesSpan.png
	lyxscale 20

	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset

	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter10/SGP079/ThesisVorticesSpan_SideView.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 7.8cm
	height 7.8cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset

 
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Vortices visualized by setting transparency of iso-surfaces using the spanwise
 vorticity component 
\begin_inset Formula $\Omega_{z}$
\end_inset

, isolating the streamwise coherent structures shed from the slat cusp.
 The streamwise vortices in the inner circulation region are now set to
 low visibility due to their low spanwise vorticity.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:SpanwiseRollers"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
