\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter10/SGP079/ThesisVorticesSpanStream.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 8.2cm
	height 8.2cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset

 
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter10/SGP079/ThesisVorticesSpanStream_SideView.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 7.8cm
	height 7.8cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset

 
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Vortices visualized by using both the spanwise vorticity component 
\begin_inset Formula $\Omega_{z}$
\end_inset

, and the residual in-plane component,
\begin_inset Formula $\sqrt{\Omega_{X}^{2}+\Omega_{Y}^{2}}$
\end_inset

, on separate colourmaps to highlight the streamwise structures inside the
 recirculation region against spanwise coherent structures.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:SpanwiseRollers-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Iso-surfaces of Q-Criterion, 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{Q}{M}=[10^{9},1.4\times10^{8}]$
\end_inset

, where 
\begin_inset Formula $M=0.14$
\end_inset

 is the flow Mach number 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:CoveVortices"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tb
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/ThesisTrailingEdgeVorticesAnnotated.png
	lyxscale 40
	width 15.5cm
	height 15.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Streamwise vortices ejected from the slat gap.
 The slat wall is set to be partially transparent to inspect the dynamics
 of the impinging vortices.
 Q-criterion is set to 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{Q}{M}=[10^{9},1.4\times10^{8}]$
\end_inset

, where 
\begin_inset Formula $M=0.14$
\end_inset

 is the flow Mach number.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:IsoQcrit-1"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Streamwise vortices ejected from the slat gap 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The selection of Q-criterion depends on the application and a good visualization
 is obtained by iterative refinement.
 For our application, the Q-value of 
\begin_inset Formula $1.4\times10^{8}$
\end_inset

 was found to isolate the vortices in the flow as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:IsoQcrit"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 As an additional aid in visualization, we also use one additional Q-value
 which is 
\begin_inset Formula $70%\ensuremath{\%}
$
\end_inset

 higher.
 This allow to visualize the exterior of the spanwise rollers in addition
 to their inner vortex core.
 The coloring of the isosurface aid in identification of dynamics associated
 with the vortex.
 Here we color the same using the vorticity value which aids in identifying
 the core from the exterior surface.
 The spanwise vorticity behavior can then be isolated by setting the transparenc
y settings in order to selectively highlight the structure based on the
 vorticity component on the iso-contours.
 By using the spanwise vorticity as the coloring criteria and for transparency,
 the spanwise rollers shed from the slat cusp can be clearly identified
 as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:SpanwiseRollers"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 As expected, the spanrollers can be noted to have a strong spanwise coherent
 vorticity in the the vicinity of the slat cusp with progressive dispersion
 until the mid shear layer where the sense of curvature of the shear layer
 reverses.
 By sense of curvature we refer to the fact that the low speed recirculation
 region is on the concave side of the mean shear layer.
 Once the sign of curvature changes, i.e.
 the low speed flow is on the convex side of the curvature, the spanwise
 vortices can be noticed to disintegrate strongly by generation of smaller
 streamwise vortices primarily formed from the periphery of the spanwise
 structures, leading to the ejection of majorly streamwise vortices through
 the slat gap as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:SpanwiseRollers-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 It must be mentioned that in addition to the streamwise vortices, this
 case also has comparatively similar, although less amount of residual spanwise
 vorticity that passes through the slat gap.
 This residual spanwise vorticity is a necessary component for the generation
 of the aeroacoustic phenomena since the streamwise vortices are far less
 efficient than spanwise coherent vortices to generate acoustic waves due
 to trailing edge scattering
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Roger2005"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\align block
The unsteady visualizations of Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:CoveVortices"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, made available as the supplementary document to this thesis, reveal that
 the process of generation of the streamwise vortices in the current case
 is particularly near and after the region where the curvature of the mean
 shear layer switches signs.
 This fact however does not allow us to clearly state that the transition
 of vorticity is definitively due to the effect of curvature.
 This is due to the fact that the region near the slat gap is a region of
 both streamwise acceleration and deceleration of the mean flow.
 The acceleration is due to the nozzle like shape of the region leading
 to the slat gap while the deceleration is caused by the stagnation region
 due to the impingement.
 The area of impingement region generates a zone of stagnation for the mean
 flow which further reduces the area available for the flow to exit, aggravating
 the nozzle effect of the geometry further.
 This complex interaction of the dynamic forces of the fluid hence makes
 it difficult to state that the vorticity transition is definitively driven
 by the curvature effect alone.
 Nevertheless, it is clear that the major source of the streamwise vortices
 is by the transition from the spanwise coherent structures along the later
 stages of the curved shear layer.
 Additionally, the curved wall of the inner slat is susceptible to the well-know
n Görtler instability of concavely curved boundary layers 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Saric1994,Floryan1991"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, and are potentially contributing to the generation of streamwise structures
 in the recirculation particularly close to the slat cusp whose inner wall
 has a strong curvature.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Another notable feature of the unsteady flow is the uneven distribution
 of the recirculation vortices inside the cove region as seen in both Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:IsoQcrit"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:SpanwiseRollers-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The streamwise vortices which are more populous tend to be sparse in the
 region close to the mid trajectory of shear layer and at the center of
 recirculation whereas the density is higher along the curved inner wall
 of the slat.
 The streamwise vortices that reach the impingement location are inevitability
 stretched along the wall due to the streamwise accelerated ejection and
 the stretched vortices disintegrate into smaller vortices as they enter
 the recirculation.
 These smaller vortices then move along the wall and experience the centrifugal
 force due to the curved streamline of the recirculation.
 The centrifugal force hence explains the tendency of the vortices to stay
 in the outer periphery of the cove recirculation causing sparsity near
 the centre of recirculation.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The recirculating streamwise structures also reach the slat cusp by moving
 along the inner slat wall.
 These structures can be noted to interfere with the shear layer in the
 region near the slat cusp and also in the early shear layer.
 The structures then interfere with the spanwise vortices accelerating the
 generation of more streamwise vortices in the process.
 This also aggravates the fact that the streamwise vortices are sparser
 in the mid-region of the slat shear layer since a major portion of the
 recirculated streamwise vortices are entrained into the shear layer.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The vortex stretching happening at the trailing edge is also worthy of further
 mention.
 The impinging vortices in the shear layer is a mix of streamwise and spanwise
 vortices with streamwise vortices in larger proportion.
 The latter majorly wind around and form ladder structures together with
 the spanwise structures.
 Near the wall at impingement, the streamwise vortices become stronger and
 assimilate to larger structures, and, as they impinge, the streamwise structure
s are elongated in both the forward and backward directions, towards the
 ejected and recirculated directions respectively.
 Here the stretching is stronger in the downstream direction through the
 slat gap.
 The streamwise vortices in the slat wall are also continuously replenished
 by incoming vortices and as they interact with the wall as they tend to
 roll along wall in the spanwise direction.
 This leads to counter rotating vortices coalescing to form large counter-rotati
ng vortex pairs.
 These counter rotating vortex pairs can be visualized by using a diverging
 colourmap that highlights the streamwise vorticity in opposing directions
 as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:streamwisevorticesredblue"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The ejected counter rotating vortices and residual smaller streamwise vortices
 are then flushed on to the suction side of the main element.
 The counter rotating pairs often undergo further instability to form helical
 structures before impinging with the suction side wall on main element
 and can noticed in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:streamwisevorticesredblue"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The mean streamlines ejected from the trailing edge location need not necessaril
y directly graze the main element.
 However, in the unsteady dynamics, the ejected vortices tend to have an
 unsteady oscillation which redirects the ejected vortices to have a flapping
 motion towards and away from the main element suction wall.
 This low frequency oscillation also leads to oscillation of the reattachment
 point of the ejected streamwise vortices on the main element.
 
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tb
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/TEVorticesRedBlue.png
	lyxscale 40
	width 15.5cm
	height 15.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Streamwise counter rotating vortex pairs at the slat gap visualized using
 a diverging colourmap based on the streamwise vorticity 
\begin_inset Formula $\Omega_{X}$
\end_inset

.
 The Q-criterion is set to 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{Q}{M^{2}}=[10^{9},7\times10^{9}]$
\end_inset

, where, 
\begin_inset Formula $M=0.14$
\end_inset

 is the flow Mach number.
 The assimilation of streamwise vorticity below the slat trailing edge then
 leads to rolling of the vortices along the wall and pairing up of counter
 rotating vortices.
 These are then stretched and ejected on to the suction side of the main
 element often leading to helical structures.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:streamwisevorticesredblue"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Streamwise counter rotating vortex pairs at the slat gap visualized using
 a diverging colourmap based on the streamwise vorticity
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/UnsteadyPressure.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 15cm
	height 15cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The unsteady aerodynamic pressure field (
\begin_inset Formula $\pm200\,Pa$
\end_inset

) in the slat cove identifying the trajectory of the spanwise coherent structure
 along the curved shear layer 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:The-unsteady-pressure"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The unsteady aerodynamic pressure field in the slat cove identifying the
 trajectory of the spanwise coherent structure along the curved shear layer
 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Additionally, the local unsteady component of pressure, 
\begin_inset Formula $P'=P-P_{0}$
\end_inset

, is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:The-unsteady-pressure"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.As expected, it is seen to have quasi-periodic fluctuations along the shear
 layer trajectory representing the convection of vortices shed periodically
 from the cusp.
 Accompanied by their impingement on the wall near TE, the oscillating pressure
 field also exerts its influence over to the leading edge of the main element.
 Hence the hydrodynamic pressure in the slat gap has periodic fluctuations
 synchronized with the pressure fluctuations due to the convected vortices.
 From the 2D visualization at mid-span, the pressure inside the cove region
 also appears to have an oscillating component of considerably lower frequency
 than other stronger fluctuations of smaller length scales.
 From such a distribution of the periodic pressure fluctuation, it is hence
 expected that the shear layer modes would be particularly dominant in a
 model order reduction techniques such as Proper Orthogonal Decomposition
 (POD) or Spectral Proper Orthogonal Decomposition (SPOD).
 However, since these fluctuations are purely hydrodynamic, an inference
 of the acoustic interactions in the slat cove would still be difficult
 unless the hydrodynamic and acoustics modes are explicitly segregated.
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/ThesisUnsteadyVelocityMagnitude.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 7.5cm
	height 7.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Velocity Magnitude 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Velocity-Magnitude"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset

 
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/ThesisUnsteadyVelocityX.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 7.5cm
	height 7.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Velocity X
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Velocity-X"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/ThesisUnsteadyVelocityY.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 7.5cm
	height 7.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Velocity Y
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Velocity-Y"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset

 
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/ThesisUnsteadyVelocityZ.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 7.5cm
	height 7.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Velocity Z
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Velocity-Z"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The unsteady pressure field in the slat cove identifying the trajectory
 of the spanwise coherent structure along the curved shear layer.
 Nevertheless, the perturbations of 
\begin_inset Formula $\pm200\thinspace Pa$
\end_inset

 are the hydrodynamic components, and are not to be inferred as representative
 of the acoustic modes.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:The-unsteady-velocity"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard

\color black
The local unsteady component of pressure, 
\color inherit

\begin_inset Formula $P'=P-P_{0}$
\end_inset


\color black
, is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:The-unsteady-pressure"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 As expected, 
\begin_inset Formula $P'$
\end_inset

 exhibits quasi-periodic fluctuations along the shear layer trajectory,
 reflecting the convection of vortices periodically shed from the cusp.
 These vortices impinge on the wall near the trailing edge, thus generating
 an oscillating pressure field that extends its influence to the leading
 edge of the main element as well.
 Consequently, the aerodynamic pressure within the whole of slat gap has
 periodic fluctuations that are synchronized with the pressure variations
 induced by the convected vortices.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard

\color blue
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\color blue
From a 2D visualization at mid-span, the pressure inside the cove region
 also reveals an oscillating component, characterized by a significantly
 lower frequency compared to the stronger, smaller-scale fluctuations observed
 elsewhere.
 Given this distribution of periodic pressure fluctuations, it is reasonable
 to expect that shear layer modes would dominate in model order reduction
 techniques such as Proper Orthogonal Decomposition (POD) or Spectral Proper
 Orthogonal Decomposition (SPOD).
 However, since these fluctuations are purely hydrodynamic in nature, inferring
 acoustic interactions within the slat cove remains challenging unless hydrodyna
mic and acoustic modes are explicitly separated.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The unsteady velocity field can shed further light on the three-dimensionality
 of the flow which is not evident from the pressure fields.
 But before elaborating on this, we first plot the unsteady velocity components
 on a colormap suited to highlight the macro flow features outside recirculation
 zone.
 As seen in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Magnitude"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, the velocity magnitude highlights the flow topology as the fluid accelerates
 through the slat gap.
 The ambient/inlet velocity of the simulation is at 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{0}=50\thinspace m/s$
\end_inset

, which is accelerated upto a maximum of 
\begin_inset Formula $105\,m/s$
\end_inset

 in the region downstream of the slat trailing edge as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:The-unsteady-velocity"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 This acceleration is due to the nozzle effect of the slat gap.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Another prominent feature to be noticed is in the velocity components.
 In Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-X_1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Y_1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, it can be noticed that the major unsteadiness is confined to a region
 close to the slat TE while the a larger area of the slat gap maintains
 a steady flow.
 This suggest that the ejected vortices, which are understood to be majorly
 streamwise structures, tend to primarily graze the surface of the slat
 trailing edge and the leading edge wall of the main element experience
 a smoother flow.
 The unsteady velocity components also tend to suggest uneven distribution
 inside the slat cove and are generally consistent with the effects of flow
 redirection through slat gap from the pressure side.
 This can be noticed in the broader distribution of 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{X}$
\end_inset

 inside the cove region and the same for 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{Y}$
\end_inset

 around the mid-length of the shear layer.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/ThesisUnsteadyVelocityPlanar_Ratio.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 7.5cm
	height 7.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Velocity Z, 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{Z}$
\end_inset


\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Velocity-Z_1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The unsteady velocity field in the slat cove visualized using a narrow colorbar
 corresponding to velocity values 
\begin_inset Formula $U=\pm20 m/sm/s$
\end_inset

.
 The freestream velocity is 
\begin_inset Formula $50 m/sm/s$
\end_inset

.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:The-unsteady-velocity-smaller-colorbar"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
To further highlight the spanwise of flow inside the cove region, the colormap
 is further restricted to a smaller range of 
\begin_inset Formula $U\in[-20,20]\,ms^{-1}$
\end_inset

 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:The-unsteady-velocity-smaller-colorbar"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 Here the 3D-feature is more prominent and hence a velocity ratio capturing
 relative out-of-plane velocity 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{z}$
\end_inset

 against the residual planar velocity 
\begin_inset Formula $\sqrt{U_{X}^{2}+U_{Y}^{2}}$
\end_inset

 is used.
 By definition, 
\begin_inset Formula $R_{U_{Z}}=\frac{U_{Z}}{\sqrt{U_{X}^{2}+U_{Y}^{2}}}$
\end_inset

, serves to quantify the significance of the spanwise component.
 It can be noted in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:VelocityRatio"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 that the 
\begin_inset Formula $R_{U_{Z}}$
\end_inset

 is majorly positive in the lower part of the cove and have an opposite
 sign in the upper region.
 By nature of 
\begin_inset Formula $R_{U_{Z}}$
\end_inset

, this indicates that both 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{z}$
\end_inset

 is significant compared to the inplane velocity and that its direction
 reverses in different regions of the cove.
 This feature is however slightly vitiated by the unsteadiness of the recirculat
ing scale vortices but is a clearly demonstrable one with a sharp boundary
 for the sign reversal while analyzing the time-averaged fields as shown
 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Z-Mean-Cove-1-1"

\end_inset

.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Additionally, we note that the point of stagnation on the pressure side
 of main element's leading edge only have a weak local spike in value of
 
\begin_inset Formula $R_{U_{Z}}$
\end_inset

 since at this point the flow is majorly redirected within the plane with
 no significant mean flow in the spanwise directions.
 This contrasts with the effect inside the cove where there is no region
 with 
\begin_inset Formula $R_{U_{Z}}\approx0$
\end_inset

, thus suggesting that the 3-dimensionality is a result of the re-circulatory
 flow within the slat cove.
 The spanwise velocity field 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{z}$
\end_inset

 has a maximum of upto 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{z}=10\,ms^{-1}$
\end_inset

 inside the cove, i.e.
 upto 
\begin_inset Formula $20%\%
$
\end_inset

 of the free stream velocity.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Section
Time-averaged flow fields
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Given that the unsteady dynamics has an array of interesting features worthy
 of further exploration, it is important to understand the time-averaged
 fields in tandem.
 The mean flow field convects the fluid and its vortices to establish the
 macro-flow features like the accelerated flow through the slat gap and
 the recirculation region.
 Within this configuration, the unsteadiness can be thought to be introduced
 by generation of vorticity due to the presence of slat cusp or the shear
 layer.
 These vortices then develop unsteady dynamics which leads to the aeroacoustics.
 Hence the vortex dynamics itself is intrinsically first determined by the
 established mean flow.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The mean pressure field around the HLD is shown in the Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:meanCp"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 in terms of the Coefficient of Pressure, 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{p}$
\end_inset

.
 The mean pressure, as can be noted, drops significantly near and downstream
 of the slat gap leading to a negative spike.
 This suction peak enhances the lift performance of the wing.
 Looking more closely on to the slat cove, the visualization is made in
 terms of the primitive variables with a tailored color map in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:meanCpCove"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The region of impingement is distinctly identifiable as a region of high
 pressure due to the partial stagnation of the flow and hence the reduction
 in the flow area through the slat gap.
 It is also evident that the low pressure core of the cove due to recirculation
 is not exactly at the center of recirculation itself but shifted nearer
 to the shear layer.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tb
wide false
sideways false
status open

\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/Thesis_Cp_distribution.png
	lyxscale 40
	width 7.5cm
	height 7.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
a) Coefficient of pressure, 
\begin_inset Formula $\ensuremath{C_{p}=\frac{P-P_{0}}{\frac{1}{2}\rho_{\infty}U_{\infty}^{2}}},$
\end_inset

where, 
\begin_inset Formula $P_{0}=101325Pa$
\end_inset

, is the ambient pressure, 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{\infty}=50ms^{-1}$
\end_inset

, and 
\begin_inset Formula $\rho_{\infty}=1.225\,kg.m^{-3}$
\end_inset

, are the freestream density and velocity respectively.
 White line indicates the contour 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{p}=0$
\end_inset

.
 b) time-averaged pressure field in the slat cove.
 Both averaging is done for 5 chord pass times (
\begin_inset Formula $C=0.3m$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{\infty}=50ms^{-1}$
\end_inset

) corresponding to a physical time of 0.03s.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Velocity Ratio,

\end_inset


\begin_inset CommandInset label

\end_layout

\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
time-averaged spanwise velocity field in the slat cove.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Velocity-Z-Mean-Cove-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The mean velocity fields also largely agree with the understanding of the
 cove flow as inspected in the mid-span plane, as shown in Fig.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Mean_Cove"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The mean center of the recirculation can be identified in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Magnitude-Mean-Cove"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and the fact that the peak mean velocity magnitude occurs on the suction
 side of the main element which is also the region of reattachment of the
 flow from the slat TE with the main element.
 The peak locations of 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{X}$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{Y}$
\end_inset

 also agree with the geometrical redirection of the flow towards the slat
 gap.
 However, the spanwise mean velocity in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Z-Mean-Cove"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 using the same colormap leads to the erroneous inference of its insignificance
 due to the comparatively lower magnitudes.
 An alternative colourmap restricted to 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{Z}\in[-5,5]ms^{-1}$
\end_inset

 as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Z-Mean-Cove-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 reveals the formation of cells of spanwise velocity inside the cove region.
 The recirculation tend to have alternating signs for the spanwise velocity
 component in the upper and lower regions of the cove.
 The contour of velocity ratio 
\begin_inset Formula $R_{U_{Z}}=\frac{U_{Z}}{\sqrt{U_{X}^{2}+U_{Y}^{2}}}$
\end_inset

 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:CoveMeanVelocityRatio"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 as well as the raw 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{z}$
\end_inset

 for the mean field shows lower magnitudes than that while using the unsteady
 fields shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:VelocityRatio"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Z_1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 This suggest that the cell formation or the spanwise dynamics may be a
 periodic phenomena which are being numerically averaged out in time but
 with a lower frequency than to be sufficiently removed within 5 chord pass
 times.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/ThesisSpanwisePlaneSchematic.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 14cm
	height 14cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Spanwise velocity, 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{Z}$
\end_inset

, visualized on a cutplane parallel to the spanwise Z axis inside the cove
 region.
 The stream tracers are used in the mid-span plane to show the recirculation
 path in the mid-plane.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:ZPlaneSchematic"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/ThesisSpanCellsAnnotated.png
	lyxscale 50
	width 13cm
	height 13cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Contours of spanwise velocity, 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{Z}$
\end_inset

, showing the cell formation inside the cove region.
 The cut line denoted the approximate position of the shear layer passing
 through the visualization plane.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:ZPlaneCells"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
To generate the spanwise planes, a slice of the simulated geometry is made
 in the slat cove region parallel to the spanwise axis as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:ZPlaneSchematic"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The spanwise velocity is then visualized on this plane with suitable colourmap
 to identify the local sign of spanwise velocity.
 As can be observed, the `spanwise cells', as we like to refer to the region
 of same velocity direction, appear to be stacked periodically with alternating
 signs.
 The magnitude of mean spanwise velocity is close to 
\begin_inset Formula $5\,ms^{-1}$
\end_inset

, which is upto 
\begin_inset Formula $10%\%
$
\end_inset

 of the free stream velocity, 
\begin_inset Formula $U=50\,ms^{-1}$
\end_inset

.
 These cells are also of length scales of the same order of the spanwise
 domain length, which for the current case of standard slat positioning
 generate a total of 6 cells, or 3 pairs of alternating signs.
 Their average spanwise wavelength is hence 
\begin_inset Formula $\lambda_{z}=L_{span}/3=0.2/3=0.066\,m$
\end_inset

.
 An exact measurement of the length of center cells are shown in Fig.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:ZPlaneCells"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and is approximately 
\begin_inset Formula $0.0696\thinspace m$
\end_inset

 thereby giving a slat chord based non-dimensional wavelength as 
\begin_inset Formula $\Lambda_{z}=\lambda_{z}/C_{s}=1.785$
\end_inset

.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The cell formations tend to maintain the same cells size along the spanwise
 direction through out the cove region.
 However, the cells are not only modulated in the spanwise direction but
 are arranged into two layers along the length of the shear layer path.
 This was already visible in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Z-Mean-Cove-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 on the spanwise mid-plane.
 The spanwise plane visualization on multiple spanwise planes marked PL1,
 PL2, and PL3, at varying Y coordinates as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Visualisation_planes"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 suggest that the stacking of cells again also form an alternating arrangement
 for the sign of the spanwise velocity, i.e.
 along the shear layer length, the arrangement of the cells are such that
 they oppose in signs between the cells attached to early shear layer and
 later shear layer.
 Visualizing on a fourth plane which lies between PL1 and PL2 as shown in
 Fig.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Visualisation_planes-4"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 also show this arrangement as they transition from the early shear layer
 to the later stage.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The spanwise modulations and their obscurity in slat noise literature lead
 us to many interesting thoughts of which the following three are worthy
 of mention here:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
First is that the alternating time-averaged spanwise velocity means that
 there exist static nodal planes towards which the flow can converge and
 diverge from.
 Those planes whose both sides have spanwise velocity such that it decreases
 from positive to negative along the spanwise direction and hence have the
 flow directed towards the plane will be referred to as the `converging
 plane'.
 The other type of planes where the spanwise velocity increases from negative
 to positive necessitating the flow to diverge from the plane are the `diverging
 planes'.
 Since these planes act as sources and sinks for the spanwise dynamics,
 they must facilitate the interaction of the spanwise dynamics with the
 2-dimensional dynamics in the streamwise direction.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
Second is that if such nodal planes exist, it is necessary that there must
 exist a mechanism to redistribute the fluid from the converging planes
 and to replenish the diverging planes continuously to establish a steady
 dynamics.
 Here, we have already seen that the recirculating small scale streamwise
 vortices are absorbed into the shear layer in regions near the mid trajectory.
 This suggest that for a converging plane, the mechanism to redistribute
 the fluid is by entertainment of flow along with the streamwise structures
 into the shear layer, which must also lead to higher concentration(spanwise)
 of streamwise structures at the locations of the converging planes.
 There must also be a lower concentration of the streamwise structures in
 the diverging planes.
 Nevertheless, this may not be a phenomena easily observed in a largely
 turbulent state at 
\begin_inset Formula $Re=10^{6}$
\end_inset

 with constant generation, distortion, and redistribution of vorticity,
 as in the slat cove.
 
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/VisualisationPlanes3.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 5.5cm
	height 5.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/Spanwise_modulations_velocity.png
	lyxscale 50
	width 9cm
	height 9cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Left: Visualization planes used to show the spanwise modulation at different
 locations of the shear layer.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Visualisation_planes"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/ThesisSpanCellsBetweenPL1andPL2.png
	lyxscale 50
	width 15cm
	height 15cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Left: Spanwise modulation on a visualization plane in between PL1 and PL2.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Visualisation_planes-4"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
The driving factor for the spanwise modulations should be the result of
 a dynamic instability either due to the shear layer geometry or due to
 the recirculating flow.
 Similar spanwise modulations are documented for flow over a backward facing
 step by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Their work categorically demonstrated the existence of large scale spanwise
 modulations in the shear layer due to the presence of a backward facing
 step, and argues that the spanwise modulations are the result of an absolute
 convective instability owing to the closed loop streamline in the recirculation
 bubble leading to generation of steady spanwise modes.
 The eigen functions identified in their work using the linear stability
 analysis of a simplified flow configuration, as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:barkleyspanmodes"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, predicts the spanwise wavelength with same order as that of the cavity
 depth.
 This is consistent with the observation that the spanwise cells in the
 slat cove have a wavelength with same order as the slat chord.
 On comparing the rectangular flow cavity with the slat cove, the cavity
 depth is analogous to the diameter of the recirculating cove flow, and
 this diameter is approximately the slat chord.
 Their study also suggest a critical Reynolds number, although at a low
 range of 
\begin_inset Formula $Re_{c}=748$
\end_inset

, from which the spanwise modulations are dominant and this critical Reynolds
 number is also argued to be decreased when a lateral side wall is present.
 In the case of simulations with spanwise periodic conditions mimicking
 an infinite spanwise domain, the critical Reynolds number is also increased.
 The case of slat cove dynamics is at a Reynolds number of 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{6}$
\end_inset

 based on the mean flow and if considering the flow inside the cove region,
 taking the mean velocity to be 
\begin_inset Formula $20\,m/s$
\end_inset

, and the characteristic length scale to be the slat chord, 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{s}=0.039\,m$
\end_inset

, corresponding Reynolds number is at 
\begin_inset Formula $54000$
\end_inset

.
 This regime is still two orders of magnitude higher than that required
 to trigger the convective instability.
 The presence of spanwise walls are also of much importance for the slat
 cove flow as well, since, in our simulations we employ periodic conditions,
 and in experimental studies the lateral side walls are necessary to support
 the HLD mockup in the wind tunnel.
 Hence, drawing parallels between the fact that the flow over a backward
 facing step is much similar to the shear layer geometry of the slat cusp,
 particularly due to the fact that the slat cove also has one side bounded
 by a shear layer and both have a recirculation bubble in which the spanwise
 modes tend to dominate, we suspect the same mechanism is also in action
 in the slat cove dynamics.
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter06_figs/Barkley_Eigen.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 12cm
	height 12cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Image of the eigen mode demonstrating the spanwise instability mode for
 flow over a backward facing step from the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The original caption read: 
\begin_inset Quotes eld
\end_inset

Three-dimensional flow structure of the critical eigenmode at 
\begin_inset Formula $Re=750$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $\beta=0.9$
\end_inset

.
 Contours indicate the strength of the streamwise velocity component and
 vectors show the 
\begin_inset Formula $(v,w)$
\end_inset

 flow pattern in each cross-sectional plane: 
\begin_inset Formula $x=1.2,6.2\text{ and }12.2$
\end_inset

.
\begin_inset Quotes erd
\end_inset


\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:barkleyspanmodes"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
Similarly, 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Neary1987"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 studied open rectangular cavity flows and the same was studied more analyticall
y using Linear Stability arguments by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 For the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Neary1987"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, three regimes of flow for an open rectangular cavity based on the Reynold's
 number was identified.
 In the first, there is a strong interaction of the shear layer with the
 recirculating vortex inside the cavity.
 In a second regime of higher Reynolds number, the interaction leads to
 intermittent behavior leading to a bursting phenomena where the recirculating
 vortex tends to oscillate in size leading to it bursting through the shear
 layer to release vorticity.
 While doing so, the flow is said to be strongly turbulent.
 In the third regime typically at 
\begin_inset Formula $Re=33500$
\end_inset

, (for our low speed cove recirculation, 
\begin_inset Formula $Re=54000$
\end_inset

), the bursting oscillations and associated pressure oscillations become
 more frequent but irregular.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
In the later work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, the rectangular cavities were further analyzed using three-dimensional
 global instability analysis to show that the spanwise instability wavelength
 scales are proportional to the cavity depth.
 The resulting spanwise modulated flow also develop oscillations that can
 induce a low frequency pulsation of the recirculating vortex.
 This frequency was deduced to have one order of magnitude lower than the
 Rossiter oscillations.
 The dependence of the growth rate of the spanwise modes with Reynolds number
 was also identified along with a critical value that would trigger the
 formation of the spanwise modes.
 However, the most interesting argument made by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 was that the spanwise instability was a result of the curvature of the
 flow, i.e.
 the curved streamline of the recirculating vortices in the cavity would
 lead to a centrifugal instability that is different from the Rossiter oscillati
ons and the Görtler type instability that occurs on curved boundary walls.
 This argument finds its strength from the fact that the location of strongest
 spanwise modulation is in the region of strong curvature of the recirculation
 bubble on the downstream corner of the cavity.
 The spanwise modulated recirculation vortex would develop also a low frequency
 oscillation, and this additional oscillations can interfere with the Rossiter
 modes to modulate both its frequency and peak amplitudes.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
That being noted on the spanwise mode formations, the same argument, along
 with the fact that for both the shear layer on a backward facing step and
 the recirculation streamline in open cavity flows have, in common, a curved
 streamline with one side bounded by a shear layer, we choose to investigate
 the case of slat cove dynamics in terms its peculiarities arising from
 curved streamline path of its shear layer.
 In line with this hypothesis, the behavior of a curved shear layer was
 also studied by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 His work studied the linear inviscid hydrodynamic stability of a slightly
 curved free shear layer.
 The study compared the cases of a stably curved and unstably curved shear
 layer identifying sensitivity of the flow to the addition of curvature
 to an already present shear layer.
 The formation of Görtler vortices was identified as a possible reason for
 the generation of streamwise oriented counter rotating vortex pairs while
 the unstably curved regime is present.
 The work also provides a non-dimensional parameter, the curvature Richardson
 number, to quantify the effect an accelerated generation of streamwise
 vortices and will be used for comparison in our study as well.
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/Spanwisemodes_Bres.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 14cm
	height 14cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The spanwise modes in a rectangular cavity with periodic spanwise conditions
 from the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The original caption read: 
\begin_inset Quotes eld
\end_inset

Visualization of the three-dimensional flow for run 2M0325-3D at six different
 times (a–f ) corresponding to approximately one-sixth phase intervals of
 a half-period of the three-dimensional instability.
 The iso-surfaces represent the spanwise velocity levels 
\begin_inset Formula $w/U=−0.01$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $w/U=0.01$
\end_inset

.
 The whole spanwise extent of the cavity is shown and the wavelength 
\begin_inset Formula $λ/D=1$
\end_inset

 of the instability can clearly be observed.
 The velocity vectors in the streamwise cross-section at 
\begin_inset Formula $z=0$
\end_inset

 are shown inside the cavity and once in the free-stream for comparison.
\begin_inset Quotes erd
\end_inset

 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:spanwisemodesbres"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
From the above-mentioned array of ideas, we tend to theorize that the slat
 cove dynamics at the current Reynolds number has the following features
 and explanations:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The slat shear layer formed due to the difference of velocity between the
 free-stream and the recirculation vortex leads to the canonical Kelvin-Helmholt
z (K-H) instability as well identified in the literature
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Terracol2016,Souza2019"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The saturation of K-H instability leads to the generation of 2-dimensional
 spanwise coherent structures being shed periodically from the cusp.
 If these vortices were to be convected in a straight line path, their behavior
 would only have the peculiarities of a vortex convected through an accelerated
 flow.
 However, since the established mean flow is such that the streamlines are
 curved along with the shear layer to facilitate flow through the slat gap,
 the vortices also follow a curved trajectory.
 This curvature of the streamline necessarily have a mean diameter of curvature
 similar in magnitude to the slat chord length.
 The spanwise coherent vortices which undergo such strong curvature experience
 an additional centrifugal force.
 Here, the pressure distribution inside the slat cove is lower than the
 pressure outside the cove region due to the fact that the region outside
 the slat cove is at the pressure side of the main element and is affected
 by presence of stagnation point on the main-element.
 Hence, the normal pressure gradient along the shear layer is positive along
 a radius of curvature of the shear layer with center of rotation inside
 the cove.
 This radial pressure gradient opposes the centrifugal force thereby requiring
 a balancing of these forces to enable a stable flow.
 This is the classical requirement for a dynamic instability to occur where
 two opposing forces which are supposed to be balanced are, in reality,
 not exactly and dynamically balanced, thereby leading to large growth rate
 for certain class of perturbations.
 The curved shear layer is hence susceptible to the curvature instability
 leading to the typical steady spanwise modes primarily attached to the
 shear layer as described by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Considering the mean velocity distribution as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Velocity-Magnitude-Mean-Cove"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, it can be noticed that for the early part of the shear layer, the lower
 velocity flow is on the concave side of the shear layer curvature.
 This is a stable curvature since according to Rayleigh criteria the equilibrium
 is stable against curvature instability if the angular momentum decreases
 radially outward
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Rayleigh1917"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 In early shear layer, the streamline velocity is increasing radially outward
 from the cove center and hence the curvature instability is stabilized.
 Furthermore, as inferred by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, the initial K-H instability may also be stabilized partially leading to
 a reduced growth rate of the streamwise perturbations suggesting a delayed
 spanwise vortex generation due to the effect of curvature.
 Hence, in this regime, the major noticeable dynamics are a delayed generation
 of K-H vortices as suggested by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 together with the large spanwise modulations arising from the convective
 instability of the recirculation from the suggestion of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
As the flow progresses downstream, the shear layer weakens due to its spreading
 and growth of spanwise vortices.
 Simultaneously, the radius of curvature also decreases to eventually reverse
 its sign.
 Once the sign of curvature reverses and strengthen near the vicinity of
 the slat trailing edge region, i.e., the streamlines curve such that the
 low pressure area of the suction peak on the main element is again on the
 concave side of the streamlines near the slat gap, and the high pressure
 region generated due to the impingement of the shear layer on the slat
 trailing edge is on its convex side.
 This reversed configuration of pressure gradient is again opposing the
 centrifugal acceleration facilitating curvature instability again.
 However, unlike the early shear layer, the velocity field can be noticed
 to have the high velocity stream on the concave side of the curvature.
 This according to 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 is the unstably curved configuration and satisfy the Rayleigh criterion
 to have a radially decreasing angular momentum.
 Hence the shear layer now develops a strong centrifugal instability leading
 to the generation of streamwise oriented counter rotating vortex pairs.
 This generation of small scale structures are strongly accelerated by the
 presence of the ingested vortices from the recirculation region.
 It must be clearly noted that the regime of flow near the slat trailing
 edge is the asymptotic case for the linear stability analyzed by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 whose conclusions are only directly valid for a curved free shear layer
 with small curvature.
 The effective range of curvature Richardson numbers for their analysis
 is of the order of 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{-3}$
\end_inset

 where for the slat shear layer, these are on average two orders of magnitude
 higher as we show in the upcoming session.
 Hence, for the later part of the shear layer near the impingement location
 and flow through the slat gap, the major phenomena is the curvature instability
 driven by a considerably lower radius of curvature with a mean velocity
 distribution enabling a fully unstable configuration.
 The only noticeable effect is hence the generation of streamwise oriented
 counter rotating vortex pairs which assimilate into larger streamwise vortices
 on the slat trailing edge and are elongated and ejected through the slat
 gap.
 The terminology used in the recent literature
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Wang2019,Wang2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 that these are `Görtler like' transition is hence logically valid, although
 there is no curved boundary layer as in the case of the canonical Görtler
 transition that leads to small scale streamwise oriented structures.
 Note that since this is a purely centrifugal instability, meaning that
 this generation of streamwise structures would happen even if there was
 no supply of spanwise coherent vortices in the impinging shear layer, as
 reported by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Wang2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Their work demonstrates that at low enough Reynolds numbers, the periodic
 vortex shedding from the slat cusp is suppressed, possibly due to the combined
 effect of the stabilization of K-H instability due to curvature and the
 low Reynolds number, and the only noticeable turbulence generation is that
 of the streamwise vortices near the trailing edge.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Finally, inside the recirculation, the flow developing spanwise modulation
 was previously unidentified in the literature although it was noticed early
 that the vorticity ejected from the slat gap had spanwise modulations.
 The flow in the cove region was largely analyzed under the assumption that
 it is spanwise homogeneous, and at this point of understanding the cove
 dynamics, it is striking why the prediction of cove flow and related acoustics
 remained elusive from a perfectly predictive modelling 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Souza2022"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 This we suggest is due to the fact that the three dimensionality of the
 flow due to the spanwise modulation would induce additional oscillations,
 suggestively with frequency one order of magnitude lower than the first
 Rossiter tone, which can modulate the tonal frequencies and the amplitude
 of the peaks as suggested by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 This tone, or more precisely a broadband hump in the low frequency was
 clearly identified in the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Jawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, who characterized the same as having a different source mechanism compared
 to other tones.
 The broadening of a purely tonal wave while propagating though a strongly
 turbulent region like that of the slat cove and flow around the airfoil
 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Clair2018"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, together with the fact that the intermittent bursting phenomena associated
 with oscillation of the recirculation vortex can both significantly broaden
 the frequency bandwidth of fluctuations effected by this mechanism on a
 far-field microphone.
 This broadband hump is also in the low frequency range which is dominated
 by the measurement noise from the experimental setup and noise from the
 shear layer of the open jet wind tunnel adding to their elusiveness.
 Thus when tonal character of slat noise was rightly identified as those
 related to the Rossiter mechanism by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, their modulation mechanism was overlooked due to the assumption of the
 spanwise homogeneity and thereby the choice of methodology for both experimenta
tion and numerical studies so far.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Now, before moving on to further discussion of the unsteady data related
 to the acoustics, we take a light detour to showcase a few additional simulatio
ns to establish that the formation of spanwise modes are not purely an artifact
 of the numerical simulation.
 This is evident from the fact that the same phenomena is observed in both
 flow over a backward facing step
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 and open cavity flows
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 and also the experimental studies of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Wang2019,Wang2021,Wang2023"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Nevertheless, our simulations serve to shed more light on the same in the
 particular context of slat cove dynamics.
 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
Similar simulations confirming the spanwise modulation in cove flow 
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Similar simulations 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
To demonstrate that the formation of spanwise modes is not an artifact of
 the simulation or the spanwise boundary condition applied, we discuss a
 few simulations which have a slightly varied configurations.
 For this first we take the case of simulation of VALIANT HLD geometry which
 has the wind tunnel geometry and the supporting lateral sidewalls included
 in the simulation.
 Then we discuss the simulations where the spanwise length of the domain
 is reduced by a factor of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.5$
\end_inset

, and then a case with only two rectangular plates included to use reflecting
 boundary conditions in the spanwise boundaries as opposed to periodic condition
s used in the standard simulations.
 All these cases are shown to develop the spanwise cells for the time-averaged
 spanwise velocity field.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Simulation with wind tunnel geometry and lateral side walls included
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
For sake of brevity, only the mean flow results of this simulation are discussed
 here and a detailed account of the same given in the Appendix A Section
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "sec:Details-of-WTunnelsimulation"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The mean velocity field obtained at multiple vertical planes across the
 span in the cove region is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwiseplanesvaliant"

\end_inset

.
 
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
This simulation was carried out with the same solver ProLB with all numerical
 parameters maintained same as that of the standard simulation in the free
 flow configuration discussed in the previous chapter.
 A schematic of the new simulation domain and the placement of the HLD within
 the supporting walls are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:simdomain"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tbp
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align left
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align left
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/SpanPlaneCove1Merged.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 15cm
	height 15cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Near the slat cusp.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align left
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align left
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/SpanPlaneCove2Merged.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 15cm
	height 15cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Inside the cove region.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align left
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align left
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/SpanPlaneCove3Merged.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 15cm
	height 15cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Near the slat gap.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Time-averaged spanwise velocity on spanwise planes at different locations
 in the slat cove region for simulation which includes the spanwise plates
 and wind tunnel geometry.
 The modulation of the spanwise velocity is noticeable with cell formation
 similar to the free flow simulation without spanwise plates.
 The edge effects distorting the cells are also evident on the sides which
 is due to the presence of lateral side walls and the boundary layer and
 associated vorticity generation 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:spanwiseplanesvaliant"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Time-averaged spanwise velocity on spanwise planes at different locations
 in the slat cove region for simulation which includes the spanwise plates
 and wind tunnel geometry
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The time-averaged mean flow fields are computed from the simulation data
 by averaging over 
\begin_inset Formula $5$
\end_inset

 chord pass times same as the standard procedure.
 As can be noted, the cell formation due to the previously mentioned curvature
 instability is notable in the spanwise velocity distribution near the central
 plane away from the lateral walls.
 However, closer to the walls, the velocity field is more strongly modulated
 with stronger amplitudes than near the center planes.
 Such effects were also noted in the presence of the backward facing steps
 where lateral side walls generate strong three dimensionality for flow
 adjacent to the walls 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 However these can be thought to be a separate phenomena since the lateral
 walls of the airfoil also generate additional dynamics due to the problem
 of corner separation for the turbulent boundary layer.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The cells near the center plane appear to have the same properties as those
 formed in the free flow simulation.
 The modulations are largely attached to the shear layer, and as the shear
 layer developed downstream, the cells inside the recirculation region tend
 to remain attached to the shear layer.
 A separate arrangement of cells with phase inversion is seen to then occupy
 the interior of the cove nearer to the curved inner wall of the slat.
 This new arrangement then develops stronger towards the slat gap but is
 noticeably more distorted due to the end wall effects.
 The nodal planes leading to converging and diverging planes are noticeable
 which suggests that the pulsating mechanism related to the low frequency
 broadband peak can be present.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The extent of the effect of lateral walls into the interior of the cavity
 in spanwise direction is significant.
 Current simulation suggests that more than 
\begin_inset Formula $80\%$
\end_inset

 of the spanwise extent is affected by the distortion and the curvature
 related flow structure is limited to only 
\begin_inset Formula $20\%$
\end_inset

 of the length.
 This means that curvature related low frequency pulse is considerably weaker
 in the experimental spectra and hence is also not notable.
 It is hence possible that the experiment also has reduced effect of the
 spanwise modulation leading to a reduced modulation of the tonal frequencies.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Another factor worthy of mention is that in comparison with the VALIANT
 experiment which uses a spanwise length of 1 chord length, i.e.
 
\begin_inset Formula $0.3\,m$
\end_inset

 as the distance between the spanwise plates, the setup for a different
 experiment on the 30P30N HLD geometry by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "KamliyaJawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 used a spanwise length of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.5\,m$
\end_inset

.
 In terms of the chord to span ratio, VALIANT experiment kept 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{L_{s}}{C_{s}}=1$
\end_inset

, whereas in 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Jawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

's work, a ratio of 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{L_{s}}{C_{s}}=1.42$
\end_inset

 was kept.
 The latter also was designed at a chord based Reynolds number of 
\begin_inset Formula $Re=70000$
\end_inset

.
 The experiment was conducted at the wind tunnel facility at University
 of Bristol and lead to observation of the prominent low frequency hump
 in the spectra corresponding to the first Rossiter mode, and particularly
 with strong intermittency and stochastic character.
 From the influence of the lateral side wall plates that is shown to disrupt
 the spanwise mode formation due to centrifugal instability and the nature
 of its suspected low frequency oscillation, we conjecture that the strength
 of the low frequency hump in the noise spectra will be correlated with
 the availability of sufficient space between spanwise holding plates.
 This can also influence the strength of the tones and can be suspected
 to be the reason for the variation of strength for the alternating narrow
 bands peaks in their far-field observation.
 It is however the general experimenter's wisdom that keeping the spanwise
 distance as high as possible would reduce the three dimensional effect
 of the side wall boundary layer thereby recovering the spanwise homogeneous
 2D flow in the spanwise central plane.
 This is expected from the behavior of wide span cavities as well
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "HamiltonSmith2024"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 But counter-intuitively, this is only disrupting the development of the
 three dimensionality due to the centrifugal instability for the slate cove
 case.
 Further more, the measurement of the turbulent intensity and wall pressure
 spectrum will also be misinformed in the case of similar experiments with
 insufficient spanwise margin since the existence of a nodal plane at the
 spanwise central plane can lead to erroneous observation of either excessive
 or reduced turbulence intensity due to the converging or diverging motion
 of spanwise structures in the cove recirculation region.
 The spanwise modes and their possible oscillations hence provide a reasonable
 explanation for the intrigue upon the quasi-periodic behavior of the Rossiter
 tones in the study by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Jawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Simulation with rectangular lateral plates only
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
To investigate the effect of spanwise boundary condition for the slat cove
 region, a similar simulation was setup where the span boundaries were supplante
d with a plate.
 The wall of the plate provides a no-slip condition similar to the simulation
 of the wind-tunnel case and hence avoids the additional artifacts of using
 a spanwise periodic domain.
 A schematic of the arrangement is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:SimulationWithPlatesSchematic"

\end_inset

 and the mean flow across the span length inside the slat cove is shown
 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:SimulationWithPlatesSchematicMeanFlowAirfoil"

\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:SimulationWithPlatesSpanwiseVelocity"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/PlatesCaseSchematic1.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 10cm
	height 10cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Schematic of the flow simulation setup.
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:SimulationWithPlatesSchematic"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/SpanplatesSeparation.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 10cm
	height 10cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\color black
The flow separates possibly due to disproportionate interference from turbulence
 due to the side walls and plate corner.
\color red

\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:SimulationWithPlatesSchematicMeanFlowAirfoil"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/SpanwiseCellsSeparatedFlow.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 11cm
	height 11cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Spanwise cell formation is still noticeable although the cove shape is distorted
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:SimulationWithPlatesSpanwiseVelocity"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The mean flow around the airfoil in this case shows a strong deviation from
 the standard case results.
 Here the flow separates early from the leading edge of the main element
 leading edge and is hence stalled.
 The shape of the cove flow is also strongly distorted such that shear layer
 is elongated with a reduced initial curvature near the slat cusp.
 Hence this case is not successful simulation of the aerodynamics in view
 of its fidelity against the experiment, but however is still valid to be
 inspected for the effect of the spanwise condition inside the slat cove.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
As can be seen in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:SimulationWithPlatesSpanwiseVelocity"

\end_inset

, the spanwise cut plane across the span still retains the spanwise periodic
 cell formation.
 Here the region inside of the cove region can be seen to have the spanwise
 cells while the region outside of the shear layer region is strongly affected
 by the presence of the wall.
 The spanwise velocity near the spanwise walls are strongly perturbed by
 the boundary layer to have a mean distribution as to direct the flow towards
 the span center.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The outcome of this simulation is two fold: one is that the presence of
 spanwise cells are demonstrated to be independent of the spanwise boundary
 conditions in the simulation for the slat cove region; the second is that
 this cell formations are possible even if there is a strong incoming turbulence
 intensity.
 For the incoming turbulence, it can modify the flow such that airfoil stalls
 at an early angle of attack and also alter the shear layer shape.
 Nevertheless, the recirculation flow generates the centrifugal instability
 inside the cove and hence the spanwise cells are still present.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Simulation with a reduced span and periodic boundary conditions
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Another case for the inspecting spanwise cell formation was one with a reduced
 span of one-half of the original length.
 All other simulation parameters are kept the same as the standard simulation.
 Here, as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:HalfSpanSimulation"

\end_inset

, the velocity distribution shows little difference in the larger two dimensiona
l features of the flow in the mid-span plane.
 However, the three dimensionality of the cove flow and the formation of
 spanwise cells seems to be attenuated in this case.
 As shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:TimeAveragedSpanwiseHalfSpan"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, the spanwise cells are formed in the early part of the shear layer as
 expected from the full span simulation.
 However, for the region corresponding to the later part of the shear layer,
 the spanwise modulation seams to have weakened leading to more homogeneity
 in the flow and reduced spanwise velocity component.
 This induced homogeneity of the flow due to spanwise condition is recognized
 in literature and have served as a criterion to determine the lower bound
 for the spanwise length of simulation domain for numerical studies
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Lockard2009,Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 have already studied the VALIANT geometry using different spanwise extent
 to demonstrate the same phenomena.
 For the current case, spanwise length of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.1\,m$
\end_inset

 is hence inferred as insufficient to reproduce the full three dimensionality
 of the flow.
 This leads to the partial formation of the spanwise modulations in the
 early part of the shear layer due to strong curvature of the flow and a
 largely homogeneous spanwise distribution in the rest of the cove region.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The partial presence of the spanwise cells in a reduced span simulation
 also hints at the fact that the spanwise boundary condition acts only so
 as to induce homogeneity.
 The persistent formation of cell structures in the region of early shear
 layer with strong curvature again suggest that the 3-dimensionality is
 predominantly a centrifugal effect.
 This centrifugal flow is primarily driven by the concave curvature of the
 inner wall of the slat cusp together with the redirection of the flow by
 the incoming ambient flow from upstream.
 Persistence of the spanwise modulation at this region, while induced homogeneit
y dominating in the downstream locations, suggest that the amplification
 of the spanwise mode instability is higher in the region of early shear
 layer compared to other regions in the cove.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/VelocityMagnitude.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 12cm
	height 12cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Time-averaged velocity magnitude field for simulation using reduced span
 of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.1\,m$
\end_inset

.
 Major flow features are not altered as compared to span length of standard
 simulation at 
\begin_inset Formula $0.2\,m$
\end_inset


\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:HalfSpanSimulation"

\end_inset
