 of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.1\,m$
\end_inset

.
 The spanwise cell formation is seen to remain only in the early part of
 the shear layer whereas the rest of the cove region seems to develop spanwise
 homogeneity arising from the effect of periodic boundary conditions applied
 in the spanwise boundaries 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:TimeAveragedSpanwiseHalfSpan"

\end_inset

\begin_layout Subsection
Simulation at lower Reynolds number using geometry scaling 
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Reduced Re Sim
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The spanwise mode formation is tested again in the case of a reduced chord
 length.
 For this we scale the geometry by a factor of 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{2}{3}=0.66$
\end_inset

.
 The new stowed chord of the HLD is 
\begin_inset Formula $C=0.2\,m$
\end_inset

.
 All the simulation parameters are kept same as the free flow standard simulatio
n, including the spanwise length which is at 
\begin_inset Formula $L_{s}=0.2\,m$
\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The time-averaged spanwise velocity fields are visualized for this case
 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:mambo_spanwise_cells"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The spanwise cells can be noted to have similar arrangement as in the standard
 case.
 However, the spanwise wavelength has been reduced by a factor of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.56$
\end_inset

.
 This is consistent with the fact that cells are formed by mechanism similar
 to the backward facing step studied by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 where the spanwise wavelength is of the same order as that of the cavity
 depth.
 Here the scaling of the slat chord, and hence the cavity depth, is also
 by a factor of 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{2}{3}$
\end_inset

 with respect to the standard geometry, and hence is now 
\begin_inset Formula $0.026\,m$
\end_inset

.
 Correspondingly, the spanwise wavelength also undergoes down scaling.
 By a linear factor of 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{2}{3}$
\end_inset

, the new wavelength would be expected at 
\begin_inset Formula $0.0464\,m$
\end_inset

 corresponding to 
\begin_inset Formula $4.3$
\end_inset

 cells.
 However the observed configuration forms a total of 
\begin_inset Formula $5$
\end_inset

 cells with a wavelength of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.039\,m$
\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The Reynolds number of the flow is also scaled by a factor of 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{2}{3}$
\end_inset

 due to the scaling of characteristic length.
 However, the inlet velocity is maintained at 
\begin_inset Formula $50\,m/s$
\end_inset

 and hence the flow along the shear layer maintains a similar velocity profile.
 Here the magnitude of curvature is amplified by a factor 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{3}{2}$
\end_inset

 and hence higher the effect of centrifugal destabilization.
 For this case the observed spanwise wavelength 
\begin_inset Formula $0.039\,m$
\end_inset

 and shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:mambo_spanwise_cells"

\end_inset

 and therefore the slat-chord based non-dimensional wavelength 
\begin_inset Formula $\Lambda_{z}=\lambda_{z}/C_{s}^{*}=1.5$
\end_inset

 where 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{s}^{*}$
\end_inset

 is the new slat chord.
 Note that for the full span case, it maintained 
\begin_inset Formula $\Lambda_{z}=1.785$
\end_inset

.
 Nevertheless, the final selection of wave number is constrained by the
 fact that the spanwise boundaries have a periodic conditions thereby necessitat
ing a whole number of cells in the total span length.
 Counting this in, the given cases validates the suggestion of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 that the spanwise wavelength is proportional to the cavity depth and also
 that the mode formation is primarily driven by the centrifugal instability
 mechanism similar to cavity flows.
 Since this phenomenon was only discovered during the exercise of this thesis,
 we did not conduct a parametric study to understand the variation of the
 span length, along with spanwise domain length.
 Such an investigation and also a model for the prediction of cell formation
 in the particular case of slat cove flow by using linear stability analysis
 can be an interesting avenue for further investigation.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter09_figs/mambocells.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 16cm
	height 16cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Spanwise cells formed near the early shear layer (for location see plane
 PL1 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Visualisation_planes-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

) for the case of downscaled geometry.
 The downscaling factor of 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{2}{3}$
\end_inset

 also affect the wavelength of the cells.
 However the selection of wave number is constrained by the fact that the
 spanwise length requires a whole number multiple of the wavelength 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:mambo_spanwise_cells"

\end_inset

 geometry

\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
Analyzing Streamline Curvature of the Shear Layer
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "sec:Analyzing-the-streamline"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Streamline Curvature
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The analysis of the mean flow inside the cove region and drawing parallels
 from the literature, particularly from that on the spanwise modulation
 of curved flows in cases of flow past a backward facing step, open cavity
 flows, and lid-driven cavity flows, it suggests to investigate the effect
 of i) the three dimensionality and ii) streamline curvature in the shear
 layer and recirculation region.
 The curvature of the streamline in the shear layer may also trigger a `Görtler'
 like transition leading to the generation of counter-rotating small-scale
 streamwise structures.
 Both these effects are fundamental to the slat noise generation mechanism
 whose tonal characteristics are necessarily influenced by the coherence
 of the impinging spanwise coherent vortices.
 Hence, to understand the curvature effects more thoroughly and to quantitativel
y understand its implications on the shear layer development, we attempt
 to characterize the mean streamlines by utilizing the mean field recording
 available from the LBM simulations.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The mean streamlines can be obtained from the time-averaged velocity field.
 For our purpose, we use a constant time stepping and the mean 2-dimensional
 velocity as the gradient field as inputs to a Runge-Kutta integrator.
 Here, since we assume that the flow features in the spanwise direction
 are primarily driven by the streamline curvature in the mid-span 2D plane,
 the streamwise and cross-flow component of the velocity field is used to
 study the streamline in their 2D plane and omit the contribution of spanwise
 velocity component.
 For the Runge-Kutta integrator, we use the classical fourth order RK4 formulati
on.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The mean flow data is obtained on the Cartesian grid of the simulation.
 However, this grid is not suitable to obtain a continuous streamline and
 hence the velocity field need to be interpolated in order to obtain the
 velocity value at a given query point for the RK integrator.
 For this interpolation we use the Clough-Tocher interpolation scheme provided
 with the scientific computing package SciPy.
 The interpolation scheme finds the three neighboring points of the query
 point and uses a piece-wise interpolating Bezier polynomial with order
 of accuracy upto third degree.
 Since the procedure is computationally inexpensive and over resolution
 is used by setting the time stepping to 
\begin_inset Formula $2\times10^{-7}s$
\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The streamline can thus be recovered for any selection of the source point
 in the flow field.
 However, to select a suitable point that would allow capturing the mean
 trajectory of the spanwise coherent vortices, the mean velocity magnitude
 distribution on a straight line across the shear layer near the slat cusp
 is used as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:velocityacrossshearlayer"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The point at the bottom of the dip in velocity magnitude correspond to
 the point immediately downstream of the slat cusp and this point is selected
 as the source point for the streamline integrator.
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tb
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/Streamline.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 7.5cm
	height 7.5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:shearlayercurvature"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset

 
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter04_figs/VelMagnitude_AlongVerticalLine.png
	lyxscale 50
	width 8cm
	height 8cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:velocityacrossshearlayer"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
a) The streamline obtained using Runge-Kutta integration of the velocity
 field from a source point near the slat cusp.
 The initial line across the shear layer used to obtain the streamline source
 point is shown as L1.
 b) The velocity magnitude obtained along the line L1 with the minima denoting
 the location of the line crossing the immediate vicinity of the slat cusp
 is marked with a dot 
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The streamline obtained using Runge-Kutta integration of the velocity field
 from a source point near the slat cusp
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset

The obtained streamline is then used to quantitatively analyze the streamline
 curvature.
 Geometrically, the local curvature of a streamline is defined as the rate
 of variation of a unit tangent vector direction with respect to the arc-length.
 This definition allows to calculate the Radius of curvature in different
 forms as 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{align*}
R & =\left\Vert \frac{d\vec{T}}{ds}\right\Vert =\frac{\frac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}}}{\left[1+\left(\frac{dy}{dx}\right)^{2}\right]^{\frac{3}{2}}}
\end{align*}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where, 
\begin_inset Formula $R$
\end_inset

 is the Radius of Curvature, which is the reciprocal of the measure of curvature
, 
\begin_inset Formula $C=\frac{1}{R}$
\end_inset

, and 
\begin_inset Formula $s$
\end_inset

 is the path length.
 Here, since we obtained the coordinates of the points of the streamline
 path, we choose the formula 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{align*}
R & =\left[\left(\frac{\partial^{2}x}{\partial s^{2}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\partial^{2}y}{\partial s^{2}}\right)^{2}\right]^{-\frac{1}{2}}
\end{align*}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where, 
\begin_inset Formula $ds$
\end_inset

 is the differential arc length computed as the first order gradient of
 flow path-length obtained by cumulative sum of the individual Runge-Kutta
 integrated steps for the path-length.
 The numerical computation of the local Radius of Curvature as a function
 of the streamwise location on the shear layer for the standard geometry
 is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:localcurvature"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The calculation of gradients is particularly noisy for the calculation
 of the second order derivative along the streamline due to the interpolation
 and hence an additional averaging is applied using a moving window for
 the calculation of curvature.
 This averaging, with a window size of 100 points, reduces the numerical
 noise and delivers a smoother calculation in the early shear layer and
 also in the downstream where the mean velocity field is less converged
 due to the low frequency oscillations of the cove flow.
 For calculations using the second order gradient we report only the smoothed
 version of the obtained quantities.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement H
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter11/SGP079_curvr_corrected.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 12cm
	height 12cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Local curvature along a streamline in the shear layer 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:localcurvature"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\end_layout

\end_inset

The measure of curvature is the inverse of the Radius of Curvature, R.
 The shear layer shape necessarily follows a path whose mean curvature is
 of the same order as that of the slat chord thereby suggesting a mean curvature
 around 
\begin_inset Formula $2/C_{s}=51.28\,m^{-1}$
\end_inset

 or higher.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
At the impingement location, the mean streamline can have two trajectories,
 one into the recirculation zone, and the other towards the ejection through
 slat gap.
 The streamline which enters the recirculation zone is sharply curved as
 seen in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:shearlayercurvature"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and is the region of highest curvature.
 The streamline then exits through the slat gap has a smaller curvature
 than the other.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
This region, according to 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, also has a low velocity flow in the concave side of the curvature unlike
 the early part of the shear layer, making it a region of unstable curvature
 configuration.
 This region is hence susceptible to the centrifugal instability led modes
 which primarily has the effect of generating streamwise vortices.
 In the cove flow case, the spanwise eddies formed are well-known to degenerate
 in their spanwise coherence in this region and the flow consists majorly
 of streamwise oriented structures prior to the impingement at the slat
 trailing edge.
 See Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:SpanwiseRollers-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:IsoQcrit-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 for visualization of the vortex dynamics using iso-contours of Q-criterion.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
To investigate the streamline for related parameters, the first parameter
 of interest is the time-averaged streamwise deceleration.
 This can be computed from the mean velocity field along the streamline
 as 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\[
D=-V\frac{dV}{ds}
\]

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where, V is the streamwise velocity magnitude.
 Here the velocity magnitude is taken to be 
\begin_inset Formula $V=\sqrt{U_{X}^{2}+U_{Y}^{2}}$
\end_inset

 where 
\begin_inset Formula $X$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $Y$
\end_inset

 are the in-plane velocity components for the streamline.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tb
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter11/SGP079_dec.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 8.3cm
	height 8.3cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:localdeceleration"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter11/SGP079_thesis.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 7.5cm
	height 7.5cm
	keepAspectRatio
	BoundingBox 150bp 100bp 1460bp 1060bp
	clip

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:locationmaxdeceleration"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
a) Local deceleration along a streamline in the shear layer and the location
 of its maximum.
 The numerical noise in the early and later regions arise from the numerical
 differentiation of the interpolated velocity field.
 Local fluctuations are also present in the velocity field due to the effect
 of low frequency oscillations not sufficiently averaged out within 5 chord
 pass times.
 b) Location of the impingement location within the flow field.
 A representative color map is used to indicate the background flow velocity
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Local-deceleration"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Local deceleration and location of the impingement within the flow field
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
As shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Local-deceleration"

\end_inset

, the deceleration on the streamline is far from uniform.
 The flow is first accelerated along the streamline in the initial region
 of the vortex shedding and as the streamline curvature decreases in the
 intermediate region, the flow is accelerated.
 Before the impingement near the wall, the stagnation causes a region of
 strong deceleration.
 This stagnation of the mean flow generates the necessary pressure gradient
 required to counter act the centrifugal force generated by the curvature
 of the flow.
 However, when the angular momentum decreases radially across the streamlines,
 the centrifugal force can be in excess of the established pressure gradient.
 This imbalance is the cause for the centrifugal instability.
 These perturbations then allow exchange of momentum along the radial direction
 by the transport of fluid thereby balancing the deficit in the pressure
 gradient to counteract the centrifugal force.
 This rapid generation of streamwise vortices is also enhanced by the degenerati
on of spanwise coherent vortices which have already entrained a portion
 of the recirculating streamwise vortices.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The location of maximum deceleration relative to the flow geometry is marked
 in Fig.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:locationmaxdeceleration"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The position is not exactly on the slat trailing edge but slightly upstream,
 the exact location being dependent on the choice of streamline.
 Nevertheless, the marked position is the location of the maximum deceleration
 experienced by a fluid particle moving along the streamline and is hence
 the location of maximum momentum transfer.
 In view of the theory that impingement of vortices is responsible for the
 generation of acoustic waves that modulate the K-H shedding frequency at
 the cusp and thereby select the tonal noise frequency, this location must
 correspond to the length of the shear layer that predicts the tonal noise
 frequency.
 To understand this further we look at the actual velocity distribution
 along the streamline and compute the time of travel.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The time required for the spanwise eddy to reach the location of maximum
 deceleration can be obtained as 
\begin_inset Formula $t_{S}=\int^{S}\frac{ds}{V(s)}$
\end_inset

.
 The total time is then obtained as sum of 
\begin_inset Formula $t_{S}$
\end_inset

 and the acoustic propagation time from the location of impingement to the
 source point of the streamline.
 This calculation leads to total time of 
\begin_inset Formula $1.213ms$
\end_inset

 corresponding to a frequency of 
\begin_inset Formula $824Hz$
\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
To compare this frequency to the theoretical model, the tone prediction
 formula of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 has the simplified form 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\[
f_{n}=n\frac{U_{\infty}}{L_{a}}\cdot\frac{1}{\mathcal{M}+\frac{\alpha_{l}}{\kappa_{v}}}
\]

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where, 
\begin_inset Formula $L_{a}$
\end_inset

 is the acoustic path length, 
\begin_inset Formula $\alpha_{l}$
\end_inset

 is the ratio of length of the shear layer to the acoustic path between
 the impingement location and the cusp and 
\begin_inset Formula $\kappa_{v}$
\end_inset

 is the ratio of vortex convection velocity of vortices along the shear
 layer to the free stream velocity.
 Here, the vortex convection velocity is not calculable from a mean flow
 solution and for our study we resort to the value obtained for the same
 case by Terracol et al., i.e.
 
\begin_inset Formula $\kappa_{v}=0.79$
\end_inset

.
 Based on the location of maximum deceleration, the acoustic path length
 is obtained as 
\begin_inset Formula $L_{a}=0.0326m$
\end_inset

, and the vortex path length along the shear layer as 
\begin_inset Formula $L_{v}=0.0387m$
\end_inset

, leading to 
\begin_inset Formula $\alpha_{l}=1.187$
\end_inset

.
 The resulting fundamental tone corresponding to 
\begin_inset Formula $n=1$
\end_inset

, is then at 
\begin_inset Formula $f_{1}=928Hz$
\end_inset

 and the multiples being 
\begin_inset Formula $[1856,2784,3712,4640,\text{ and }5568]$
\end_inset

 Hz.
 These frequencies are higher than the experimental tone frequencies 
\begin_inset Formula $[1771,2655,3540,4425,\text{ and }5310]$
\end_inset

, and hence suggest that the location of maximum deceleration is a location
 slightly too early than the actual location of the acoustic generation.
 However, 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

's formula is highly sensitive to the computation of the shear layer path
 length, and hence on the location of the acoustic generation, lending high
 level of uncertainity in the tone calculation using this method.
 Moreover, for the same calculation, a correction of the convection velocity
 factor to 
\begin_inset Formula $\kappa_{v}=0.75$
\end_inset

 can lead to a more accurate prediction of the frequencies.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Now we inspect the curvature of the streamline further, more in line with
 work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bradshaw1969"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 His analogy of the streamline curvature with a stratified flow under the
 effect of buoyancy led to formulation of representative parameters.
 One of these, pertinent to interpretation of the slat shear layer, is the
 flux Richardson number.
 By the analogy, for flow along a curved streamline, it is the ratio of
 turbulent kinetic energy production between the radial direction and the
 streamwise direction, i.e.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\[
R_{f}=-\frac{\text{extra \ensuremath{v^{2}} production}}{\text{sum of \ensuremath{u} and \ensuremath{w^{2}} production}}
\]

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where, 
\begin_inset Formula $\bar{u}$
\end_inset

 is conventionally the streamwise velocity, 
\begin_inset Formula $\bar{v}$
\end_inset

 is the velocity in the cross-stream direction across the streamlines, and
 
\begin_inset Formula $\bar{w}$
\end_inset

 is the spanwise velocity.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bradshaw2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 obtain a form of the flux Richardson number inspired from the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Wyngaard1967"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, as
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\begin{equation}
R_{f}=\frac{2\frac{U}{R}}{\frac{\partial U}{\partial R}+\frac{U}{R}}=\frac{2U}{\frac{\partial}{\partial R}(UR)}\label{eq:curvatureRich}
\end{equation}

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
This form was then re-derived later by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 while studying the stability of curved free shear layers in small curvature
 regime.
 The generation of vorticity in the streamwise direction, in their perspective,
 is an effect of the diffusion of the turbulent velocity perturbation into
 the streamwise direction led by the effect of the centrifugal force and
 hence arises from the requirement of inviscid stability.
 The flux Richardson number aids in quantifying the effect of this imposed
 vorticity transfer by taking into account the effect of the centrifugal
 force acting on the flow and also the local vorticity thickness by incorporatin
g the radial streamwise-velocity gradient 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{\partial U}{\partial n}$
\end_inset

.
 In this regard, we extrapolate the existing perspective as follows:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
It is well understood from the literature that the streamline curvature
 along a shear layer can lead to additional instability arising from the
 centrifugal effects.
 This leads to the generation of streamwise vortices across a wide range
 of Reynolds numbers.
 The effect of curvature is such that there is a generation of streamwise
 vorticity which is cumulative in the sense that this accumulation of streamwise
 vorticity happens as long as the Rayleigh criteria holds, i.e.
 with a reduction of the angular momentum radially outward from the center
 of curvature.
 The cumulative effect of this curvature can be captured by the total transfer
 of momentum due to the additional centrifugal force in action, or as the
 work done by the same.
 The instantaneous momentum transfer, 
\begin_inset Formula $M_{c}$
\end_inset

, effected by the centrifugal force while the fluid traverses a curved path
 
\begin_inset Formula $ds$
\end_inset

 with a local radius of curvature 
\begin_inset Formula $R$
\end_inset

, traversing with a streamwise velocity 
\begin_inset Formula $U$
\end_inset

, is equivalent to 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\[
d\Theta_{c}=\frac{U^{2}}{R}\frac{ds}{U}=\frac{U}{R}ds
\]

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where, 
\begin_inset Formula $U$
\end_inset

 is the velocity component along the streamline, and in the vectorial sense
 of the centrifugal force, the direction of this momentum transfer is invariant
 as the direction radially outward from the center of curvature.
 The resulting term 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{U}{R}$
\end_inset

 is hence the effective density of total momentum transfer due to the centrifuga
l force along the path length.
 Thus the curvature Richardson number of the form in Eq.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "eq:curvatureRich"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 effectively capture the effect of the centrifugal force in its momentum
 transfer leading to the generation of streamwise vorticity.
 The same term is used in the curvature Richardson number together with
 the cross-stream velocity gradient, 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{\partial U}{\partial R}$
\end_inset

.
 In case that the shear layer has a strong velocity gradient such that 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{\partial U}{\partial R}>>\frac{U}{R}$
\end_inset

, as in the early part of the slat shear layer, or in the case of a plane
 shear layer, the curvature Richardson number approaches zero.
 However, in the region where the shear layer weakens, and the curvature
 is finite such that 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{\partial U}{\partial R}<<\frac{U}{R}$
\end_inset

, the curvature Richardson number will tend to increase and saturate at
 2.
 For the case of applying the linearized equations to study effects of a
 slightly curved free shear layers, 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 used a Richardson number of the order of 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{-2}$
\end_inset

.
 However, for the case of slat shear layer, the curvatures are atleast two
 order of magnitude higher and hence is expected to be highly non-linear
 in its dynamics.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The computation of curvature Richardson number requires to calculate the
 strain rate, 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{\partial U}{\partial R}$
\end_inset

.
 For this we obtain the normals of the streamline on each point of the streamlin
e using a constant cell size.
 An over-resolution of 
\begin_inset Formula $2.5\times10^{-5}m$
\end_inset

 is maintained to avoid numerical discrepancies.
 A subsample of the streamline normals along the length of the streamline
 is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:locationstreamnormals"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and the computed 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{\partial U}{\partial R}$
\end_inset

 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:localdu_dn"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 .
 As can be seen, the initial values of 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{\partial U}{\partial R}$
\end_inset

 near the slat cusp has an order of magnitude of 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{4}$
\end_inset

 which reduces downstream due to the shear layer spreading.
 Streamwise locations after the streamline enters the recirculation is noisy
 again due to the low frequency oscillations of the cove requiring longer
 averaging time to be averaged out.
 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
placement t
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter11/SGP079_du_dn.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 8cm
	height 8cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:localdu_dn"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter11/SGP079.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 7cm
	height 7cm
	keepAspectRatio
	BoundingBox 150bp 100bp 1460bp 1060bp
	clip

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:locationstreamnormals"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
a) Local deceleration along a streamline in the shear layer and the location
 of maximum.
 The numerical noise in the early and later regions arise from the numerical
 differentiation of the interpolated velocity field.
 Local fluctuations are also present in the velocity field due to the effect
 of low frequency oscillations not sufficiently averaged out within 5 chord
 pass times.
 b) Location of the impingement location within the flow field.
 A representative colourmap is used to indicate the background flow velocity.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement H
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter11/SGP079_richardson.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 11cm
	height 11cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Local curvature along a streamline in the shear layer 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:localcurvaturerichardson"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The local curvature Richardson number along the streamline is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:localcurvaturerichardson"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The Richardson number can be seen to have a low value in the early shear
 layer due to the high value for the strain rate.
 As the shear layer spreads, the curvature Richardson number tends to increase,
 suggesting the strong momentum transfer due to the centrifugal force.
 In the mid-region, the curvature reduces as the shear layer inverts its
 direction of the curvature towards the unstable configuration, and the
 Richardson number hence drops.
 Afterwards, the curvature Richardson number increases as the shear layer
 spreads due to growth of the spanwise eddies along with entertainment of
 streamwise vortices.
 The curvature Richardson number then tend to saturate towards 2 in the
 region immediately downstream of the location of maximum deceleration,
 owing to the large value of curvature.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The case considered here is the standard geometry with standard position
 of the slat with respect to the airfoil.
 This configuration showed strong presence of the broadband acoustic spectra
 and tonal noise owing to the fact that the spanwise coherence of the shed
 vortices from slat cusp is not fully disintegrated by the time of their
 travel towards the trailing edge.
 This owes to the fact that the curvature Richardson number rises to a strong
 value only near and downstream of the location of maximum deceleration
 suggesting that the flow did not accrue a large enough effect of the centrifuga
l destabilization, as it would have been the case if the flow developed
 a larger curvature Richardson number further upstream of the impingement
 location.
 This means that although the effect of centrifugal instability is substantial
 in generating the streamwise turbulence, it is not sufficient to cause
 a complete degeneration of spanwise coherence to disable the aeroacoustic
 resonance.
 
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Nevertheless, in the vicinity of the impingement location, the process of
 spanwise decoherence must be strongly dominated by the collision processes
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
This means that the momentum transfer due to centrifugal force is weaker
 in this particular case when compared to cases whose slat positioning enables
 a higher distribution of Richardson number throughout the shear layer.
 This fact is reflected in the distribution of the curvature Richardson
 in Fig.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:localcurvaturerichardson"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, since its value is typically low in the region of the early shear layer.
 The flow is also stable towards centrifugal instability due to the stable
 configuration of increasing angular momentum along the radius of curvature.
 The curvature Richardson number rises to a strong value only near and downstrea
m of the location of maximum deceleration suggesting that the flow did not
 accrue largely the effect of the centrifugal force, as it would have been
 the case if the flow developed a larger curvature Richardson number further
 upstream of the impingement location.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
That being said, we now define a non-dimensional quantity that allows us
 to compare the effect of curvature for any given geometry of the slat shear
 layer, based only on the shear layer shape and mean flow distribution.
 For this we use a cumulative integral of the Richardson number along the
 shear layer, which can be formally written as 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Formula 
\[
M^{*}(l)=\int_{0}^{l}Ri_{f}ds
\]

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
where, 
\begin_inset Formula $l$
\end_inset

 is the length along the streamline through the shear layer.
 For the given standard case, the cumulative curvature Richardson number
 as a function of the shear layer path length is shown in Fig.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:cumulativecurvaturerichardson"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 For the given case, the cumulative Richardson number is at a value of approxima
tely 0.005 at the location of maximum deceleration.
 The accrual of Richardson number above this value sharply increases in
 the region downstream of location of maximum deceleration and it rises
 to 0.01 suggesting strong generation of the streamwise structures arising
 from the centrifugal effect.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
There are two things worth mentioning with regard to analyzing the curvature
 effect in this manner:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
First is that in the volume of region after the impingement, the effect
 of curvature instability is obviously large across the slat gap.
 However, this region is not only influenced by the curvature but by the
 effect of impingement itself.
 The effect of the latter towards the decoherence process can be assumed
 to be stronger given that it generates strong aerodynamic pressure fluctuations
 and vorticity generation.
 Hence it is not useful to use the curvature Richardson number after the
 location of maximum deceleration.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The second is that the effect of curvature is obviously substantial.
 Hence the same can be used to qualitatively understand how the noise efficiency
 will change when shape of the shear layer changes.
 However, this is useful only if the impingement location is sufficiently
 close to the trailing edge with the shear layer shape upstream of impingement
 has variations.
 In such a case, a slower accrual of the curvature Richardson number can
 lead to a higher spanwise coherence of the spanwise eddies responsible
 for exciting the Rossiter mechanism and hence can deliver a strong resonance
 leading to noisy operation.
 In cases with an early impingement, as in the case considered by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Souza2019"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 where they used a plug on the slat wall to cause variations in shear layer
 shape, the spanwise coherence will degenerate regardless of the curvature
 effects leading to reduced noise efficiency.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
That being said, before moving to a parametric analysis, let us look into
 the acoustics data available from the simulation in detail.
 We do not reiterate the far-field data obtained using FWH computation but
 the data from unsteady density in the vicinity of the cove.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
placement H
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter11/SGP079_cumulative_richardson.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 11cm
	height 11cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Cumulative curvature Richardson number as a function of the slat shear layer
 path length along a streamline 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:cumulativecurvaturerichardson"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
Acoustics
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Acoustic perturbations are essentially perturbations of the pressure field
 arising from compressibilty and translate to equivalent density perturbations.
 By the continuity equation, the density perturbation can be written in
 terms of the divergence of the velocity field as
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\[
\Theta=-\frac{1}{\bar{\rho}}\frac{D\rho}{Dt}=\nabla\cdot\mathbf{u}
\]

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where, 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{D}{Dt}=\frac{\partial}{\partial t}+\mathbf{u}\cdot\nabla$
\end_inset

 represents the material derivative and 
\begin_inset Formula $\Theta$
\end_inset

 is called the dilatation field
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Ribner1964"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Within turbulent flows, the dilatation field has two components due to
 the hydrodynamic and acoustic fluctuations.
 The former are large magnitude perturbations that witness slight hydrodynamic
 compressibilty that might contribute or not to sound radiation whereas
 the latter are small magnitude perturbations that represents the propagation
 of sound.
 Although vastly differing in their order of magnitudes, separating the
 two is still a non-trivial procedure
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Ewert2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 But the emanating acoustic wave fronts can be identified in the region
 outside the turbulent region where sound generation is absent.
 The typical dilatation field around the HLD as obtained from the unsteady
 simulation is shown on the snapshot of Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Dilatation"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The wave fronts emitted from the slat cove are identifiable from the dilatation
 field towards both the suction side and the pressure side, latter being
 towards the ground observer.
 The major acoustic source region can be identified as the slat cove and
 the trailing edge of the main-element.
 The trailing edge of this HLD, must be recalled, is obtained by replacing
 a TE flap in order to reduce lift
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Hence the noise generation from the trailing edge is not covered in our
 study since it is found to have no interference with the slat cove acoustics.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement h
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter09_figs/Dilatation.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 14cm
	height 14cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Dilatation field over the HLD from the unsteady data
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Dilatation"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The slat cove radiation can be noticed to have characteristic directivity
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Choudhari2017"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The radiation towards the pressure side is seen to radiate from the region
 close to the slat gap, and for the radiation to the suction side, the source
 appears to be located within the slat cove.
 There also exist a region with acoustic shadow in the upstream of the slat
 since the geometry shadows the radiation unless the wave number is small
 enough to enable diffraction.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The dilatation field also has drawbacks visualizing data on the grids with
 refinement interfaces.
 At the refinement interface, the calculation of derivative introduces numerical
 errors, which are not necessarily unsteady.
 Hence the errors does not necessarily lead to generation of spurious acoustics
 but vitiates the acoustic field visualization.
 An improvement in this regard is hence possible by using an alternative
 definition for dilatation as the density rate.
 For isentropic fluctuations of small amplitudes in an otherwise quiescent
 media, the dilatation can be expressed as the rate of pressure fluctuation
 as 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Formula 
\[
\ensuremath{\Theta=-\frac{1}{\rho_{0}}\frac{\partial P}{\partial t}}
\]

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where, 
\begin_inset Formula $\rho_{0}$
\end_inset

 is the ambient mean density.
 The pressure rate being a temporal derivative also removes its local steady
 component.
 
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
For this, assuming that in the farfield, only linear acoustic perturbations
 are dominant, the material derivative is reduced to the temporal derivative,
 i.e.
 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{D\rho}{Dt}\approx\frac{\partial\rho}{\partial t}$
\end_inset

.
 
\end_layout

\end_inset

A visualization of the density rate field in the slat cove vicinity is shown
 in Fig.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:DensityRate-1"

\end_inset

.
 The acoustic field thus visualized shows majorly high frequency wavefronts
 which have an approximate wavelength of 
\begin_inset Formula $\lambda=0.008\,m$
\end_inset

.
 This corresponds to acoustic waves of frequency higher than 
\begin_inset Formula $50\,kHz$
\end_inset

.
 It hence suggests that the wavefronts visible in this visualization are
 also strongly vitiated by the high frequency numerical noise which are
 amplified by the temporal derivative.
 
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The source of this very high frequency noise is suspected to be from the
 mesh refinement applied to the region downstream of the slat trailing edge.
 A visualization of the mesh along with the dilatation field in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:DensityRateMesh-1"

\end_inset

 illustrates this fact.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tb
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter10/SGP079/DensityRateVisualisation.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 11cm
	height 11cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Perturbations near slat TE show upstream traveling wave number components.
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:DensityRate-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure

sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter09_figs/mesh_ refinement.png
	lyxscale 20

	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

 problem is aggravated.
 See the work of

\end_inset

 for a detailed account of the issues.

\end_inset

 a refinement region downstream of the trailing edge.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Unsteady pressure field visualized using density rate 
\begin_inset Formula $-\frac{1}{\rho}\frac{d\rho}{dt}$
\end_inset

 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Filtered pressure fields
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
To study the acoustic modes of particular frequency, the unsteady pressure
 fields can be subjected to Fourier filtering.
 For this we choose to apply the filter for the pressure field on a 2D plane
 recording around the slat cove region for frequencies corresponding to
 the broadband hump at the 
\begin_inset Formula $885\,Hz$
\end_inset

, and the tonal peaks at 
\begin_inset Formula $1771,$
\end_inset

 
\begin_inset Formula $2655,$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $3540\,Hz$
\end_inset

.
 The Fourier transform and corresponding inverse transform at single frequencies
 were done using the python package NumPy.
 The visualization of the filtered fields are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:filteredpressure"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The left side plots highlight the hydrodynamic pressure fluctuation at
 the select frequency inside the cove region, and right side plots highlight
 the acoustic field around the HLD over a larger domain.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tbp
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter10/SGP079/FilterPressure_885Hz/FilteredPressure885Hz2_1.png
	lyxscale 15
	width 7.5cm

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The Fourier filtered pressure fields at a select frequencies corresponding
 to the peaks in farfield spectra.
 The visualization is for a spanwise central plane, and the streamline along
 which the vortex path is extracted from mean flow is shown as green line
 and corresponding wavelengths for the traveling waves are also annotated
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:filteredpressure"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The Fourier filtered pressure fields at a select frequencies corresponding
 to the peaks in farfield spectra
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
From observing the dynamics of the filtered fields, the following observations
 can be made:
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Enumerate
The filtered field corresponding to 
\begin_inset Formula $885Hz$
\end_inset

 has two dominant lobes near the impingement location as shown in Fig.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:filterpressure885"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 This is the location of maximum curvature where the streamline curves into
 the recirculation region.
 The two lobes on the either side of the location of impingement has opposite
 polarity and are coupled in their dynamics.
 The node between the two lobes appear to have a stationary location unlike
 a traveling wave for other frequencies.
 This suggest that this mode is not generated by the impinging vortices
 convected by the shear layer, but rather by a feature of the flow dynamics
 that is local to the impingement location.
 This is hence reasoned to be the low frequency steady mode fluctuation,
 as part of the steady spanwise mode found in the mean velocity fields,
 driven by the effect of strong curvature of the streamlines.
 Moreover, the opposing polarity of the two lobes suggest that there exists
 a strong oscillating pressure gradient.
 This pressure gradient leads to oscillation of the impingement location
 of the shear layer leading to a closing and opening of the cavity, which
 is enclosed by the shear layer on one side and the curved slat wall on
 the other side.
 Such an effect drives the fluctuation of the larger hydrodynamic pressure
 mode inside the cavity and due to the amplitude of oscillation will influence
 the vortex shedding frequency leading to a selection of common oscillating
 frequency between them.
 This process can hence be suspected to largely influence the frequency
 selection of the resonance frequencies, in addition to the Rossiter mechanism.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
Dynamics corresponding to frequencies of other tones show similarities between
 them as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:filterpressure1771"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:filterpressure2655"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:filterpressure3540"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The tonal frequency reveal that they are traveling waves along the shear
 layer with the lowest frequency having the largest lobes.
 For higher frequencies, the lobes grow smaller, however traverses with
 a constant convection velocity of approximately 
\begin_inset Formula $23 m/sm/s$
\end_inset

.
 These are hence attributed to the large scale spanwise coherent structures
 convected along the shear layer inducing their traveling pressure fields
 on to the flow.
 The impingement location instead of having lobes separated by the impingement
 location, have shapes aligned with the ejected streamline.
 These lobes are however present in pairs arranged along the cross flow
 direction suggesting that the mode of fluctuation induce motion of the
 ejected fluid normal to the slat trailing edge wall, and normal to the
 mean streamlines.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
The dynamics of acoustic waves can also be noted to be strongly coupled
 with large amplitude hydrodynamic oscillations.
 For all frequencies visualized, the acoustic fluctuations near the slat
 trailing edge is notably synchronized with pressure fluctuations of the
 impingement dynamics.
 The radiated wavefronts upstream of slat trailing edge outside the cove
 also have their center precisely at the slat trailing edge.
 For the case of 
\begin_inset Formula $885Hz$
\end_inset

, the center of radiation is more ambiguous due to the fact that the wavelength
 at this frequency is 
\begin_inset Formula $0.38m$
\end_inset

, roughly one order of magnitude higher than the slat chord.
 Hence this tone, along with the other characteristics tones less than approxima
tely 
\begin_inset Formula $9 kHzkHz$
\end_inset

, cannot form a standing wave in the 2D plane of slat cove flow between
 the slat trailing edge and cusp.
 Consequently, the only standing wave possible in the low frequency range
 is the spanwise direction.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
The tonal wavefronts for the higher frequencies are notably centered at
 the slat trailing edge with a directivity normal to the tangent of the
 upper wall.
 The trailing edge of the VALIANT geometry has a thickness of 
\begin_inset Formula $1.7mm$
\end_inset

 and is hence not exactly a pointed edge as in the case of the cusp.
 The directivity of the lobe agrees well with the observations in the literature
 that the tonal directivities follow dipole behavior, with the axis of the
 dipole normal to the slat wall at trailing edge.
 However, this is only an approximation since only the upper lobe at the
 trailing edge can radiate to the farfield and the lower lobe is partly
 reflected and partly shielded by the presence of the main element.
 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
The hydrodynamic pressure in the slat cove for all tone frequencies of 
\begin_inset Formula $1771\,Hz$
\end_inset

 and above extracted shows a spatially growing wave along the shear layer.
 These waves represent the pressure fluctuation induced by the convected
 vorticity generated near the cusp.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
The dynamic visualization of impingement of these spatial waves on the trailing
 edge suggest that they are in-phase with the acoustic source for corresponding
 frequency near the trailing edge for the tones at 
\begin_inset Formula $1771\,Hz$
\end_inset

 and above.
 This re-validates the fact that impingement of vortices are responsible
 for the acoustic wave generation and subsequent Rossiter mechanism.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
The hydrodynamic oscillation at the slat TE for 
\begin_inset Formula $885\,Hz$
\end_inset

 shows persistent elongated lobes along the shedding direction.
 These lobes represent pressure fluctuations that due to the vortex shedding
 and is responsible for the flapping motion of the shear layer at the slat
 TE.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
Spanwise Trends in Wall Pressure Data 
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Spanwise Trends 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement th
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter10/SGP079/Wall_Pressure_prob locations.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 6cm
	height 6cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:wp_coords-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter09_figs/spanwiseprobes_replica.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 8.2cm
	height 8.2cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Spanwise-replicated-numerical_loc-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
a) Select wall pressure probe coordinates on the slat.
 b) Spanwise replicated numerical probes and the slat geometry.
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Wall pressure probe locations and their spanwise replications with respect
 to the slat geometry.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The wall pressure probes used to record the unsteady pressure fields in
 the simulation are analyzed next with the particular aim to study their
 spanwise behavior.
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
For this, the pressure field is sampled at a rate of 
\begin_inset Formula $180405\,Hz$
\end_inset

, allowing to obtain the spectra upto 
\begin_inset Formula $90\,kHz$
\end_inset

 by the Nyquist criteria
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Nyquist1928,Shannon"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The probes are activated for the full length of the simulation to monitor
 convergence and only the part of signals after convergence are subjected
 to power spectral density calculation.
 The raw pressure signals from the probes are given in Appendix A.
 For the power spectral density calculation using Welsch method, we select
 a total of 
\begin_inset Formula $41000$
\end_inset

 steps and a window size of 
\begin_inset Formula $8200$
\end_inset

 steps with an overlap of 
\begin_inset Formula $50%\ensuremath{\%}
$
\end_inset

.
 This leads to a total of 
\begin_inset Formula $9$
\end_inset

 averaging windows and a linear trend line is used to remove the mean from
 each window to obtain the fluctuating component of the pressure.
 The PSD is then obtained with a resolution of 
\begin_inset Formula $22\,Hz$
\end_inset

.
 The locations of the probe along the spanwise center plane and their correspond
ing wall pressure spectra are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:wp_spectras_slat"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 for the slat wall and in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:wp_spectras-mainelement"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, and 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:wp_spectras_mainelement2"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 for the main element.
 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
From analyzing the data, the recordings from probes on the leading edge
 of the slat shows strong similarity with the far-field acoustic spectra.
 Probes 1, 3, and 5, shows the the first main tone at 
\begin_inset Formula $1771\,Hz$
\end_inset

 although with less sharpness than the second tone at 
\begin_inset Formula $2655\,Hz$
\end_inset

.
 The second and third tones are prominent and a steady decay for the higher
 frequencies are noted.
 Due to absence of a developed boundary layer or incoming turbulence, this
 pressure field is the incident acoustic field recorded by the wall pressure
 sensors.
 The same behavior can also be noted for probes 14, 16, 19, and 20, moving
 progressively from the trailing edge to the cove region on the pressure
 side of the main element.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
For probes inside the slat cove, namely, Probe 6, 8, 10, and 11, the obtained
 spectra shows a progressive behavior.
 The spectra for Probe 6 which is close to the slat cusp shows the second
 tonal peak at 
\begin_inset Formula $2655\,Hz$
\end_inset

 as the dominant tone and the first tone at 
\begin_inset Formula $1771\,Hz$
\end_inset

 is shadowed by the low frequency fluctuations arising from the behavior
 of cove motion.
 This drowning of the tonal oscillations increases progressively towards
 the slat cusp, and for Probe 
\begin_inset Formula $11$
\end_inset

, the tones are completely dominated by steady noise from the impinging
 vortex structures.
 The overall low frequency noise below 
\begin_inset Formula $885\,Hz$
\end_inset

 also increases obscuring the hump at this frequency corresponding to the
 first Rossiter mode.
\end_layout

\end_inset

status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Wall pressure spectra for select probes on the main element wall and on
 spanwise center plane.
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:wp_spectras_mainelement2"

\end_inset

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset

 The very low frequency oscillations inside the cove are suspected to be
 the result of the modes induced by centrifugal modes which are also accompanied
 by the spanwise cell formations.
 To understand this further, plots of the spectra along the spanwise direction
 is given in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwisespectra_probe6_7_8_9"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 for probes 
\begin_inset Formula $6$
\end_inset

, 
\begin_inset Formula $7$
\end_inset

, 
\begin_inset Formula $8$
\end_inset

, 
\begin_inset Formula $9$
\end_inset

, 
\begin_inset Formula $10$
\end_inset

, and 
\begin_inset Formula $13$
\end_inset

 from Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:wp_coords-1"

\end_inset

.
 Each of these probes are replicated along the spanwise direction as illustrated
 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Spanwise-replicated-numerical_loc-1"

\end_inset

 and a function spectra is plotted as function of the spanwise coordinate.
 The mean pressure from these probes for the computed PSD are also shown
 on the right side to shed light on the correspondence between the spanwise
 trend of spectra and spanwise cell formations.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Wall pressure spectra from spanwise replicas of probes on spanwise center
 plane showing variation of spectra along the span.
 Corresponding time-averaged pressure for the probe recording is also shown
 to identify the spanwise cell locations 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:spanwisespectra_probe6_7_8_9"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Wall pressure spectra from spanwise replicas of probes on spanwise center
 plane showing variation of spectra along the span
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
From inspection of data of Probe 6 and its replicates, as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:probe6wallpressure"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, it can be noted that the spanwise modulations are reproduced in the low
 frequency part of the spectra particularly above 
\begin_inset Formula $200\,Hz$
\end_inset

 and below 
\begin_inset Formula $1000\,Hz$
\end_inset

.
 The spectra in this region tends to 
\begin_inset ERT
status open
\begin_layout Plain Layout
\backslash textcolor{red}{have stronger levels}
\end_layout
\end_inset
 for spanwise
 locations that correspond to pressure locations which are at the diverging
 plane of the spanwise velocity field.
 Probe 6 location being close to the slat cusp with spanwise modulation
 at low frequency verifies the hypothesis that spanwise nodal planes are
 stronger and driven by the initial curvature of the shear layer.
 It also further suggests that there are low frequency fluctuations particularly
 associated with such planes.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
For other probes, namely Probe 
\begin_inset Formula $7$
\end_inset

 which is adjacent to Probe 
\begin_inset Formula $6$
\end_inset

, but deeper into the cove from the slat cusp, the spanwise modulation in
 the wall pressure spectra becomes less pronounced.
 This is expected from the shape of the spanwise velocity contours which
 shows that the cells near the slat cusp region is closer to the shear layer
 than the wall and also transition to the upper chain of cells as we move
 along the inner wall of the slat.
 The modulation again gather strength for Probe 
\begin_inset Formula $8$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $9$
\end_inset

, also with a lowering of the low frequency contents.
 As we move further towards the impingement location with Probe 
\begin_inset Formula $10$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $13$
\end_inset

, the low frequency contents again becomes dominant due to the possible
 contribution from low frequency fluctuations associated with strongly curved
 flow at the impingement location.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Apart from the spanwise modulated behavior, the presence of the tones at
 
\begin_inset Formula $1771,$
\end_inset

 
\begin_inset Formula $2655,$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $3450\,Hz$
\end_inset

 can be seen to be present irrespective of the spanwise location.
 The first tonal peak at 
\begin_inset Formula $1771\,Hz$
\end_inset

 however seems to be more susceptible to the spanwise modulations particularly
 for Probes 
\begin_inset Formula $8$
\end_inset

, 
\begin_inset Formula $9$
\end_inset

, and 
\begin_inset Formula $10$
\end_inset

.
 For the low frequency hump at 
\begin_inset Formula $885\,Hz$
\end_inset

, the wall pressure spectra is not able to provide a clear identification,
 although for probes outside the cove, namely Probe 
\begin_inset Formula $3$
\end_inset

, 
\begin_inset Formula $5$
\end_inset

, and 
\begin_inset Formula $19$
\end_inset

, this hump is distinctly identifiable.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The initial reduction of the low frequency fluctuations from Probe 
\begin_inset Formula $6$
\end_inset

, placed at the highly curved flow region near the cusp, to intermediate
 probes and then gaining strength towards the impingement location again
 with highly curved flow due to impingement suggest that these fluctuations
 could be the result of modes driven by the centrifugal instability.
 Another possible reason can be that the concave wall geometry acts as as
 a reflecting surface that leads to partial focusing of the reflected pressure
 waves near such locations.
 Furthermore, from Probe 
\begin_inset Formula $6$
\end_inset

 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:probe6wallpressure"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, it is clear that the flow near the cusp has spanwise modulated pressure
 oscillations around 
\begin_inset Formula $885\,Hz$
\end_inset

 corresponding to the low frequency hump in the far-field acoustic spectra.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Now, from the presence of converging and diverging planes of spanwise velocity,
 it is possible that the fluid accumulates at the converging plane and has
 to be redistributed to the diverging planes by a dynamic mechanism.
 We hence how hypothesize that it is the periodic bursting of the early
 shear layer at the diverging planes that leads to this redistribution of
 fluid and in this process results in hydrodynamic pressure oscillation
 eventually leading the radiation of acoustic waves at this frequency.
 This mechanism therefore must be the most pronounced in the hot-wire measuremen
ts at the slat cusp if a spanwise investigation is enabled.
 
\end_layout

\end_inset

We now proceed to inspect the numerical hot-wire probe data.
\end_layout

\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Time-averaged velocity and components from the SL probe file placed near
 slat cusp.
 P0 to P24 represent the 25 spanwise replication of the SL file and each
 curve represent the velocity profile as each spanwise location.
 a) The velocity magnitude profile is uniform along the span, b) The streamwise
 velocity is also uniform along the span, c) the cross-stream velocity in
 the 2D plane of the airfoil cross section is also largely uniform along
 the slap, and d) the spanwise component of velocity shows uniformity along
 the span but has a alternating profile inside the shear with an amplitude
 of 
\begin_inset Formula $\approx15\%$
\end_inset

 of the velocity magnitude.
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Time-averaged velocity and components from the SL probe file placed near
 slat cusp 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The hot-wire probe data allows to analyze single point time series recording
 of the flow velocity.
 The point recording captured from LBM simulation at selected nodes are
 hence analogous to the hot-wire measurements in the experiments and are
 typically used to compare the experiment and simulations.
 Here they are used to study spanwise variability of the flow.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Various groups of probes are used to obtain the velocity fields near the
 cusp, near the slat trailing edge, and on few select locations on the main
 element wall.
 We intend to call these probe groups as files and their positions are shown
 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:hotwireprobelocations"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 Among these we first analyze the file placed near the cusp across the early
 shear layer, capturing the variation of turbulent velocity field from outside
 of the cove flow to its interior.
 For this, first the mean velocity magnitude is plotted as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:averagehotwiseSLmag"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The time-averaged velocity magnitude profile shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:averagehotwiseSLmag"

\end_inset

 concurs with the mean inflow velocity of 
\begin_inset Formula $50 m/sm/s$
\end_inset

, and the deceleration due to presence of the main-element outside of the
 cove region.
 The mean recirculation velocity near the cusp is obtained as 
\begin_inset Formula $15 m/sm/s$
\end_inset

, which also concurs with Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:velocityacrossshearlayer"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 The velocity magnitude profiles are also largely spanwise invariant outside
 the cove and have a deviation of 
\begin_inset Formula $\pm5 m/sm/s$
\end_inset

 inside the recirculation.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The profiles for all velocity components are also shown.
 For the spanwise component shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:averagehotwireSLZvel"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, the region outside the cove region shows negligible variation whereas
 for the region inside the cove, the velocity switched signs with a peak
 amplitudes of 
\begin_inset Formula $7 m/sm/s$
\end_inset

, suggesting that the spanwise modulation is the main contributor to total
 velocity modulation along the span.
 The alternating averaged spanwise velocities correspond to the spanwise
 cells previously demonstrated in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Visualisation_planes-1"

\end_inset

 and is an additional characterization uncovering their structure.
\begin_inset Float figure
