\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Unsteady velocity spectra from spanwise replicas of probes close to slat
 cusp.
 Corresponding time-averaged spanwise velocity for the probe recording is
 also shown to identify the spanwise cell locations 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:hotwireSL_21_24"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Unsteady velocity spectra from spanwise replicas of probes close to slat
 cusp 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The modulated velocity spectra for the spanwise component 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{z}$
\end_inset

 are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:hotwireSL_0_14_15"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:hotwireSL_21_24"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 For the case of Probe 0 positioned outside the cove as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:hotwireprobelocations"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, the fluctuation related to tonal peaks in the acoustic spectra can be
 identified for 
\begin_inset Formula $1771Hz$
\end_inset

 and above.
 The low frequency hump at 
\begin_inset Formula $885Hz$
\end_inset

 is however absent.
 For probes 14 and higher, it can be noted that the spanwise velocity shows
 a consistent oscillation between 
\begin_inset Formula $200-300Hz$
\end_inset

 across multiple probe locations along the span.
 For Probe 14 and 15, shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:hotwireSLspanwise_P14"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:hotwireSLspanwise_P15"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, the peaks corresponding to acoustic frequencies are hardly distinguishable
 but instead hot spots for a frequency of 
\begin_inset Formula $200Hz$
\end_inset

 can be noticed.
 The hot spots appear strongest at spanwise location where the spanwise
 mean velocity switches sign from negative to positive suggesting that this
 location is a diverging plane.
 The periodic oscillations are interestingly absent in the locations of
 the converging planes where the fluid is removed from the spanwise motion
 potentially entrained by the shear layer.
 This suggest that redistribution mechanism arising from presence of nodal
 planes tend to develop a low frequency pulsating behavior with which the
 initial shear layer bursts periodically.
 This low frequency bursting is also consistent with the behavior identified
 by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 in the case of rectangular cavity flows.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Such a periodic bursting if present may affect the acoustics.
 Since the Rossiter mechanism is driven by the impingement of spanwise coherent
 vortices at the slat trailing edge, the retained spanwise coherence is
 a necessary factor for exciting a strong resonance.
 The periodic disruption of the spanwise coherence of the early vortices
 thereby affects the resulting acoustic tones through an amplitude modulation.
 Furthermore, for Probe 20, which is placed deeper into the cove inside
 the shear layer, the spectral content shows increased activity at the same
 frequency of 
\begin_inset Formula $200Hz$
\end_inset

.
 Here the averaged spanwise velocity modulation is also with a higher amplitude
 approximately 
\begin_inset Formula $7 m/sm/s$
\end_inset

, thereby having a higher power level for the low frequency fluctuations
 including 
\begin_inset Formula $200Hz$
\end_inset

.
 The higher energy levels at 
\begin_inset Formula $200Hz$
\end_inset

 for this location is clearly distinguishable from neighboring frequencies
 as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:hotwireSLspanwise_P20"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Additionally, the modulation of spanwise velocity biased towards the interior
 of the shear layer also agree with the hypothesis that this additional
 spanwise modulation and its associated low frequency fluctuations are predomina
ntly the effect of curvature, since it is known from the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 that for the case of a mildly curved shear layer, the spanwise eigen modes
 have predisposition to shift to the low velocity side of the shear layer.
 See Fig.9 in 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 for further clarity.
 Here the lower speed side correspond to the interior of the shear layer
 towards the center of recirculation.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
For Probes 20 and 21 shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:hotwireSLspanwise_P21"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:hotwireSLspanwise_P24"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, the spanwise modulation of the frequency range between 
\begin_inset Formula $700Hz$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $1000Hz$
\end_inset

 are also notable.
 This also suggest that there is a spanwise inhomogeneity in the hydrodynamic
 fluctuations at 
\begin_inset Formula $885Hz$
\end_inset

.
 However, this frequency is clearly the first Rossiter mode since it matches
 with the theoretically calculated first mode based on the vortex and acoustic
 travel times.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The Rossiter mechanism is a dominantly 2D phenomena and a 3D aspect can
 potentially disrupt its efficiency.
 Thus a variation of the oscillation amplitude of the hydrodynamic field
 across the span suggest that the first Rossiter mode can be destructively
 affected.
 This is in line with the fact that the first mode has a lower power levels
 in the farfield spectra and is often not obvious in the experimental studies
 where low frequency contents are polluted by the apparatus noise 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Manoha2012"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Upon discovery, this tone is found to be incoherent and characteristically
 intermittent
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "KamliyaJawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Moreover, the experimental studies assume that the flow in slat cove is
 dominantly 2D and examines wall pressure and hot wire probes at the spanwise
 center plane.
 This location in a symmetric setting can be reasonable assumed to have
 a diverging or converging plane for the spanwise velocity leading to concentrat
ion, rarification, and periodic behavior of the recirculated small scale
 streamwise structures.
 This will lead to erroneous evaluation of the turbulence and its spectral
 parameters.
 On the other hand, had the probes be placed in a plane corresponding to
 the center of a spanwise cell, the evaluated parameters would have been
 different for the first tonal peak.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
Cove bursting as a modulating mechanism
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The spanwise behavior of the flow was demonstrated previously in the works
 of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 for rectangular cavity flow, and also for flow past a backward facing step
 by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The spanwise modulation was also shown to exist in moderate Reynolds number
 flows for lid-driven rectangular cavity flow by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Albensoeder2001"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The effect is hence reasonably assumed to be the result of centrifugal
 effects of flow with a curved streamline and is identified as a new fundamental
 fluid dynamic feature of the cove motion, which was not identified previously
 in the literature due to both an erroneous assumption of spanwise homogeneity
 and the very low frequency oscillations induced by its dynamics.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The highly curved shear layer and the curved streamline of the recirculation
 enables saturation of spanwise modes associated with the centrifugal instabilit
y in recirculation region.
 These modes are the most unstable steady eigen modes in view of centrifugal
 instability
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 This generates planes of convergence and divergence of the fluid mass.
 The fluid mass hence must be redistributed from the converging planes to
 the diverging planes to maintain mass continuity in the spanwise flow.
 However, in the peculiar configuration of a cavity flow bounded by a shear
 layer on one side, the velocity of flow outside the shear layer which entrains
 the fluid from the recirculation is at a higher velocity than the inner
 recirculation which plays the role of redistributing the fluid back to
 the diverging planes.
 Due to this difference of flow rates, the entrainment and removal of fluid
 mass is faster at converging planes and redistribution is slower in diverging
 planes leading to an imbalance of the mass continuity.
 This imbalance saturates periodically leading to a local bursting of the
 shear layer at the location of diverging planes, enabling mass transfer
 across the shear layer and leading to generation of streamwise oriented
 vortices in the process.
 The bursting hence periodically and locally disrupts the spanwise homogeneity
 of early shear layer in terms of spanwise vorticity and hence the spanwise
 coherence of the 2D K-H vortices.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
One key ingredient in understanding the subsequent effects of such a cove
 bursting is in the fact that the bursting occurs at the diverging planes.
 Since the velocity is diverging, the generated streamwise vortices are
 convected either by the positive velocity or by the negative.
 By nature of turbulent flow, the bursting location is located more frequently
 at the center and hence the convection direction is selected in a stochastic
 manner.
 Consequently their location of impingement at the trailing edge of the
 slat also varies in the same fashion.
 This is precisely the phenomena noted in the recent work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Wei2025a"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 where spanwise location of the tonal sources shows intermittent variations
 along the spanwise locations at the slat trailing edge.
 Our demonstrations hence provides a plausible explanation on what fundamentally
 drives this dynamics.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Moreover, the Rossiter mechanism selects the frequencies based on the number
 of vortices that are shed which upon impingement are able to close the
 aeroacoustic loop.
 This means that if there is a periodic disruption of spanwise coherence,
 select Rossiter peaks would be affected depending on the frequency of the
 modulating oscillation, while the vortex shedding at other frequency multiples
 can remain intact.
 One direct evidence of such a periodic disruption of spanwise coherence
 is that the acoustic waves formed by impinging vortices which drives the
 Rossiter mechanism will show an amplitude modulation in time.
 The amplitude modulation will then lead to non-linear transfer of energy
 between the tonal frequencies is also a popular phenomena is slat noise,
 though unexplained.
 Here the first broadband hump which corresponds to the first Rossiter tone
 is weaker in the sound level compared to the second tone, and is not evident
 in the VALIANT experiment against installation noise.
 This peak also shows intermittent behavior according to 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Jawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 for measurements in the wall pressure measurements.
 A further investigation of the farfield spectra observed by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Jawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 shows that the low frequency broadband humps shows two symmetric shoulders
 on its sides, as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:jawahar_farfield"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, within a frequency range of approximately 
\begin_inset Formula $\Delta St_{s}=0.12$
\end_inset

 on both side of its central frequency.
 We here theorize that this appearance of shoulders for the broadband low
 frequency hump is the result of the first Rossiter mode (corresponding
 to the BB hump) being amplitude modulated.
 The effect of amplitude modulation of a signal leading to development of
 additional symmetric peaks in the spectral domain corresponding to frequencies
 
\begin_inset Formula $F_{peaks}=F_{c}\pm F_{s}$
\end_inset

 around the carrier frequency 
\begin_inset Formula $F_{c}$
\end_inset

 by the modulating signal frequency 
\begin_inset Formula $F_{s}$
\end_inset

 is a canonical phenomena in signal processing.
 Correspondingly, an estimation of the Strouhal number for modulating frequency
 of 
\begin_inset Formula $200Hz$
\end_inset

 for the given slat chord yields 
\begin_inset Formula $\Delta St_{s}=0.16$
\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tb
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter09_figs/HasanPlot.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 9cm
	height 9cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The farfield spectra from experimental study of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Jawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 for the 30P30N HLD geometry.
 The experiment had a free field velocity of 
\begin_inset Formula $30 m/sm/s$
\end_inset

, 
\begin_inset Formula $Re=7\times10^{5},$
\end_inset

 and a span to chord ratio of 1.5.
 The low frequency broadband hump shown in the inset correspond to the first
 Rossiter mode and can be noted to have the shoulder frequency corresponding
 to 
\begin_inset Formula $\Delta St=0.12$
\end_inset

.
 This is conjectured to arise from the low frequency modulation of the first
 Rossiter mode due to the spanwise mode formation and resulting low frequency
 bursting of the early shear layer demonstrated in this chapter 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:jawahar_farfield"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The farfield spectra from experimental study of Jawahar et al.
 for the 30P30N HLD geometry.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Here, the Strouhal numbers for the Rossiter tones are dependent on the shear
 layer path length.
 Following the hypothesis that the low frequency oscillation is due to the
 effect of mass flow disparity, the Strouhal number for the low frequency
 oscillation is not necessarily linked to the shear layer path length but
 related to the difference of velocity, 
\begin_inset Formula $\Delta U=U_{0}-U_{i}$
\end_inset

, between the inner cove and the free stream and also to the length of spanwise
 cells 
\begin_inset Formula $\lambda_{s}$
\end_inset

.
 Thus, if the frequency of the cove bursting is 
\begin_inset Formula $f_{B},$
\end_inset

 then 
\begin_inset Formula $f_{B}\propto\Delta U$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $f_{B}\propto\frac{1}{\lambda_{s}}$
\end_inset

 , then 
\begin_inset Formula $St_{B}\propto\frac{\Delta U}{\lambda_{s}}\times\frac{C_{s}}{U_{\infty}}$
\end_inset

.
 However, the spanwise cell wavelength is proportional to the slat chord
 as suggested by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008a"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, then 
\begin_inset Formula $St_{B}$
\end_inset

 would reduce to 
\begin_inset Formula 
\[
St_{B}\propto\frac{\Delta U}{U_{\infty}}\propto1-\frac{U_{i}}{U_{\infty}}
\]

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{i}$
\end_inset

 is the velocity of recirculation.
 Hence Strouhal number for the bursting phenomena can be reasonably assumed
 to be dependent only on 
\begin_inset Formula $\Delta U$
\end_inset

, the velocity difference across the initial shear layer.
 Nevertheless a more rigorous approach on extracting a model for this Strouhal
 number requires precise knowledge of the dependence of spanwise cell size
 based on the slat chord.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tbp
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter09_figs/Bursting024.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 14cm
	height 14cm
	keepAspectRatio
	groupId brusting_qcrit

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Time stamp
\begin_inset Formula $0.214s$
\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter09_figs/Bursting029.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 14cm
	height 14cm
	keepAspectRatio
	groupId brusting_qcrit

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Time stamp 
\begin_inset Formula $0.219s$
\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The cove bursting near the mid-span diverging plane at time stamps separated
 by 0.005s corresponding to the 200Hz peak in the numerical hot-wire probe
 data 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:The-cove-bursting"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Furthermore, from the inspection of data recorded from the high fidelity
 simulation, the vortex visualization enables to identify the cove bursting.
 For this, we increase the Q-criterion value used to obtain the iso-contours
 to obtain a smooth cover of the region of initial shear layer such that
 a bursting of this spanwise coherent isocontour, itself arising from the
 spanwise vorticity of the early shear layer, can be identified.
 Snapshots of the flow separated in time by a time interval of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.005s$
\end_inset

 corresponding to the frequency for 
\begin_inset Formula $200Hz$
\end_inset

 are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:The-cove-bursting"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 It can be noticed that the spanwise coherence of the shear layer is burst
 in a quick burst of streamwise vorticity formation which is then convected
 along the shear layer.
 The generated vortices also gain a spanwise velocity corresponding to the
 position of the bursting, i.e.
 the vortices from the bursting are carried by the positive of negative
 spanwise velocity depending on the proximity of such vortices to the negative
 or positive velocity cells in the initial stage.
 This suggests that the position of the bursting is only approximately static
 in the very early shear layer, and towards the impingement location the
 location of vortices from the bursting can be highly chaotic.
 This is only of significance if there is a sufficient difference of characteris
tic between the region of vortices from bursting and the slurry of streamwise
 vortices already present towards the impingement location.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
Conclusion
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
In this chapter, we presented the numerical investigation and major findings
 specific to cove dynamics and noise mechanisms for VALIANT geometry HLD.
 The airfoil was kept at an angle of attack at 
\begin_inset Formula $18^{0}$
\end_inset

 against an inflow of 
\begin_inset Formula $50 m/sm/s$
\end_inset

 at a chord based Reynolds number of 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{6}$
\end_inset

 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The slat positioning was kept as standard.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The objective of the study was to investigate the details of data generated
 using unsteady 3D LBM for the slat cove flow and to revisit existing knowledge
 on its noise mechanism.
 In line with this, the unsteady visualizations of the cove vortices using
 Q-criterion was obtained and the behavior of spanwise coherent structures
 and their conversion to small scale streamwise structures were discussed.
 The generation of streamwise structures were shown to be possibly influenced
 by the curvature instability of the shear layer which augments the current
 understanding of their behaviors.
 Detailed visualizations were used to suggest that the vortices are generated
 from the outer periphery of the spanwise coherent structures and that a
 major fraction of the recirculated vortices are entrained and consumed
 by the spanwise coherent vortices from the early the shear layer.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
On inspecting the mean flow contours of the velocity and pressure fields
 in the cove, the 2D flow components largely agreed with the existing knowledge
 of slat cove dynamics.
 However, the distributions of spanwise velocity rendered strong spanwise
 modulations which called into question the veracity of a spanwise homogeneous
 flow typically assumed for the configuration in both experiments and numerical
 simulations.
 The spanwise velocity modulation with amplitude upto more than 
\begin_inset Formula $10%\ensuremath{\%}
$
\end_inset

 of the mean stream velocity was observed in the simulation which used a
 spanwise domain length of more than 
\begin_inset Formula $5C_{s}$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $0.66C,$
\end_inset

 where 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{s}$
\end_inset

 is the slat chord length and 
\begin_inset Formula $C$
\end_inset

 is the stowed chord of the full HLD.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
To establish that the modulation is not an artifact of the simulation due
 to application of the periodic boundary condition, a simulation of the
 original wind tunnel geometry along with the lateral supporting plates
 were used.
 Here, the flow around the HLD was typically expected to be spanwise homogeneous
 in the region which is free from the influence of the wall in the experiment.
 But counter-intuitively this region was found to have a length of 0.2
\begin_inset Formula $C$
\end_inset

.
 However, the presence of spanwise modulations were also strongly disrupted
 by the presence of wall related turbulence for the rest of the span.
 Hence it is inferred that the presence of spanwise modulations is not a
 numerical artifact of the simulation but an effect of the centrifugal force
 due to the recirculating motion in the cove.
 To further the argument, two other simulations, one with a reduced span
 length by a factor of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.5$
\end_inset

 and another with a subsized geometry with the chord scaled by a factor
 of 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{2}{3}$
\end_inset

 are also presented.
 Both the cases are also shown to retain the spanwise cell formation with
 the latter having a higher spanwise wave number for the modulations demonstrati
ng that the feature responds to the geometrical conditions.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
On further investigation of the mean flow distributions, it was inferred
 that the spanwise modulation of velocity leads to generation of converging
 and diverging 2D planes.
 At these planes, if we move along the positive spanwise direction, spanwise
 velocity switches signs.
 For those which switches the velocity from negative to positive are what
 we refer to as the diverging planes and they act as a source of the fluid
 for spanwise flow.
 The vice-versa is true for the converging planes which act as the sinks
 enabling entrainment of flow into the flow exterior to the recirculation.
 Such a configuration was shown to distort the pressure field in the cove
 such that the low pressure center of recirculation (time-averaged) generated
 due the centrifugal effect is not spanwise homogeneous, but deflected towards
 the shear layer at the location of the diverging nodal planes.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The spanwise variation of the velocity spectra for the spanwise component
 then revealed that there exists an oscillation at 200Hz, corresponding
 to 
\begin_inset Formula $St\approx0.156$
\end_inset

.
 These periodic oscillations since occurring at the diverging planes only
 at the early share layer can potentially affect the spanwise coherence
 of the shed eddies.
 Moreover, the streamwise vortices generated in this oscillation are convected
 towards both spanwise directions from the diverging plane in a stochastic
 manner.
 The latter phenomena is thus suggested as a plausible reason for recently
 discovered stochastic nature of the spanwise coherence location, trailing
 edge turbulence characteristics, and the non-linear interaction between
 the slat tones.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Thus, based on the above inferences, we suggest in this chapter that the
 spanwise modulation of the spanwise velocity present in the slat cove have
 a non-trivial impact on both the cove vortex dynamics and their acoustic
 signature.
 The problem of spanwise mode generation itself is sparingly attended in
 the fluid dynamics literature although the same has been noted, intrigued
 on, and partially characterized in the works including that of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Albensoeder2001"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, and 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008a"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The low frequency oscillation mechanism connected to spanwise modes and
 their interaction with the recirculating 2D flow can be noticed in the
 recent exhaustive review of cavity flows by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "HamiltonSmith2024"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 A further investigation of these phenomena is an interesting topic of future
 research and can be undertaken by fundamental analysis of the behavior
 of the Navier-Stokes equation under the effect of strong curvature of of
 a shear layer which bounds a region of recirculation.
 For its implications for slat noise, it is clear from this demonstration
 that experimental investigations which use 2D PIV and hotwire measurements
 at the spanwise center-plane will not be able to capture the spanwise mode
 formations.
 This explains why the stochasticity of slat Rossiter tones remained elusive
 of a reasonable explanation, and the discrepancies related to the tone
 frequency calculations and amplitude calculations from explanation based
 on Rossiter mechanism alone.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset bibtex
LatexCommand bibtex
btprint "btPrintCited"
bibfiles "/home/amurali/Desktop/References/zoterolibrary"
options "unsrtnat"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_body
\end_document#LyX 2.3 created this file. For more info see http://www.lyx.org/
