\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Curvature distribution along the shear layer for Cases 22 and 26 computed
 using Eq.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "eq:curvreqn"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, along with the corresponding shear layer shapes and farfield noise spectra.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:streamlinecurvature-2"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The main characteristics of the curvature distribution on the streamline
 are the following:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
The magnitude of curvature has atleast one null point along the shear layer
 where the direction of curvature inverts.
 This occurs when the initial shear layer which is redirected towards the
 slat gap has to correct the curvature in order to redirect the flow through
 the slat gap.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
Depending on the proximity of the slat with respect to the main element,
 and if the initial curvature is insufficient, the curvature can spike before
 the inflection point, as in Case 
\begin_inset Formula $4$
\end_inset

.
 This is particularly the case when the slat overlap is increased.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
Upon impingement the streamline enters a region of strong turbulence which
 also have low frequency and intermittent behaviors.
 The region is also close to the slat wall where the mean flow solution
 is not well converged using the 
\begin_inset Formula $5$
\end_inset

 chord pass times used to average the flow.
 This leads to noise in the streamline calculated using the mean flow and
 therefore the curvature calculation has a strong error.
 Case 
\begin_inset Formula $[4,5,6,25,27,\text{ and }28]$
\end_inset

 can be noted to have this problem after the impingement location.
 These cases have a high slat overlap leading to the impingement point being
 far inside the cavity also attenuating both tonal and broadband characteristic
 noise.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Enumerate
The vortex impingement location on the slat upper wall will generate a strong
 curvature.
 This spike in curvature is the second sharp peak after the first inflection.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The curvature profiles thus analyzed is very much in agreement with the
 qualitative deductions in the previous sections.
 More precisely, a shear layer which maintains a curvature lower or same
 order of magnitude as inverse slat chord with the most delayed point of
 inflection, which consequently leads to a delayed impingement location
 closest to slat trailing edge, tend to be a more efficient noise generator.
 The proximity of the impingement location, identifiable as a feature from
 the curvature profile also has a strong influence on the noise levels.
 A good example is the comparison of Case 
\begin_inset Formula $22$
\end_inset

 and Case 
\begin_inset Formula $26$
\end_inset

 as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:streamlinecurvature-2"

\end_inset

.
 For Case 
\begin_inset Formula $22$
\end_inset

, the trajectory have a regularized curvature with the impingement location
 close to the trailing edge, while for Case 
\begin_inset Formula $26$
\end_inset

, the impingement location is moved to the interior.
 For the latter, although the exit velocity is higher at the slat gap, the
 noise levels are lower than Case 
\begin_inset Formula $22$
\end_inset

, suggesting that the location of impingement plays a crucial role in determinin
g the source efficiency.
 Moreover, in addition to the effect of impingement at the wall, the region
 around the impingement by nature of the centrifugal instability leads to
 a reduction of spanwise coherence of structures.
 Hence we theorized that the curvature history prior to the trailing edge
 is the noise-determining feature and not the impingement location by itself.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
That being the observations based on raw curvature along the streamline,
 the centrifugal effects also depends on the streamline velocity.
 A shear layer that maintains a higher streamline velocity must therefore
 accrue a larger effect of centrifugal instability, which here is the generation
 of streamwise vortices at the expense of spanwise vorticity.
 Therefore, we proceed to investigate shear layer shapes based on the suggestion
s from 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bradshaw2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
The Curvature Richardson Number
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Curvature Richardson
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
As mentioned in the introduction, an early work looking into the fundamental
 problem of the effect of curvature on the turbulence characteristics can
 be seen in attempt by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bradshaw1969"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 It was then deduced that the curvature effects are significant if the shear
 layer thickness exceeds 
\begin_inset Formula $1/300^{th}$
\end_inset

 of the radius of curvature.
 From the characterization of curvatures, we can deduce that the streamline
 curvature of the slat shear layer is of the same order as that of the slat
 chord and consequently a shear layer thickness of 
\begin_inset Formula $1\times10^{-4}\,m$
\end_inset

 will be large enough to be unstable.
 From the observation of the slat flow cases, the standard initial shear
 layer thickness is of the order of 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{-3}\,m$
\end_inset

 as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:shearlayercurvature"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 in Chapter 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "chap:04_The_VALIANT_Case"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, suggesting that the curvature must have a non-trivial effect.
 The effect also becomes increasingly significant as the shear layer spreads
 towards the impingement where the curvature is maximized and the shear
 layer thickness is large enough to be fully unstable.
 A later work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bradshaw2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 suggested that a curved streamline will also have the same dynamic balance
 between curvature driven centrifugal force and fluid dynamic forces as
 in the case of forces with density stratified flows.
 For the latter, the buoyancy force appears as a source term in the momentum
 equations whereas for curved streamlines the centrifugal force appears
 as a source term when the Navier-Stokes momentum equations are written
 in the streamline coordinates.
 The equivalence of terms were then exploited to obtain an equivalent curvature-
Richardson number such that it can capture the effect of curvature on the
 streamline turbulence.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tb
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset space \space{}

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Case 31
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset space \space{}
\end_inset

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Case 31
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset space \space{}
\end_inset


\begin_inset space \space{}
\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/Thesis_draft/parametric_case_images/parametric_cases/fwh/FWHObserver2_AOAp195SDAp352SGPp094SOLn042.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 6cm
	height 6cm
	keepAspectRatio
	groupId thesis_spectra

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Case 31
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Comparison of shear layer shape, Curvature Richardson number profile and
 far-field noise of select cases 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:curvature_richardson-3-1"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
In the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 using linear stability analysis, the effect of curvature on a slightly
 curved shear layer was shown to have two important effects: first being
 a partial stabilization of the K-H instability due to the curvature and
 the other being the existence of curvature driven steady spanwise modes.
 For the latter, the curvature is particularly identified as unstable if
 the Rayleigh criterion is satisfied, i.e.
 if the angular momentum decreases radially outward across the curvature.
 From the distribution of mean flow in the slat cove, we can deduce that
 this condition is satisfied only in the later part of the shear layer towards
 the impingement region.
 This is due to the high velocity stream being on the concave side of the
 curvature in the slat gap and hence qualitatively explains the generation
 of the streamwise vorticity in this region.
 Now, to obtain a quantitative measure of how curvature affects the shear
 layer, the linearized streamline equations in curvilinear coordinates were
 used by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 to obtain the kinetic energy production terms in streamwise and spanwise
 direction.
 The ratio of the same then capture the vorticity transfer into streamwise
 structures.
 This ratio also came out as the curvature Richardson number as originally
 suggested by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bradshaw1969"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 and have the definition
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard

\size large
\begin_inset Formula 
\[
R_{f}=\frac{\frac{2U}{R}}{\frac{dU}{dy}+\frac{U}{R}}
\]

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
where, 
\begin_inset Formula $U$
\end_inset

 is the streamline velocity and 
\begin_inset Formula $R$
\end_inset

 is the local radius of curvature.
 Here the term 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{U}{R}=\frac{1}{ds}\left[\frac{U^{2}}{R}\frac{ds}{U}\right]$
\end_inset

 represents the momentum transfer that is effected when a fluid mass traverses
 a unit distance under the influence of centrifugal force 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{U^{2}}{R}$
\end_inset

.
 A more elaborate thought on the works of Bradshaw and Liou and why their
 ideas are valid for the slat cove dynamics is given in Chapter 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "chap:04_The_VALIANT_Case"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 Here we proceed to use the same for a comparative analysis.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The curvature Richardson number profiles along the shear layer for a few
 select cases are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:curvature_richardson-3-1"

\end_inset

 and a full dataset is given in Appendix B.
 A first case of interest with a clearly interpretable result is with Case
 18 and 25, and is shown separately in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:curvature_richardsonCase18"

\end_inset

.
 This case clearly have a positive slat overlap with a reduced slat gap
 leading to choking of the flow.
 However, the tonal noise components are still evident, particularly the
 third and fourth tones which show a strong SPL above the mean noise levels.
 
\color black
This hints at the nature of non-linear interaction between the harmonic
 tones such that the first two tones transfer energy to the higher order
 modes.
 Such non-linear interactions were discussed recently in the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Wei2025"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The same effect can be noticed in Case 25, which has an improved exit velocity
 but still less than Case 23 for example.
 Hence Case 25 also have a diminished broadband level and the third and
 the fourth tone maintains the same SPL as the most noisy Case 22.
 Interestingly these cases exhibit an increase in the curvature Richardson
 number owing to the effect of sharp curvature near the impingement.
 As can be inferred from the Richardson number plot, the impingement points
 for both these cases are slightly more upstream along the wall from the
 trailing edge than the standard Case 22, and shows the non-linear tonal
 relations at multiple flow exit velocities.
 However, despite our best efforts, a more direct relationship between the
 curvature effect and the non-linear frequency couplings are still elusive.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
It can also be noted that the Richardson numbers are higher than 
\begin_inset Formula $0.1$
\end_inset

 on average along the shear layers for all cases.
 In comparison, 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 identified curvature instabilities for the case of slightly curved shear
 layers whose Richardson numbers were in the order of 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{-2}$
\end_inset

.
 For the noisy case Case 22, the Richardson number has an initial value
 of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.1$
\end_inset

 and rises to 
\begin_inset Formula $0.9$
\end_inset

 before the curvature inflection.
 The region after the inflection, which then satisfies the Rayleigh criteria,
 maintains the Richardson number above 
\begin_inset Formula $0.2$
\end_inset

 until impingement close to the trailing edge.
 This region between the curvature inflection and the impingement is hence
 where the shear layer vorticity is unstable due to the centrifugal effects
 and therefore lead to rapid generation of streamwise structures.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
On observing the same region for the Richardson numbers in the noisy cases
 in the dataset, it can be observed that Case 
\begin_inset Formula $22$
\end_inset

 maintains a lower bound for the Richardson number for this region i.e.
 all other cases which have the characteristic broadband and tonal components
 but with a lower SPL over the broadband range tend to maintain a higher
 Richardson number in the region before the impingement.
 Hence it can be inferred that the lowest Richardson number is one factor
 than contributes to the noise efficiency of Case 22 by allowing higher
 spanwise coherence.
 However again, to infer the contribution of curvature quantitatively requires
 a more meticulous approach since the broadband noise is primarily dependent
 on the exit velocity past the slat trailing edge.
 In Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:curvature_richardson-3-1"

\end_inset

, a few select cases are shown which have a similar exit velocity but with
 a variation of the sound levels.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
On comparing Case 24 with Case 26 with reference Case 22, the exit velocity
 magnitude in the slat gap for Case 24 is lower than that of Case 26.
 But the noise level of Case 24 is higher and agrees well with Case 22.
 On comparing their Richardson number profiles, the Case 24 and 22 agrees
 closely whereas for Case 26, the curvature inflection point occurs earlier
 in the shear layer.
 Hence the Case 26 has more length along the shear layer which is unstable
 to the centrifugal instability thereby leading to a sharp reduction of
 the spanwise coherence.
 Now comparing Case 26 to Case 31, there is a smoother evolution of the
 shear layer shape for Case 31 than the former since for this case the impingeme
nt location is closer to the trailing edge.
 Hence the effect of impingement is further reduced than Case 26 thereby
 recovering the spectra closer to the standard case.
 However, despite the exit velocity being still higher than Case 24, the
 Case 31 does not recover the same levels.
 This suggest that the effect of curvature driven decoherence holds relevance
 for the noise efficiency in addition to the exit velocity and the proximity
 of impingement.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Hence the Richardson number comparison with the most noisy cases can conspicuous
ly suggest the noise efficiency of the case.
 A Richardson number profile in the critical region similar to Case 22,
 the most noisy configuration, together with the location of the impingement
 location closest to the trailing edge suggest that the broadband noise
 and tonal levels will be similar, despite the fact that the tonal frequencies
 can be shifted based on the total length of the shear layer.
 This comparison hence suggest that the streamline curvature magnitude,
 as theorized, has a significant effect on the noise efficiency of the configura
tion.
 
\end_layout

\end_inset

However, an acoustic model or a quantitative correction based on the curvature
 profile is rather more subtle since the actual noise efficiency is much
 more strongly affected by the location of the impingement which occurs
 rather simultaneously with increased curvature effects.
 The normal pressure gradient calculation also have a high sensitivity near
 the impingement location since stagnation pressure near impingement causes
 a distortion of the pressure profile such that the normal pressure gradient
 is not representative of the pressure gradient in the shear layer.
 Therefore, although we demonstrate the role of the curvature in the vorticity
 conversion and noise efficiency, a practical acoustic model must rely comprehen
sively on all of the other factors too and thus the noise computation method
 using LBM-FWH approach or surrogate modelling is still suggested.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
That being the effect of vorticity transfer due to curvature, another effect
 of the streamline curvature is the generation of larger scale spanwise
 vorticity cells.
 This is explored in the next section.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
This process in our theory is responsible for the noisy efficiency thereby
 reducing the noise source efficiency.
 For the noisy cases, it can be noted that curvature inflection occurs at
 approximately 
\begin_inset Formula $70\%$
\end_inset

 of the path length from the cusp to the trailing edge.
 This case also have the maximum Richardson number at the location of the
 Trailing edge owing to the impulsive correction of the streamline direction
 as it passes along the sharp trailing edge.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Given that Case 22 is a noisy configuration, the curvature Richardson number
 profile serves as a base line to assess other cases.
 If the history of Richardson number for a case is such that it accrues
 a significant excess of the same, it suggests that the vorticity transfer
 was also accelerated during the traversal along the shear layer.
 Such a case will therefore have a larger proportion of the streamwise vorticity
 at the trailing edge thereby reducing the efficiency of acoustic scattering
 by the trailing edge.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
For cases including Case 
\begin_inset Formula $[4,6,\text{ and }27]$
\end_inset

 where the impingement location is away from the trailing edge and into
 the cove, the calculation of curvature gains noise in the location after
 impingement as mentioned earlier.
 This noise carries over to the Richardson number plots, however only suggesting
 that such a region prior to the trailing edge location definitively suggest
 a strongly turbulent region involving majorly streamwise vortices and hence
 with a weak noise characteristic.
 It is evident from the comparison of any generic case, that the impingement
 location is the closest to the trailing edge for Case 22.
 This proximity maintained only in Case 19, which upon inspection of its
 mean flow shows a different ejection velocity due to narrowing of the slat
 gap, however with only slightly weaker broadband characteristics.
 This suggests that the proximity of the impingement to the trailing edge
 can effectively compensate the reduction of noise intensity due to a reduced
 exit velocity.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
From comparison of the cases, it is hence clear that Richardson number profile
 of the shear layer, together with exit velocity and the impingement location
 can explain the broadband noise levels.
 However, the local Richardson number at the exit plane is not a physically
 consistent explanation of the same since the centrifugal effect enables
 the related vorticity conversion over the course of the trajectory.
 Hence a history of the Richardson number or more formally the cumulative
 integral of Richardson number is deemed as appropriate choice.
 For this we plot the cumulative Richardson number as a function of the
 streamline path length in Fig.??.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
placement ph
wide false
sideways false
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

	height 4.75cm
	keepAspectRatio
	BoundingBox 30mm 0bp 1440bp 867bp
	groupId richardson_numbers

\end_inset

\begin_inset Float figure

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/Thesis_draft/parametric_case_images/parametric_cases/sl_path/AOAp160SDAp320SGPp082SOLn054_richardson.png

\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Case 10
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The shear layer trajectory at mid-span plane obtained using time integration
 of the mean velocity field for parametric cases in the dataset.
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:curvature_richardson"

\end_inset

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
Spanwise Modes
\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Spanwise Modes
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The second characteristic cove flow phenomena that we are particularly intereste
d is the existence of spanwise modes.
 As shown for the standard positioning of the slat in Chapter 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "chap:04_The_VALIANT_Case"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, the spanwise velocity inside the cove close to the shear layer tends to
 develop a spanwise modulation with amplitudes upto 
\begin_inset Formula $0.15\,U_{\infty}$
\end_inset

.
 This leads to formation of converging and diverging planes which necessitate
 that a mass continuity is established between them.
 However, this continuity cannot be met since the outer stream entrains
 the flow from the converging planes faster than the inner low speed recirculati
on which replenishes the diverging planes leading to periodic bursting of
 the cove.
 This periodic bursting were shown to have a slat chord based Strouhal number
 of 
\begin_inset Formula $St=0.156$
\end_inset

 (
\begin_inset Formula $200\,Hz$
\end_inset

) for the standard slat position and will be investigated for all the cases
 in the dataset.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tbp
wide false
sideways false
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Comparison of the shear layer shape, curvature profile, and the spanwise
 modulations in three cases with initial curvature lower than Case 22.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:spanwise_cookies"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
One critical parameter related to the spanwise modes is its wave number.
 In the case of backward facing step studied by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Barkley2002"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, spanwise wavelength was approximately 
\begin_inset Formula $\approx7$
\end_inset

 times the step height.
 For cavity flows, the spanwise wave number was approximately one cavity
 depth as suggested by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2009"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Complementing their suggestions, 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 also demonstrated the spanwise steady modes in curved free shear layers.
 Although such a step height or cavity depth is difficult to define in the
 slat cove case, the slat chord 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{s}=0.039m$
\end_inset

 can be taken for an equivalent diameter for a circumcircle that passes
 through both the slat cusp and the trailing edge.
 In other words, 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{s}$
\end_inset

 can be taken for an equivalent cavity depth.
 For the standard case we showed that the non-dimensional wave number using
 the same for spanwise modulation, 
\begin_inset Formula $\Lambda_{z}=\frac{\lambda_{z}}{C_{s}}$
\end_inset

, would then range between 
\begin_inset Formula $1.0$
\end_inset

 for 
\begin_inset Formula $5$
\end_inset

 cells to 
\begin_inset Formula $1.7$
\end_inset

 for 3 cells, or zero when no cells are formed.
\end_layout

placement tbph

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Comparison of shear layer shape, curvature profile, and spanwise velocity
 modulations of three cases with initial curvature higher than Case 22
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:spanwise_cookies-2"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Consequently, and following Barkley, Bres and Liou, the spanwise modulation
 in slat cove is also reasoned to be primarily influenced by initial shear
 layer curvature with the exact value determined by the snapping necessitated
 by spanwise extend of the simulation.
 The snapping occurs since although the periodic condition represents an
 infinite spatial domain for the flow, it ensures that all variables have
 identical values on both spanwise edges at all time steps.
 This means that any standing wave pattern along spanwise direction will
 have to select a wave number such that the flow is congruent between the
 domain ends.
 The wave number is thus selected as the nearest whole number that fits
 the span length.
 For our simulations, the spanwise wavelength is 
\begin_inset Formula $0.2\,m$
\end_inset

 and as the slat position is varied, 
\begin_inset ERT
status open
\begin_layout Plain Layout
\backslash textcolor{red}{the degree}
\end_layout
\end_inset
 of centrifugal modes
 are first driven by the curvature of the shear layer and then the periodic
 condition leads to selection of the nearest possible whole number.
 Note that the same effect occurs in the presence of walls where the Dirichlet
 condition in pressure and velocity causes the spanwise wave number to snap
 to whole numbers.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
placement tbp
wide false
sideways false

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Power spectral density of spanwise velocity component as a function of spanwise
 location for cases which has spanwise mode formations.
 The low frequency oscillations are localized in the diverging planes of
 the modes where the spanwise velocity 
\begin_inset Formula $U_{z}=0$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{\partial U_{z}}{\partial z}>0$
\end_inset

 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:spanwise_psd_probe17_1"

\end_inset


\begin_inset Argument 1
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Power spectral density of spanwise velocity component as a function of spanwise
 location for cases which has spanwise mode formations
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
These spanwise velocity cells for all cases are given in the Appendix B.
 Among them the Cases 
\begin_inset Formula $[4,11,12,18,\text{ and }19]$
\end_inset

 have no cells corresponding to a null wave number.
 On comparing their shear layer curvatures from Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_cookies"

\end_inset

, it can be noted that these cases have shear layers which have a low curvature
 on the early region near the cusp.
 Case 
\begin_inset Formula $4$
\end_inset

 is a clear anomaly where the slat overlap causes a delayed curvature with
 the initial shear layer parallel to the outer wall of slat cusp.
 For Case 
\begin_inset Formula $11$
\end_inset

, the case develops a weak spanwise homogeneous flow however not forming
 cells due to the fact that the initial curvature is low, and with a significant
ly low exit velocity.
 The reduced exit velocity reduces both the streamline velocity along the
 shear layer and the recirculation velocity, and hence reduces the growth
 of centrifugal related instabilities.
 The same follows for Case 
\begin_inset Formula $18$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $19$
\end_inset

 where the shear layers are initially parallel to the incoming flow and
 the curvature increases in the mid-trajectory to compensate the delay and
 redirect the flow.
 Thus, in comparison with Case 
\begin_inset Formula $22$
\end_inset

, whose wave length is 
\begin_inset Formula $\Lambda_{z}=1.7$
\end_inset

, the above-mentioned cases have a lower initial curvature.
 This suggest two things: one is that it is additional proof that the spanwise
 modes are driven by the curvature of the shear layer since the wave number
 varies proportional to the initial curvature.
 The second is that unlike for the vorticity conversion, only the early
 part of the shear layer is significant as a driver of the mode formation.
 This could be possibly due to the fact that the initial shear layer curvature
 determines the radial of the recirculation bubble which ultimately determines
 the strength of centrifugal effects.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure

\begin_layout Plain Layout

	lyxscale 10
	width 4.15cm
	height 4.15cm
	keepAspectRatio
	BoundingBox 30mm 0bp 1440bp 867bp
	groupId thesis_spanwisemodes

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Case 19
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename parametric_case_images/parametric_cases/PSD_hot_wire_SL/AOAp180SDAp276SGPp053SOLn063_probe_17.png
	lyxscale 10
	width 7.5cm
	height 7.5cm
	keepAspectRatio
	BoundingBox 0bp 0bp 1250bp 520bp
	groupId psd_spanwise

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Case 19
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Power spectral density of spanwise velocity component as a function of spanwise
 location.
 The low frequency oscillations spanwise homogeneous.
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:spanwise_psd_probe17_2"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Investigating this proposition further, Cases 
\begin_inset Formula $[5,8,9,14,27,\text{ and }30]$
\end_inset

 have the smallest wavelength of 
\begin_inset Formula $\Lambda_{z}=1.025$
\end_inset

.
 Comparing the shear layer profiles from Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_cookies-2"

\end_inset

, these cases clearly have its initial curvatures as highest in the dataset
 and also an impingement point farthest from the trailing edge due to a
 high slat overlap.
 Thus the reduced diameter of the recirculation cavity explains the decrease
 in the spanwise cell size.
 These cases can also be noted to have a low broadband and tonal characteristic
 noise (See Appendix B for spectra) and owes to the early impingement leading
 to a complete decoherence of the ejected vorticity at trailing edge.
\color brown

\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
This can be explained based on the curvature instability leading to a complete
 transfer of vorticity to streamwise structures prior to their crossing
 the trailing edge.
 Nevertheless, the generation of a high wave number spanwise mode will also
 generate more number of diverging planes.
 The divergent planes periodically disrupt the spanwise vorticity of the
 shed vortices which are responsible for the aeroacoustic resonance.
 Hence this factor also acts in tandem to reduce the noise efficiency of
 this configuration and contributes to a high turbulence with majorly streamwise
 oriented vorticity being ejected from the slat gap.
 
\color brown
Although not elaborated in our work, these cases can also be seen to have
 a high level of high frequency noise above 
\begin_inset Formula $10 kHzkHz$
\end_inset

 suggesting that this component is sourced by the high speed ejection of
 streamwise structures onto the suction side of the main element.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
In contrast, as can be noted from Cases 
\begin_inset Formula $[10,15,17,20,21,22,24]$
\end_inset

 (see Appendix B), whose wavelength 
\begin_inset Formula $\Lambda_{z}=1.7$
\end_inset

, these arrangements produce the most noisy cases.
 Hence the presence of modes does not directly imply that the characteristic
 noise sources including the aeroacoustic resonance are significantly disrupted
 solely by presence of these modes.
 Rather, they induce additional dynamics arising from their periodicity.
 In Chapter 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "chap:04_The_VALIANT_Case"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, we showed that for the standard positioning of the slat, there exists
 a low frequency 
\begin_inset Quotes eld
\end_inset

bursting
\begin_inset Quotes erd
\end_inset

 of the divergent planes at frequency corresponding to 
\begin_inset Formula $St=0.156$
\end_inset

.
 This oscillation modulates the spanwise coherence of the shear layer such
 that the aeroacoustic loop is not driven by a steady shedding and impingement
 of spanwise coherent vortices but with an intermittent modulation of the
 coherence length of the impinging turbulence.
 We proposed that the resulting tones hence will also be amplitude modulated
 thereby developing side bands.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
To investigate the spanwise mode oscillations further, we now extract the
 spanwise distribution of the velocity spectra for the modulated spanwise
 component.
 As shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_psd_probe17_1"

\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_psd_probe17_2"

\end_inset

, the power spectra of spanwise velocity component has a localized spike
 around 
\begin_inset Formula $200\,Hz$
\end_inset

 corresponding to 
\begin_inset Formula $St=0.156$
\end_inset

 for all the cases studied.
 A particular statement can be that for the Case 15 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_psd_probe17_1"

\end_inset

.
 Here it can be observed that the case have three wavelengths within the
 spanwise domain.
 Hence, for the region near the slat trailing edge, there are 3 diverging
 planes and 3 converging planes.
 For the figure, the power spectral densities of velocity is obtained for
 a reduced spanwise length of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.1\,m$
\end_inset

 and hence the 2 diverging planes close to the mid-plane are captured.
 Also note that for positioning of the diverging cells, the lower and upper
 array of cells in the slat cove have a shifted phase by a quarter of wavelength.
 These spikes can be noticed to occur at the locations of the diverging
 planes where the spanwise velocity is zero and increasing.
 These spanwise localization is also present in all cases that have the
 cell formation and can be deduced from the exhaustive dataset presented
 in Appendix B.
\end_layout

\begin_inset Float figure

sideways false

\begin_inset Float figure

status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/UnsteadyAnalysis/AOAp190SDAp320SGPp064SOLn009/recirculation_freqs.png
	lyxscale 10

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Recirculation frequency
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Streamline extracted from the mean flow profile for Case 29 suggest that
 the recirculation in the cove maintains a frequency of 
\begin_inset Formula $190Hz$
\end_inset


\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:recirculation_frequency_case29"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
In contrast, for cases which does not have a spanwise modulation of the
 velocity due to its low insufficient initial curvature, the oscillation
 is still present but not localized along the span, i.e.
 the oscillation is homogeneous.
 This is demonstrated in Fig.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_psd_probe17_2"

\end_inset

.
 The low frequency range of the spectra also shows saturation of the standard
 color map below 
\begin_inset Formula $200\,Hz$
\end_inset

 suggesting high amplitude of oscillation compared to the cases where they
 are absent.
 On examining one of these cases further using a better color map, the particula
r Case 
\begin_inset Formula $04$
\end_inset

 as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_spectra_case04"

\end_inset

, it can be observed that these oscillations have a low amplitude spanwise
 structure at a very high wave number than the rest of the cases and a low
 amplitude variation of the spanwise velocity across the span, typically
 less than 
\begin_inset Formula $0.1U_{\infty}$
\end_inset

.
 This can be attributed to the recirculation of the streamwise structures
 which are periodically generated at the impingement and convected back
 to the early shear layer region by the recirculation.
 These cases are thus not forming the larger scale spanwise cells that are
 present in other cases but is only a spanwise homogeneous oscillation correspon
ding to the same low frequency of around 
\begin_inset Formula $200\,Hz$
\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Interestingly in Case 
\begin_inset Formula $[4,11,\text{ and }12]$
\end_inset

, a strong spanwise homogeneous oscillation is observed between 
\begin_inset Formula $100Hz$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $200Hz$
\end_inset

 over the whole span.
 For Case 
\begin_inset Formula $18$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $19$
\end_inset

, the frequency range lower than 
\begin_inset Formula $200Hz$
\end_inset

 is also largely occupied by fluctuations from very low frequencies.
 Together with the progressively developing characteristic farfield noise,
 these cases hence suggest transitional phase in the spanwise mode development.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
It must be mentioned that the spanwise localization of the peak at 
\begin_inset Formula $200Hz$
\end_inset

 is strongest only in the very close vicinity of the slat cusp as shown
 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:hotwire_probe_17_case11"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 in Chapter 04.
 In our results, the probe placement with respect to the slat wall geometry
 is static while its position with respect to the shear layer shape varies
 across the cases.
 Hence the variation of the levels in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_psd_probe17_1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_psd_probe17_2"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, and 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_psd_probe17_3"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 are not indicative of the variation of the strength of oscillations.
 The illustrations are only aiming to demonstrate that the low frequency
 localized oscillations occurs for all the slat positions considered while
 the actual degree of localization can be higher if a suitable probe positioned
 within the early shear layer are visualized for each case.
 
\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
To examine this further, Case 
\begin_inset Formula $[4,11,\text{ and }12]$
\end_inset

 without the presence of spatially modulated velocity, a single probe at
 the same cross flow location of probes in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_psd_probe17_3"

\end_inset

 is shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:hotwire_probe_17_case11"

\end_inset

 from Case 
\begin_inset Formula $11$
\end_inset

.
 The spanwise velocity component obtained shows that there exists a pertinent
 fluctuation around a zero mean flow component corresponding to the frequency
 of 
\begin_inset Formula $130Hz$
\end_inset

 suggesting that the flow near the cusp tends to oscillate with a homogeneous
 phase along the full span.
 This oscillation hence, more probable than not, be a fundamental instability
 mode related to the centrifugal effects.
 As mentioned, for a spanwise periodic simulation without explicit constraint
 at the boundary, the curvature determines the wave-number.
 Accordingly, for the case with severely low initial curvature due to the
 positioning of the slat, the spanwise mode number is close to 1 or less,
 leading to a spanwise homogeneous oscillation at the same Strouhal number
 range.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The low frequency fluctuations present in both cases with and without the
 spanwise modes suggest that this frequency itself is not directly connected
 to the centrifugal instability but rather a feature of a different flow
 dynamics.
 To investigate this, we choose an arbitrary position inside the cove, in
 close proximity to the slat cusp, where if a streamline is sourced would
 generate one that enters the recirculation after the impingement location.
 The three dimensional length of this streamline is then used to obtain
 the velocity profile, the time of travel along which can be used to obtain
 the recirculation frequency.
 The recirculation frequency as a function of the streamline path length
 for Cases 
\begin_inset Formula $[5,11,22,\text{ and }29]$
\end_inset

 are shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:recirculation_frequency_case5-1"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 to 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:recirculation_frequency_case29"

\end_inset

.
 The recirculation frequencies for these cases show that the time taken
 for a streamline particle from the vicinity of the slat cusp to return
 to the same vicinity via the recirculation explains the oscillation at
 
\begin_inset Formula $200\,Hz$
\end_inset

.
 This is true in the case of the three dimensional recirculation where the
 streamline is not necessarily two dimensional and the spanwise velocity
 leads to spanwise drifting.
 The frequency finds a better matching when the spanwise modes are formed
 as in the case of Case 
\begin_inset Formula $22$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $29$
\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard

\color black
For Case 
\begin_inset Formula $11$
\end_inset

 where the shear layer has a low initial curvature, the oscillation is spanwise
 homogeneous with a frequency slightly lower than the recirculation.
 Precisely, in this case, the frequency of spanwise oscillation is 
\begin_inset Formula $100\,Hz$
\end_inset

 and the recirculation frequency is at 
\begin_inset Formula $170\,Hz$
\end_inset

, i.e.
 the ratio of spanwise homogeneous oscillation frequency to that of recirculatio
n is at approximately 
\begin_inset Formula $0.6$
\end_inset

.
 We do not put forward an explanation for this but only suggest that it
 can be possibly due to the presence of a spanwise homogeneous drift velocity
 present in this case causing the recirculation loop to be a spiral with
 axis along the span, as seen in the streamline visualization in Fig.
\color inherit

\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:recirculation_frequency_case11"

\end_inset


\color black
.
 In contrast, for the other cases with presence of spanwise modes, the modes
 constrain the spanwise velocity to have opposing polarity with the cells
 and the oscillations to occur at the diverging planes.
 Then at this frequency, the diverging spanwise velocity leads to a saturation
 of the low pressure thereby bursting the shear layer at the recirculation
 frequency.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Section
Conclusions
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
In this last chapter, we utilized the LBM based ProLB solver and high-fidelity
 data generated using same to investigate the slat cove dynamics.
 We parameterized the slat positioning with respect to the main element
 using a three variable coordinate and used a surrogate model based automated
 exploration using Bayesian Active Learning to collect the dataset such
 that maximum information pertaining to the variation of the spectra is
 captured.
 The flow recordings were then investigated to uncover the slat cove dynamics.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
On inspecting the dataset, it was first showed that the spectra showed strong
 sensitivity to the shape of the shear layer as expected.
 Following the theory of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Terracol2016"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 that the tone frequencies are selected by the Rossiter mechanism, we investigat
ed the effect of shear layer shape in determining the strength of the resonance.
 For this we followed the suggestion of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 that a curved free shear layer has instabilities related to the centrifugal
 forces and can develop steady spanwise modes as well as Görtler like vortices.
 Based on 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Bradshaw1969"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, we characterized the slat shear layer for each case using its distribution
 of curvature and Richardson number.
 It was shown that the Richardson number for all cases are well in the unstable
 regime near the slat trailing edge.
 Nevertheless, the variation of Richardson number and corresponding variation
 in the spanwise coherence near the trailing edge is less significant than
 what would be caused by the effect of the position of the impingement location.
 The movement of the impingement location to the closest to the trailing
 edge is hence a better predictor for the strength of the tones.
 It happens geometrically that it is only possible to produce an additional
 curvature near the trailing edge by inadvertently making the impingement
 point to move upstream.
 The decoherence effect by the impingement then trumps the effect of additional
 curvatures.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
A second and novel finding related to the cove dynamics was presented in
 Chapter 04, i.e.
 the presence of spanwise modulated spanwise velocity.
 We showed using the dataset that the slat chord normalized wavelength of
 these modes 
\begin_inset Formula $\Lambda_{z}=\frac{\lambda_{z}}{C_{s}}$
\end_inset

 ranges between 
\begin_inset Formula $1.0$
\end_inset

 to 
\begin_inset Formula $1.7$
\end_inset

, the exact value dictated by the spanwise length of the cove.
 We also demonstrated using the curvature distribution of shear layers that
 a high initial curvature is the characteristic that leads to a stronger
 modulation leading to smaller wavelength of the spanwise velocity.
 Further investigation of the spanwise distribution of velocity spectra
 then revealed that there exist spanwise localized oscillations at 
\begin_inset Formula $200\,Hz$
\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The investigation of this spanwise distribution for all cases in the dataset
 showed that oscillation is present in all cases which develops the spanwise
 modes, and the localization is always in the diverging planes.
 The oscillations were also found to be always within the range of 
\begin_inset Formula $100$
\end_inset

 to 
\begin_inset Formula $200\,Hz$
\end_inset

 for all cases in the dataset.
 In search of the source of this frequency, the three dimensional recirculating
 streamlines were generated and the recirculation times were then shown
 to fall in the same range around 
\begin_inset Formula $200\,Hz$
\end_inset

.
 Hence it is theorized that the low frequency oscillation is the effect
 of the periodic recirculation, often referred to as the 
\begin_inset Quotes eld
\end_inset

pulsation of the cove
\begin_inset Quotes erd
\end_inset

 in recent literature.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Moreover, the low frequency oscillations were also visualized in the previous
 chapter using the Q-criterion demonstrating that this phenomena is a periodic
 bursting of the shed spanwise vorticity at the slat cusp.
 The spanwise coherence of the spanwise vorticity is hence periodically
 disrupted at its initial shedding phase leading to generation of small
 scale streamwise vortices.
 Being generated in diverging planes, these small scale structure is then
 convected by either positive or negative spanwise velocity.
 Being a turbulent process, the effect of this bursting and breaking of
 spanwise coherence is thus intractable periodically at the region farther
 from the cusp region.
 This very well explain the mode switching behavior that is attributed to
 the variation of coherence length and dominant tonal fluctuations across
 the spanwise extend reported in very recent literature
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Wei2025"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 This also explains the apparent stochasticity of the slat tones reported
 in the experimental investigations of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "KamliyaJawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Here it must be emphasized that the experimental investigations which selects
 the spanwise mid-plane to place the wall pressure and hot-wire probes may
 or may not be at the center of a diverging plane depending of the development
 of the cells.
 Hence, the studied characteristics will inevitably tend to diverge between
 the experimental observations from different wind tunnel cases in view
 of periodicity.
 The turbulence ejection that accompanies the bursting phenomena will also
 appear to induce intermittency in the turbulence characteristics in the
 slat gap since the periodicity of bursting is robust only in the very early
 shear layer near the slat cusp and the generated vorticity from each event
 is then convected along with the rest of turbulence.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Here, the fact that the bursting occurs at the diverging planes due to saturatio
n of a suction pressure at diverging planes is not entirely consistent with
 the fact that its frequency is close to the recirculation frequency.
 The saturation of low pressure could have been synchronized with other
 modes which are more probable, for example with the first Rossiter mode,
 and the flow recirculation frequency is an unintuitive candidate to synchronize
 with the spanwise mode oscillation, thereby suggesting a non-trivial coupling
 between the bursting phenomena and the recirculation.
 This aspect hence is an intriguing line of experimentation for future investiga
tions.
 Nevertheless, with the current understanding from our dataset and the presented
 results herein, it is overwhelmingly evident that the low frequency oscillation
 associated with the recirculation phenomena is pertinent to the establishment
 of characteristic noise sources in the cove dynamics.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard

\color brown
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout

\color brown
The idea of a low frequency modulation of the Rossiter tone by periodic
 disruption of the spanwise coherence of the shear layer and its periodic
 busting leading to generation of a streamwise vorticity is essential to
 form the complete picture of the slat cove dynamics that was until today
 characterized in terms of the 2D Rossiter mechanism.
 The low frequency modulation leading to generation of periodic and localized
 generation of streamwise vorticity also explains the intermittency characterist
ics that was so far speculated from the turbulence characteristics at the
 slat trailing edge.
 Clearly, the generation of streamwise structures at the early shear layer
 at locations of diverging planes are then convected by an in-homogeneous
 spanwise velocity through a fully turbulent shear layer with interactions
 between the recirculated small scale turbulence and additional turbulence
 generated due to the centrifugal convective instability.
 This renders the turbulence characteristic at the trailing edge to lose
 pertinent information about the coherent periodicity occurring at the early
 shear layer.
 This factor explains why the spanwise behavior and bursting remained elusive
 thus far from the previous investigators whose methodology primarily focused
 on data collected at the mid-span plane and the unsteady fluctuations at
 the slat trailing edge.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout

 Case 11 showing the presence of homogeneous oscillation of the spanwise
 velocity at approximately 130Hz.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:hotwire_probe_17_case11"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Slat cove vortices and their behavior is an intriguing phenomenon in view
 of their dynamics.
 As well-explained in the literature for slat noise, the primary vortices
 in the cove are those generated from the slat cusp due to the shearing
 of flow between inner cove flow and the incoming ambient.
 The velocity difference leads to 2D Kelvin-Helmholtz (KH) instability and
 leads to formation of structures which are nearly homogeneous in the spanwise
 direction.
 The vortices then travel to the slat trailing edge as they are convected
 by the mean flow which itself is accelerated by its passage through the
 constricted slat gap.
 The resulting acceleration leads to breaking up of the spanwise coherent
 structures into streamwise structures as they travel past the slat trailing
 edge and thus the ejected flow majorly contain streamwise oriented counter
 rotating vortex strands.
 These strands then interact with each other to generate helical vortices
 as they are are flushed onto the suction side of the airfoil.
 A visualization by isolating the spanwise coherent vortices shed from the
 slat cusp and their transition behavior towards the trailing edge is shown
 in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spancovevortex"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter05_figs/CoveVortices.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 16cm
	height 16cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:spancovevortex"

\end_inset

Slat cove vortices isolated using the Q-criterion.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsubsection
Görtler vortices at the trailing edge
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The behavior of cove vortices are hence interesting from a view of its fundament
al fluid mechanics.
 One interesting phenomena is the above-said transition of majorly spanwise
 vorticity in the early shear layer into streamwise vortices.
 One theory suggesting the generation of streamwise vortices is derived
 from an analogy related to Görtler vortices.
 In boundary layer flow past a concavely curved wall, the flow tends to
 develop streamwise oriented vortices as studied in detail by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Goertler1941"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 and later by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Saric1994"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 According to their analysis, the centrifugal force developed due to the
 curvature of the streamline is balanced by a pressure gradient normal to
 the streamline.
 The pressure gradient is responsible for redirecting the flow along the
 curved path and at higher curvatures when the centrifugal force is in excess,
 the pressure gradient developed will not be sufficient to redirect the
 flow resulting in an instability.
 In the unstable regime, the flow try to balance itself by generation of
 streamwise vorticity that aid in the transfer of momentum across this pressure
 gradient normal to the streamline.
 Moreover, as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:gortler_vortices_schematic"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, the angular velocity 
\begin_inset Formula $rU$
\end_inset

 is 0 at both the center of curvature and at the wall since 
\begin_inset Formula $r=0$
\end_inset

 at the center of curvature and 
\begin_inset Formula $U=0$
\end_inset

 at the wall respectively.
 Hence there must exist a maxima for the angular velocity in the flow region
 and also a region where 
\begin_inset Formula $rU<0$
\end_inset

.
 This idea was used by Görtler to show that the solutions to corresponding
 disturbance equations are of the form of streamwise-oriented counter rotating
 vortices.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter05_figs/Gortler Vorticse.png
	lyxscale 50
	width 12cm
	height 12cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:gortler_vortices_schematic"

\end_inset

A schematic of the streamwise oriented Görtler vortices from the work of
 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Saric1994"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset

The Görtler transition occurs only in regions of unstable curvature, i.e.
 the curvature needs to be concave and satisfy the Rayleigh criteria
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "rayleigh1917dynamics"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 In the trajectory of slat cove vortices, this transition is thus justified
 only near the trailing edge, where the flow is redirected away from the
 impingement location to be ejected out of the slat cove.
 At this location, the streamline curvature is such that high speed flow
 is on its concave side thus having a negative velocity gradient along the
 radius of curvature.
 Let aside the fact that the flow is strongly accelerated at the slat gap
 due to the nozzle effect of the cove geometry, the curvature effect is
 sufficient to generate streamwise vorticity.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Wang2023"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 experimentally studied the effect of chord based Reynolds number on the
 cove vortex dynamics and suggested that the Görtler vortices are present
 even at low Reynolds numbers, 
\begin_inset Formula $Re\approx1.3\times10^{4}$
\end_inset

 when shedding of spanwise coherent vortices from the cusp are absent.
 At higher Reynolds numbers, the flow develops the spanwise coherent structures
 in the early shear layer and is convected through the region of unstable
 curvature near the trailing edge.
 These spanwise structures thus interacts with the streamwise vortices that
 are generated in-situ and also those which are convected from the recirculation.
 In this interaction, the spanwise vorticity is again readily converted
 into streamwise vorticity resulting in a saturation of streamwise vortices
 in the trailing edge.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The effect of centrifugal force driving the generation of streamwise vortices
 were also studied by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "bradshaw1973effects"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Their study draws the analogy between the effect of streamline curvature
 and buoyancy forces due to the density gradients on the turbulence structure
 of shear layers.
 They concluded that 
\begin_inset Quotes eld
\end_inset

the effects of curvature on the apparent mixing length are appreciable if
 the shear-layer thickness exceeds roughly 1/300 of the radius of curvature
\begin_inset Quotes erd
\end_inset

, i.e.
 if 
\begin_inset Formula $\frac{\delta}{R}>\frac{1}{300}$
\end_inset

.
 With the local curvature along the streamline maintained at about 
\begin_inset Formula $0.01m$
\end_inset

, this translates to a sufficient condition that the shear layer is susceptible
 to curvature effects if the shear layer thickness is more than 
\begin_inset Formula $0.01/300=3\times10^{-5}m$
\end_inset

.
 From the mean velocity profile for the flow around the cusp, the shear
 layer thickness near the shedding region is roughly 0.002m as shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:shearprofile"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, which is about 60 times the requirement for the instability.
 Hence, the cove shear layer is clearly in the unstable regime related to
 curvature instabilities.
 In addition, any assumptions of linearity of the resulting interactions
 may be too exacting as well.
 According to the analysis of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Liou2014"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, the curvature Richardson numbers that allow linearity are of the order
 of 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{-2}$
\end_inset

.
 In the cove shear layer, the curvature Richardson number is near saturation
 at a value of 2, and hence suggest a strongly non-linear regime.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter05_figs/ShearVelocityProfile.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 6cm
	height 6cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label

\end_inset

 Shear layer profile along a normal to streamline near the cusp.
 y-axis - y coordinate, x-axis - velocity magnitude
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset space \space{}
\end_inset


\begin_inset space \space{}
\end_inset


\begin_inset space \space{}
\end_inset

\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsubsection
Spanwise cell formation for spanwise velocity and vorticity
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
A second phenomenon pertinent to the cove flow dynamics is the appearance
 of spanwise modulation.
 The mean velocity and pressure fields develop spanwise cells when the flow
 is fully developed, with the spanwise modulation best recognizable in the
 spanwise component of velocity.
 Alternating directions of spanwise velocity can be noted, as shown in Figure
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:pressure_and_velocity_spanwise_case22"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, with wave numbers varying consistently with nature of cove vortex shape.
 The strongest fluctuations associated with these cells appears to be attached
 to the cove flow shear layer, and is present dominantly inside the cove
 region.
 The flow is also modulated on the concave side of the flow curvature at
 slat gap.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter05_figs/span_cookies_AOAp180SDAp340SGPp094SOLn081.png
	lyxscale 15
	width 6cm
	height 6cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label

\end_inset

 for Case 22
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset

\begin_layout Plain Layout
