\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:pressure_and_velocity_spanwise_case22"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Most recent findings of spanwise modulated behavior in cavity flows that
 are relevant to cove dynamics is the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

, which were inspired by an earlier work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Faure2007"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 They characterized the flow in open cavities at a moderate Reynolds number
 range less than 
\begin_inset Formula $1.1\times10^{4}$
\end_inset

 to demonstrate that spanwise modulations of similar nature occurs in open
 cavity flows.
 They characterized such behavior as a result of local curvature of the
 flow.
 When the flow recirculates around the closed walls inside the cavity, the
 streamlines are curved along with a no-slip conditioning at the walls.
 Such curvature is hence subject to the curvature led instability and satisfy
 the Rayleigh criteria that the angular momentum decreases with respect
 the radial direction of streamline curvature.
 Note that this phenomena is now consistent with the fact that cove flow
 aeroacoustics are closely related to open cavity flows in that the aeroacoustic
 resonance mechanism driven by the cove shear layer is understood in close
 analogy to the well-known Rossiter mechanism for cavity resonance.
 This identification of spanwise modulated behavior of the flow is a new
 contribution to the slat noise literature in this thesis and hence we try
 to document the same as much as possible using the data obtained using
 the simulations.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Let us first look at the case of a standard slat position with respect to
 the main element.
 A visualization of the spanwise cells of spanwise velocity in the slat
 cove is shown in Figure 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:CoveSpanwiseModulationGriffonStandardCase"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 For the case of inflow velocity of 50 m/s, the chord based Reynolds number
 of the flow is roughly 
\begin_inset Formula $10^{6}$
\end_inset

, 2 orders of magnitude higher than 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Bres2008"
literal "false"

\end_inset

's moderate Reynolds numbers studied for open cavity flows.
 Also as mentioned in the previous subsection, the curvature Richardson
 number for this case is significantly higher than regimes considered for
 study of linear growth rate of the curvature instability.
 Hence this spanwise modulation is suggested as a result of saturation of
 possibly non-linear instability arising from the centrifugal effects in
 the cove recirculation.
 The initial curvature of the shear layer can be noted to be a good indicator
 of the strength of curvature effects.
 In Case 22, the shear layer radius of curvature is 0.025m, same order of
 magnitude as the slat chord, 
\begin_inset Formula $C_{s}\approx0.039m$
\end_inset

.
 This results in a curvature Richardson number of 1.1 in the early shear
 layer.
 The resulting shape of the cove recirculation region is shown in Figure
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:CovebubbleCase22"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 As can be noted in comparison with other cases, the curvature Richardson
 number of Case 22 is moderate between the range of 0.2 and 1.6 for other
 cases.
 This case develops a spanwise wavenumber of 
\begin_inset Formula $\lambda_{z}=0.2/3=0.067m$
\end_inset

, with three wavelengths fit to the spanwise domain length of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.2m$
\end_inset

.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
The pressure field inside the recirculation bubble is also interesting in
 that there does not exit a spanwise uniform low pressure core for the recircula
tion bubble.
 The mean pressure distribution is instead forming cells which are curved
 in their ends towards the shear layer and leads to formation of nodal planes
 towards which the flow converges and diverges.
 Such planes convect the low wavenumber Görtler vortices that are recirculating
 in the slat cove and leads to their concentration in these planes where
 the flow converges.
 From the comparison of the pressure and velocity fields, it appears also
 that the convergent planes tend to have the center of recirculation deeper
 into the cove whereas as for divergent planes, where the flow convect fluid
 away from the plane, the center of recirculation is closer to the shear
 layer.
 This means that spanwise flow velocity is driven by establishment of mean
 pressure distribution developed as a result of the centrifugal effect.
 On the contrary, if the nodal planes developed a higher pressure distribution,
 it could have been reasoned as s stagnation effect that converging fluid
 mass drives the pressure field modulation, but however this is not the
 case.
 The centrifugal effect of the shear layer flow generates radially outward
 flow which elicit a response from the flow pressure distribution to have
 a low pressure inner region at the center of the bubble.
 However, this behavior is not stable in the spanwise direction and hence
 a homogeneous low pressure center of circulation is not absent, and instead
 a wavy pattern is formed resulting in the convergent and divergent planes
 where the fluid mass is redistributed accordingly.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Problem*

\series bold
Why does the fluid want to form spanwise modulations instead of a spanwise
 homogeneous cove flow where the centrifugal effect is balanced by the radial
 pressure gradient?
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
This is a fundamental question about the Navier-Stokes behavior.
 The conservation of momentum of fluid in rotating configuration is famously
 unstable to perturbations along the axis of rotation.
 The Taylor-Couette configuration of flow between two rotating cylinders
 is a classical example where, if the Rayleigh criterion is satisfied, and
 if the flow is within the unstable range of Taylor numbers, the flow develops
 axisymmetric tubes of rotating fluids stacked along the axis of rotation.
 At higher Taylor numbers, which denotes the ratio of the centrifugal force
 to the viscous forces in a fluid, the flow also tends to develop spiral
 wavy patterns.
 The complexity of this configuration and the richness of this problem is
 evident from the variety of regimes for a Taylor-Couette system as described
 by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Andereck1986"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 They characterized a system of concentric cylinders based on the inner
 and outer-cylinder Reynolds numbers, 
\begin_inset Formula $R_{i}$
\end_inset

 and 
\begin_inset Formula $R_{o}$
\end_inset

.
 The resulting 2-dimensional domain produces Taylor vortices, wavy vortices,
 modulated wavy vortices, and spiral vortices to mention a few, and are
 reproduced from their original work in Figure 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Regimes-observed"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
For the slat cove flow behavior, we believe that the most relevant region
 is that of co-rotating cylinders.
 This is because the inner and outer flow in the slat cove have the same
 sense of rotation but different speeds.
 Hence it must be possible to identify the slat cove flow behavior in terms
 of an equivalent inner and outer flow Reynolds number.
 In comparison with the Taylor-Couette flows, in can be noticed in Figure
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Regimes-observed-zoomed"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 that TC flow tends to have an asymptotic behavior towards Azimuthally laminar
 flow with weak Ekman vortices (AZI).
 Hence it is convincingly possible that effect of cove recirculation and
 centrifugal forces are responsible for the formation of the spanwise modulation
s in slat cove.
 However, this notice of spanwise modulation was not the primary motive
 of our study and hence we do not engage a fundamental analysis of this
 phenomenon.
 Nevertheless we intend to convince the reader of its significance and that
 it is not possible to have a complete understanding of slat cove flow without
 characterizing this aspect.
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter05_figs/TaylorRegimes.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 12cm
	height 12cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Regimes observed in flow between independently rotating concentric cylinders.
 Dashed lines indicate the transition boundaries that are difficult to establish
 from visual observation alone since there is no abrupt change in the appearance.
 Dotted lines indicate the expected, but not yet observed, continuation
 of several boundaries.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Regimes-observed"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter05_figs/TaylorRegimes_Corotating.png
	lyxscale 30
	width 10cm
	height 10cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter05_figs/TaylorRegimes_CorotatingAbbrevs.png
	lyxscale 20
	width 7cm
	height 7cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Regimes observed in flow between independently rotating concentric cylinders.
 Dashed lines indicate the transition boundaries that are difficult to establish
 from visual observation alone since there is no abrupt change in the appearance.
 Dotted lines indicate the expected, but not yet observed continuation of
 several boundaries.
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:Regimes-observed-zoomed"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset

That being said, we now proceed to investigate the dataset.
 Variation of slat position with respect to the main element provides a
 way to compare the effect of cove recirculation on the formation of the
 modes.
 For this we choose to compare cases which have a sufficient variety of
 the slat shear layer shape.
 We choose Case 22 as a reference case as this is the most noisy case available
 in the dataset and also having the farfield noise spectra closest to experiment
al case.
 For comparison, three other cases are chosen, which are Cases 5, 29, and
 11, from Table 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "tab:allcases"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 and are shown in Figure 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:CoveSpanwise3Cases"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
For Case 5, the slat position is move closer to the main element by reducing
 the slat overlap.
 This has resulted in a configuration where the slat trailing edge is positioned
 downstream of the main element leading edge, however still with a sufficient
 slat gap for avoiding choking of the ejected flow.
 This case hence maintains a high velocity profile along the mean shear
 layer while moving the impingement location deeper into the cove away from
 the slat trailing edge.
 For the initial region of the shear layer, this means that initial radius
 of curvature is reduced while maintaining a sufficiently high flow velocity.
 Hence this case is expected to display and amplified effect of the shear
 layer curvature effect.
 Accordingly it can be noted that the case develops 10 spanwise cells, with
 a corresponding spanwise wavenumber 
\begin_inset Formula $k_{z}=\frac{N_{z}}{L_{z}}=\frac{5}{0.2}=25$
\end_inset

.
 Note that the spanwise wavenumber quantitatively can be sensitive to the
 spanwise extend of the domain since the periodic condition influence the
 wavenumber selection mechanism by provide a hard boundary condition of
 the length of the domain.
 However, given that all our simulations are conducted using the same spanwise
 extend, the wavenumber of the cells remains a useful representation for
 comparing the cases.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
For Case 22 and 29, the resulting spanwise wavelength is 
\begin_inset Formula $k_{z}=15\text{ and }20$
\end_inset

.
 The curvature Richardson number on the initial shear layer as seen in Figure
 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:Curvature-Richardson-Number"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

 is at 1.2.
 Hence this case can be reasoned to be on the interface between the stability
 modes of the spanwise instability, leading to a shift of the selected wavenumbe
r.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
For Case 11, the slat positioning is such that the trailing edge is again
 close to the main element however with a much smaller slat gap than Case
 5, leading to a choking of the flow.
 Hence the flow velocity is smaller along the shear, in agreement with the
 larger cove flow and also with a lower curvature of the initial shear layer.
 Hence this case is an example of the case with significantly smaller effect
 of the centrifugal forces on the flow.
 As can be noted, this case does not form spanwise modulations in the mean
 flow.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
placement H

sideways false
status open

\align center
\begin_inset Float figure

\end_inset

 number for corresponding cases in Fig.12 and 8.
 Cases for low initial 
\begin_inset Formula $Ri_{c}$
\end_inset

 (path length <0.2) do not lead to formation of spanwise cells while a higher
 Richardson number leads to higher wavenumber suggesting that the curvature
 effect influences spanwise modulation.
\begin_inset CommandInset label

\end_layout

\begin_layout Subsection
Effect of cove recirculation on the slat noise
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align left
The spanwise coherence of these vortices is a crucial factor that affect
 their aeroacoustics.
 The efficiency of impinging vortices to drive the acoustic mechanism –
 which generate an acoustic wave that travel back to the slat cusp to excite
 the aeroacoustic resonance – depends on the spanwise coherence of the structure.
 If the impinging structure is spanwise homogeneous, it will lead to generation
 of acoustic waves which are also nearly spanwise homogeneous leading to
 a two dimensional resonance loop.
 This in theory must be related to the strength of tonal peaks in the far-field
 acoustic spectra and hence arises the importance of phenomena responsible
 for the transfer of vorticity from spanwise to streamwise direction.
 Moreover, it is possible that the acoustic wave generation mechanism responsibl
e for the resonance loop is not directly due to the impingement of the vortices
 but due to the scattering of the incident pressure field the eddies by
 the trailing edge.
 As shown in Figure 
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_coherent"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, a spanwise oriented eddy while passing by the trailing edge causes an
 abrupt change of the incident pressure at the trailing edge.
 The variation is coherent in the spanwise direction and lead to generation
 of an amplified dipole sound source.
 On the contrary, in the case of a streamwise oriented eddy convected past
 a sharp trailing edge, the temporal variation of pressure distribution
 at the trailing edge is not significant and such eddies does not generate
 a strong noise source.
 Hence naturally, the composition of turbulence that flow past the trailing
 edge has to be spanwise coherent with a lower proportion of streamwise
 structure for the case to have strong tonal components.
 
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/My Publications Source Code/AIAA Rome/Noise radiation and dynamics of slat cove vortices revisited in light of a parametric LBM study/figs/Sketch_Vortex_TE_Span.png
	width 7cm
	height 7cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:spanwise_coherent"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\align center
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/My Publications Source Code/AIAA Rome/Noise radiation and dynamics of slat cove vortices revisited in light of a parametric LBM study/figs/Sketch_Vortex_TE_Stream.png
	width 7cm
	height 7cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:streamwise_eddy"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Sketch of the pressure signature generated at a TE by passing vortices :
 (a) spanwise vortices (b) streamwise vortices.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status collapsed

\begin_layout Section
Simulations with half spanwise extends
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
A simulation with half the spanwise length was also executed to probe the
 existence of spanwise modulations when the spanwise extend is varied.
 All simulation parameters were kept identical and only the spanwise extend
 was reduced to half, i.e.
 
\begin_inset Formula $0.1m$
\end_inset

.
 As shown in Fig.
\begin_inset CommandInset ref
LatexCommand ref
reference "fig:spanwise_modes"
plural "false"
caps "false"
noprefix "false"

\end_inset

, the new spanwise extend also allows the formation of spanwise velocity
 cells with the diverging and converging planes.
 These cells however not does not maintain the same wavelength as in the
 original case.
 Since there are two full cells in a spanwise extend of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.1m$
\end_inset

, the wavelength can be approximated as 
\begin_inset Formula $0.05m$
\end_inset

.
 However in the standard positioning of the slat, there are three cells
 over a spanwise extend of 
\begin_inset Formula $0.2m$
\end_inset

 thereby giving the wavelength as 
\begin_inset Formula $0.066m$
\end_inset

.
 This variation is in agreement with the fact that the spanwise boundary
 conditions impose a strong condition of congruence on the spanwise boundaries
 leading to restriction on the wave number selection.
 However the presence of modes can be inferred to be independent of the
 spanwise extend of the simulation.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Float figure
wide false
sideways false
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename chapter06_figs/Cutplane_spanhalf.png
	lyxscale 40
	width 5cm
	height 5cm
	keepAspectRatio

\end_inset

 
\begin_inset Graphics
	filename /home/amurali/Desktop/DRARM_Thesis_2024/processes/chapter13/spanwise_halfplane/Spanwise Cells.png
	lyxscale 25
	width 12cm
	height 12cm
	keepAspectRatio
	BoundingBox 0bp 200bp 1920bp 900bp
	clip

\end_inset


\begin_inset Caption Standard

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Spanwise modes in the case of reduced span of 0.1m showing the converging
 and diverging planes.
 
\begin_inset CommandInset label
LatexCommand label
name "fig:spanwise_modes"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
Apart from the dynamics of the flow, implications of spanwise modes on acoustics
 arise not from the spatial modes themselves but from the above mentioned
 periodic bursting.
 The spanwise coherence of impinging vortex is the first necessary condition
 for aeroacoustic resonance to occur since the Rossiter mechanism is a largely
 2D phenomenon with the strength of resonance decreasing progressively with
 spanwise coherence
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "HamiltonSmith2024,Souza2019"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Hence, if the spanwise coherence is broken periodically at a frequency
 lower than the first Rossiter tone, the strength of resonance will also
 be modulated, which means that the acoustic tones are not sourced by ideally
 periodic fluctuations but are amplitude modulated by the bursting frequency.
 Such an amplitude modulation can be detected in the spectral domain as
 appearance of side bands which we conjectured as the reason for the first
 Rossiter tone to appear broadband due to contributions from side band frequenci
es.
 This is however observable only if the span to chord ratio of the simulation
 is sufficiently large such that the centrifugally driven spanwise mode
 oscillations are prominent, as in the case of experiment by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "KamliyaJawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 The same effect will also vitiate the periodicity of the noise source character
istics rendering them as intermittent or quasi-periodic if analyzed close
 to the diverging planes.
 This is promptly underlined in the work of 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "KamliyaJawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 which shed light on the intermittency associated with the first Rossiter
 tone.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Plain Layout
In summary, the effect of shear layer shape on acoustics is qualitatively
 deducible from the collection of cases.
 It can be noted that both broadband and tonal noise levels are dependent
 primarily on the exit velocity with additional influence from the location
 of impingement and shear layer shape.
 This complements the literature where a scaling law of the slat noise level
 was established with OASPL in the characteristic frequency range proportional
 to 
\begin_inset Formula $M^{5}$
\end_inset

, where 
\begin_inset Formula $M$
\end_inset

 is the free stream Mach number
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Roger2005,Santana,Singer2000,Takeda2004,Guo2012"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 However, the location of impingement does not necessarily need to be stationary
 with an increase in the free-stream velocity and neither does the maximum
 exit velocity since the impingement location can influence both the recirculati
on flow rate and the exit flow rate.
 This determines the the velocity with which coherent structures are ejected
 past the trailing edge.
 Adding to the same complexity, the shear layer shape variation introduce
 varying levels of centrifugal instability to the shear layer which determine
 the vorticity transitions from spanwise coherent structures to streamwise
 which determine the efficiency of the TE scattering leading to broadband
 noise.
 This explains why the canonical scaling laws based on free-stream parameters
 alone have high uncertainties for standard slat-noise prediction models
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citep
key "Guo2003,Bolivar2020"
literal "false"

\end_inset

.
 Additionally, the location of impingement being close to the trailing edge
 is a strong indicator of the presence of characteristic noise signature
 regardless of the shear layer shape.
 Hence, it can be safely assumed that the the far-field power levels of
 the characteristic noise is primarily determined by the strength of dynamics
 at the trailing edge.
 Given these factors, we consider that an appropriate analysis of the slat
 noise characteristics and scaling laws must be based on the geometric parameter
s of the shear layer rather than based on the geometric positional variables
 of the slat or free stream parameters.
 The former can have a non-linear relation with the shape parameters of
 the shear layer and can hence introduce unpredictability if the noise levels
 are modelled in terms of the former only.
\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
\begin_inset Note Comment
status open

\begin_layout Plain Layout
\begin_inset CommandInset bibtex
LatexCommand bibtex
btprint "btPrintCited"
bibfiles "/home/amurali/Desktop/References/zoterolibrary"
options "unsrtnat"

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_inset


\end_layout

\end_body

\begin_body

\begin_layout Chapter
Conclusions and Future Perspectives
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The research presented in this thesis attempts to advance the understanding
 of leading-edge slat noise through high-fidelity simulation, detailed flow
 analysis, and innovative surrogate modeling.
 The main findings from each chapter can be summarized as follows:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Paragraph
Literature Review – Aeroacoustic Noise Mechanisms and Slat Noise:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The survey of past studies highlighted the canonical aeroacoustic mechanisms
 with the objective to explain the leading-edge slat noise.
 One striking feature of slat noise research is that there exists a discrepancy
 between the experiment and flight test for the tonal nature of its noise.
 The tones are not acknowledged to exist in the flight test data but are
 a prominent feature in subscale noise testing from early on.
 Also despite extensive experimental efforts and analytical models, the
 complex cove flow dynamics of slats remained only partially understood,
 with phenomena like intermittent behavior of the aeroacoustic tones reported
 but not fully explained.
 This motivated the use of advanced computational approaches.
 The Lattice Boltzmann Method (LBM) emerged as a promising tool for aeroacoustic
 simulation of such flows, offering inherently low dissipation and excellent
 parallel scalability for capturing acoustic waves.
 The literature review thus established both the need for high-fidelity
 analysis of slat noise mechanisms to investigate it in light of known aeroacous
tic mechanisms and the potential of LBM to meet this need.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Paragraph
Simulation Framework – LBM validation for Aeroacoustics:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
A comprehensive study of the theoretical underpinning of LBM and a validation
 of the LBM solver 
\begin_inset Formula $\emph{ProLB}$
\end_inset

 was carried out for a standard slat configuration in free-stream conditions.
 The solver was able to reproduce the mean flow field and surface pressure
 distribution on the slat-main element configuration with good accuracy
 when compared to experimental data.
 In particular, the simulated wall-pressure coefficients on the slat and
 main element showed the correct trends and magnitude, with minor discrepancies
 attributable to differences of experimental setup from that of simulation.
 The far-field sound predictions using a Ffowcs Williams–Hawkings (FWH)
 acoustic analogy also demonstrated a close agreement across the frequency
 range of interest, confirming that the LBM-FWH approach can capture both
 broadband and tonal noise components of the slat.
 This validation aided to establish confidence in the numerical framework’s
 capability for high-fidelity aeroacoustic simulation of slat noise.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Paragraph
Flow Physics of the Slat Cove:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Using the validated solver, an in-depth analysis of the baseline (standard)
 slat geometry was performed to investigate the noise-generation mechanisms.
 The study revealed the details of a highly complex unsteady flow in the
 slat cove region characterized by spanwise-periodic cellular structures
 in the recirculation bubble.
 These spanwise cells – alternating converging and diverging flow regions
 along the span – are driven by a centrifugal instability of the curved
 shear layer in the cove.
 As the shear layer rolls over the slat cusp, it forms spanwise coherent
 vortices that initially organize according to the cellular pressure pattern.
 During this thesis we have uncovered a previously unknown localised and
 periodic “bursting” phenomenon at a characteristic non-dimensional frequency
 around St ≈ 0.16 (based on slat chord and freestream velocity) which corresponds
 to the recirculation frequency of the slat cove.
 The spanwise coherent vortical structures shed from the cusp also abruptly
 breaks down into smaller-scale streamwise vortices.
 This bursting occurs preferentially at the diverging planes of the spanwise
 cells (where a pressure deficit accumulates) and convects downstream with
 the shear layer.
 The result is a recurrent injection of turbulence into the shear layer.
 These findings expand on the current understanding of slat cove dynamics
 by pinpointing a specific mechanism for the transition from large coherent
 structures to fine-scale turbulence via an intrinsic unsteady mode of the
 recirculation flow.
 Notably, the estimated frequency of the cove “pulsation” matches the low-freque
ncy tone observed in slat noise spectra, suggesting a direct link between
 the unsteady recirculation and acoustic emissions.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Paragraph
Slat Noise Generation Mechanisms:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
The flow features thus understood translated into clear noise-generation
 pathways.
 The shear layer emanating from the slat cusp impinges on the slat trailing
 edge, and its unsteadiness induces pressure fluctuations.
 These fluctuations can emanate themselves as farfield noise but also interact
 with the vortex shedding at the slat cusp to cause an aeroacoustic resonance.
 The resonant modes act as sources of tonal noise.
 The intermittent breakdown of spanwise coherence in the shear layer explains
 the tone intermittency and mode switching reported in experiments for slat
 noise – essentially, the effective coherence length of the noise sources
 in the gap can shorten when a burst occurs, leading to a temporary reduction
 or shift of tonal noise, before coherence rebuilds and tones re-emerge.
 Thus, the study provides a physical explanation for the stochastic behavior
 of slat tones (as observed by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "Jawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 and others) by relating it to the intrinsic variability of the cove flow.
 In summary, the dominant slat noise sources were found to be: (1) the unsteady
 shear layer impingement causing aeroacoustic resonance, producing a primary
 tonal noise at the burst frequency and its harmonics, and (2) additional
 broadband contributions from the smaller-scale turbulent structures convected
 through the gap.
 Importantly, no evidence was found of purely artificial acoustic modes
 due to the computational setup – the spanwise cellular pattern was confirmed
 to be a physical feature rather than a numerical artifact, as it persisted
 when varying the spanwise domain length, boundary conditions, and slat
 positioning.
 The variability from no cell formation to wave numbers of 
\begin_inset Formula $L_{z}/5$
\end_inset

 where 
\begin_inset Formula $L_{z}$
\end_inset

 is the spanwise length provides a validation of the same fact.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Paragraph
Surrogate Modeling and Parametric Study:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
To extend the analysis beyond a single geometry, a surrogate modeling framework
 was developed to investigate slat noise across a range of slat positions.
 Using a Gaussian Process (GP) regression as the surrogate, coupled with
 an active learning strategy (Upper Confidence Bound, UCB), the study explored
 a three-dimensional parameter space of slat gap, overlap, and deflection
 angle, i.e.
 positions relative to the main element.
 The use of a statistical surrogate model has the objective of maximizing
 the sampling efficiency for the parametric simulation, and also to introduce
 such methods to aeroacoustic engineering research.
 The surrogate model was trained on a limited set of high-fidelity LBM simulatio
ns and was able to predict the noise spectra for any intermediate slat setting,
 along with an estimate of its own uncertainty.
 This approach was also presented as an optimization tool: the UCB-driven
 sampling iteratively selected new simulation cases that were pinned to
 case that maximize the far-field noise, thereby honing in on the loudest
 configurations.
 As a result, the most acoustically critical slat setting in the considered
 design space was identified with far fewer runs than a naive parameter
 sweep.
 The surrogate’s predictions of sound pressure levels were in close agreement
 with subsequent LBM simulations for those noisiest configurations, demonstratin
g the model’s utility and the benefit of uncertainty-based sampling.
 Beyond optimization, this parametric campaign yielded a rich dataset that
 allowed us to examine the generality of the cove flow phenomena: indeed,
 the spanwise cell formation and bursting mechanism were observed across
 all tested slat positions, though the exact frequency and strength of the
 bursts showed some dependence on slat geometry.
 For instance, moving the slat outboard (increasing gap and overlap) tended
 to slightly alter the recirculation size and shift the burst frequency,
 but the qualitative behavior remained the same.
 These observations confirm that the centrifugal-instability-driven unsteadiness
 is an inherent feature of slat cove flows.
 In summary, the surrogate modeling effort not only facilitated rapid evaluation
 of slat noise performance for different geometries, but also supported
 the physical analysis by expanding the range of conditions under which
 the newly identified noise mechanism has been validated.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Overall, this thesis combined high-fidelity LBM simulations and data-driven
 surrogate modeling to gain new insights into slat noise.
 We have demonstrated that LBM can reliably capture the intricate flow physics
 and acoustics of a leading-edge slat, provided sufficient care in its numerical
 setup.
 The discovery of the spanwise cellular instability and its role in modulating
 the noise generation is a key scientific contribution, offering a deeper
 mechanistic understanding of slat noise that bridges previously disparate
 observations (tone interactions, intermittency, etc.).
 Meanwhile, the surrogate modeling approach represents a step towards practical
 aeroacoustic design optimization, showing how costly simulations can be
 leveraged in an intelligent manner to explore design changes.
 The tools and knowledge developed in this work lay a foundation for more
 efficient framework and eventually an aeroacoustic surrogate model applicable
 to real world design problems.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Section*
Future Perspectives
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
From the conclusions of this thesis, several avenues are proposed for future
 work.
 These include immediate next steps that naturally extend the current study,
 as well as long-term research directions that apply emerging techniques
 to the problem of slat noise prediction and reduction.
 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Paragraph
Expanded Parametric Studies: 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
A logical and first next step is to broaden the parameter space investigated
 for slat noise characteristics.
 In this thesis we varied the slat gap and overlap for a fixed airfoil geometry
 – the VALIANT 
\begin_inset ERT
status open
\begin_layout Plain Layout
\backslash textcolor{red}{3-element}
\end_layout
\end_inset
 configuration at a single angle of attack, Mach
 number, and Reynolds number.
 Future studies should consider a more comprehensive parametric sweep, including
 different slat deflection angles, gap sizes, profile shapes, and incoming
 velocity.
 Varying the flow conditions – such as the freestream velocity (Reynolds
 number) or angle of attack of the main wing – would provide insight into
 the scaling of the noise sources.
 Expanding the dataset in these ways would not only enhance the surrogate
 model (making it more general), but also test the limits of the current
 conclusions.
 For instance, it can answer questions like whether the bursting Strouhal
 number remain around 0.16 for other free stream velocities, or does it shift
 with different flow parameters.
 Variation of the Reynolds number can also shed light on whether the strength
 of spanwise modes and its wave number increases as the Reynolds number
 increases, and thus whether such an increased instability explain the complete
 attenuation of tonal noise at flight Reynolds numbers.
 Answering such questions would help generalize the slat noise theory and
 potentially lead to low-order design tools.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Paragraph
Further Validation and Diagnostics: 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
Although a validation was performed for the baseline case, it would strengthen
 the conclusions to seek additional experimental or high-fidelity data for
 comparison.
 Near-term efforts could involve collaborating with experimental researchers
 to obtain detailed measurements for a few key cases for instance, the loudest
 slat position identified by our surrogate model.
 Comparing measured and simulated far-field spectra, as well as any measured
 flow features, would provide a rigorous test of the new physical insights.
 This could include checking if the predicted burst frequency and spanwise
 mode pattern occur in reality.
 The recent experiments by 
\begin_inset CommandInset citation
LatexCommand citet
key "KamliyaJawahar2021"
literal "false"

\end_inset

 on slat noise intermittency, for example, might be re-examined in light
 of our findings to probe whether their wall-pressure traces or acoustic
 spectra show signatures consistent with a recirculation bubble pulsation;
 or whether the characteristics vary along the spanwise directions.
 A targeted experimental campaign on a slat-only configuration could directly
 look for the spanwise cellular flows or the unsteady recirculation bubble
 hypothesized here.
 Validating these flow features is challenging, but indirect evidence could
 support our conclusions.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Paragraph
Machine Learning Surrogates with Enhanced Capability: 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
A major long-term goal is to leverage advanced machine learning (ML) techniques
 to create surrogate models of slat noise that go beyond the limited-parameter
 Gaussian Process model developed here.
 This thesis sets the basic structure and theoretical ideas for it, but
 has implemented the surrogate primarily for Active Learning purposes.
 The same model, if continually trained for further acquisition steps can
 provide a noise surrogate, including for variations of the Reynolds number.
 Moreover, the method can be extended for more complex cases other than
 slat noise by utilizing the same method of feature reductions and representatio
n of spectral data and their uncertainties.
 Finally the stochastic Upper Confidence Bound acquisition function that
 we deployed is only one among many possible techniques, which are also
 evolving in their own literature.
 An upgradation using a more optimal acquisition function for sampling will
 be highly beneficial for industrial use.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Paragraph
Integration into Design and Noise Mitigation:
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
In the long run, the insights and tools developed here can be directed towards
 practical noise reduction strategies for high-lift devices.
 One vision is to incorporate the surrogate model (enhanced by ML as discussed
 above) into a multi-objective optimization framework for aircraft design.
 For example, an optimizer could adjust the slat geometry or deployment
 angle to minimize noise, perhaps aiming to disrupt the coherence or reduce
 the strength of the cove instabilities, while still meeting lift and aerodynami
c requirements.
 The fast evaluation provided by a surrogate model would make it feasible
 to explore a vast design space and identify novel configurations or add-on
 devices such as slat cove fillers or serrated slat cusps that achieve a
 better noise-performance trade-off.
 Any promising designs coming out of such computational optimization could
 then be validated by targeted high-fidelity simulations and experiments.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Paragraph
Extending High-Fidelity Simulations: 
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
As computing power continues to grow, it will become increasingly feasible
 to apply high-fidelity methods like LBM to more complex and realistic scenarios
, which is another long-term avenue.
 Future researchers could build on this work by simulating a full wing with
 both slat and flap in deployed position, or a complete aircraft landing
 configuration, capturing the interplay between multiple noise sources (slat,
 flap, landing gear, etc.).
 While today this would be enormously demanding, trends in GPU-based computing
 and algorithmic improvements (e.g.
 adaptive mesh refinement in LBM, better boundary conditions, coupling with
 Large-Eddy Simulation turbulence models for finer near-wall resolution)
 may bring such computations within reach.
 These simulations would validate whether the noise mechanisms identified
 in an isolated slat hold in the presence of other components and whether
 new noise source interactions emerge.
 They could also provide high-fidelity data to guide standards and regulations
 by virtually testing noise abatement scenarios.
 In summary, the long-term trajectory of this research field will likely
 see a convergence of data-driven models and intensive simulations: the
 former (ML surrogates) will rapidly explore design changes and hypotheses,
 while the simulation tools like LBM as a next-generation high-fidelity
 simulation method will verify and deepen our understanding, each feeding
 into the other.
\end_layout

\begin_layout Standard
In closing, the work accomplished in this thesis, in our expectations, has
 laid a groundwork for statistical surrogate methodology in aeroacoustic
 design and augmented the physical insights for addressing slat noise.
 By amalgamating an advanced CFD approach (LBM) with modern surrogate modeling,
 we have shown a pathway to analyze, predict, and possibly mitigate the
 complex noise generated by high-lift devices.
 The method is also generalisable to other aeroacoustic cases where complex
 industrial geometries need to be studied parametrically but where each
 experimentation is computationally expensive.
 Finally, the findings on the flow dynamics and aeroacoustic mechanisms
 that we presented not only assist in solving pieces of the long-standing
 puzzle of slat noise dynamics, but also open the door to innovative research
 directions.
 Continued efforts along the lines described will bring us closer to the
 goals of deeper scientific understanding and practical noise reduction,
 contributing to the broader aim of more environmentally sustainable aviation.
\end_layout

\end_body
\end_document
